Question 0:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ... tida perna dia liat, ___ sungay ko bisa terbuka begini
Gloss (with missing item): ... NEG once 3SG see ___ river 2SG be.able be.opened like.this
The English translation of this sentence is:[Seeing the ocean for the first time:] ‘[never before has he seen, what, a river that is so very big like this ocean,] never before has he seen you, you river can be wide like this?’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Papuan Malay pronouns often co-occur with nouns or \isi{noun} phrases, as shown in (\ref{Example_6.1}). This chapter argues that ``\textsc{pro} \textsc{np}'' constructions in which a \isi{pronoun} precedes a \isi{noun} or \isi{noun} phrase, as in \textitbf{the morpheme ___ }[\textitbf{sungay the morpheme ___}] ‘you, [you river]’, constitute appositional constructions, with the pronouns having pronominal function. ``\textsc{np} \textsc{pro}'' constructions in which the \isi{pronoun} follows a \isi{noun} or \isi{noun} phrase, as in \textitbf{sungay the morpheme ___} ‘you river’, by contrast, are analyzed as \isi{noun} phrases with adnominally used pronouns in post-head position. To demonstrate this distinction, appositional \textsc{pro} \textsc{np} constructions and adnominal \textsc{np} \textsc{pro} constructions are discussed in some detail in §\ref{Para_6.1.6} and §\ref{Para_6.2}, respectively.
A: word: ko	 gloss: 2SG
B: word: skola	 gloss: go.to.school
C: word: dua~dua	 gloss: RDP~two
D: word: martin	 gloss: Martin
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 1:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ... tida perna dia liat, ko ___ ko bisa terbuka begini
Gloss (with missing item): ... NEG once 3SG see 2SG ___ 2SG be.able be.opened like.this
The English translation of this sentence is:[Seeing the ocean for the first time:] ‘[never before has he seen, what, a river that is so very big like this ocean,] never before has he seen you, you river can be wide like this?’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Papuan Malay pronouns often co-occur with nouns or \isi{noun} phrases, as shown in (\ref{Example_6.1}). This chapter argues that ``\textsc{pro} \textsc{np}'' constructions in which a \isi{pronoun} precedes a \isi{noun} or \isi{noun} phrase, as in \textitbf{ko }[\textitbf{the morpheme ___ ko}] ‘you, [you its gloss ___]’, constitute appositional constructions, with the pronouns having pronominal function. ``\textsc{np} \textsc{pro}'' constructions in which the \isi{pronoun} follows a \isi{noun} or \isi{noun} phrase, as in \textitbf{the morpheme ___ ko} ‘you its gloss ___’, by contrast, are analyzed as \isi{noun} phrases with adnominally used pronouns in post-head position. To demonstrate this distinction, appositional \textsc{pro} \textsc{np} constructions and adnominal \textsc{np} \textsc{pro} constructions are discussed in some detail in §\ref{Para_6.1.6} and §\ref{Para_6.2}, respectively.
A: word: sungay	 gloss: river
B: word: langsung	 gloss: immediately
C: word: air	 gloss: water
D: word: saya	 gloss: 1SG
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 2:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ... tida perna dia liat, ko sungay ___ bisa terbuka begini
Gloss (with missing item): ... NEG once 3SG see 2SG river ___ be.able be.opened like.this
The English translation of this sentence is:[Seeing the ocean for the first time:] ‘[never before has he seen, what, a river that is so very big like this ocean,] never before has he seen you, you river can be wide like this?’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Papuan Malay pronouns often co-occur with nouns or \isi{noun} phrases, as shown in (\ref{Example_6.1}). This chapter argues that ``\textsc{pro} \textsc{np}'' constructions in which a \isi{pronoun} precedes a \isi{noun} or \isi{noun} phrase, as in \textitbf{the morpheme ___ }[\textitbf{sungay the morpheme ___}] ‘you, [you river]’, constitute appositional constructions, with the pronouns having pronominal function. ``\textsc{np} \textsc{pro}'' constructions in which the \isi{pronoun} follows a \isi{noun} or \isi{noun} phrase, as in \textitbf{sungay the morpheme ___} ‘you river’, by contrast, are analyzed as \isi{noun} phrases with adnominally used pronouns in post-head position. To demonstrate this distinction, appositional \textsc{pro} \textsc{np} constructions and adnominal \textsc{np} \textsc{pro} constructions are discussed in some detail in §\ref{Para_6.1.6} and §\ref{Para_6.2}, respectively.
A: word: ko	 gloss: 2SG
B: word: skola	 gloss: go.to.school
C: word: goyang	 gloss: shake
D: word: dengang	 gloss: with
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 3:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): sa su pukul ___ di kamar
Gloss (with missing item): 1SG already hit ___ at room
The English translation of this sentence is:‘I already hit her in (her) room’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: This tendency for the clause-final position to be the preferred site for the ``heavy'' long \isi{pronoun} forms affects the choice of the \isi{pronoun} form for the different object slots, as shown in (\ref{Example_6.2}) to (\ref{Example_6.12}).
A: word: dia	 gloss: 3SG
B: word: diai	 gloss: 3SG
C: word: dei	 gloss: 3sg
D: word: nusa	 gloss: Nusa
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 4:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): tete ini bilang ___ dong
Gloss (with missing item): grandfather D.PROX say ___ 3PL
The English translation of this sentence is:‘this grandfather spoke to them’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: This tendency for the clause-final position its gloss ___ be the preferred site for the ``heavy'' long \isi{pronoun} forms affects the choice of the \isi{pronoun} form for the different object slots, as shown in (\ref{Example_6.2}) its gloss ___ (\ref{Example_6.12}).
A: word: sama	 gloss: to
B: word: sama~sama	 gloss: RDP~be.same
C: word: harus	 gloss: have.to
D: word: itu	 gloss: D.DIST
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 5:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): tete ini bilang sama ___
Gloss (with missing item): grandfather D.PROX say to ___
The English translation of this sentence is:‘this grandfather spoke to them’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: This tendency for the clause-final position to be the preferred site for the ``heavy'' long \isi{pronoun} forms affects the choice of the \isi{pronoun} form for the different object slots, as shown in (\ref{Example_6.2}) to (\ref{Example_6.12}).
A: word: dong	 gloss: 3PL
B: word: dong/dorang	 gloss: 3PL
C: word: kam	 gloss: 2PL
D: word: herman	 gloss: Herman
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 6:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): sa su pukul ___ di kamar
Gloss (with missing item): 1SG already hit ___ at room
The English translation of this sentence is:‘I already hit her in (her) room’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In the examples in (\ref{Example_6.2}) to (\ref{Example_6.5}), the pronouns take the direct object slot in monotransitive clauses. When the direct object occurs in clause-internal position, both the long and the short \isi{pronoun} forms are used, as shown with long \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘\textsc{3sg}’ in (\ref{Example_6.2}) and short \textitbf{de} ‘\textsc{3sg}’ in (\ref{Example_6.3}). When the direct object occurs in clause-final position, speakers typically take the long \isi{pronoun} form, such as \textitbf{saya} ‘\textsc{1sg}’ in (\ref{Example_6.4}). Only rarely do speakers employ a short \isi{pronoun} form in clause-final position, such as \textitbf{sa} ‘\textsc{1sg}’ in (\ref{Example_6.5}).
A: word: dia	 gloss: 3SG
B: word: diai	 gloss: 3SG
C: word: dei	 gloss: 3sg
D: word: dorang	 gloss: 3PL
Please only return the letter (A–D).

You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option.

Gloss (with missing item): 1SG already hit ___ at room
The English translation of this sentence is:‘I already hit her in (her) room’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In the examples in (\ref{Example_6.2}) to (\ref{Example_6.5}), the pronouns take the direct object slot in monotransitive clauses. When the direct object occurs in clause-internal position, both the long and the short \isi{pronoun} forms are used, as shown with long \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘\textsc{3sg}’ in (\ref{Example_6.2}) and short \textitbf{de} ‘\textsc{3sg}’ in (\ref{Example_6.3}). When the direct object occurs in clause-final position, speakers typically take the long \isi{pronoun} form, such as \textitbf{saya} ‘\textsc{1sg}’ in (\ref{Example_6.4}). Only rarely do speakers employ a short \isi{pronoun} form in clause-final position, such as \textitbf{sa} ‘\textsc{1sg}’ in (\ref{Example_6.5}).

Question 8:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): sa tanya ___ begini
Gloss (with missing item): 1SG ask ___ like.this
The English translation of this sentence is:‘I asked her like this’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In the examples in (\ref{Example_6.2}) to (\ref{Example_6.5}), the pronouns take the direct object slot in monotransitive clauses. When the direct object occurs in clause-internal position, both the long and the short \isi{pronoun} forms are used, as shown with long \textitbf{dia} ‘\textsc{3sg}’ in (\ref{Example_6.2}) and short \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘\textsc{3sg}’ in (\ref{Example_6.3}). When the direct object occurs in clause-final position, speakers typically take the long \isi{pronoun} form, such as \textitbf{saya} ‘\textsc{1sg}’ in (\ref{Example_6.4}). Only rarely do speakers employ a short \isi{pronoun} form in clause-final position, such as \textitbf{sa} ‘\textsc{1sg}’ in (\ref{Example_6.5}).
A: word: de	 gloss: 3SG
B: word: deng	 gloss: with
C: word: dei	 gloss: 3sg
D: word: ipa	 gloss: natural.sciences
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 9:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): nanti ko kejar ___
Gloss (with missing item): very.soon 2SG chase ___
The English translation of this sentence is:‘in a moment you chase me’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In the examples in (\ref{Example_6.2}) to (\ref{Example_6.5}), the pronouns take the direct object slot in monotransitive clauses. When the direct object occurs in clause-internal position, both the long and the short \isi{pronoun} forms are used, as shown with long \textitbf{dia} ‘\textsc{3sg}’ in (\ref{Example_6.2}) and short \textitbf{de} ‘\textsc{3sg}’ in (\ref{Example_6.3}). When the direct object occurs in clause-final position, speakers typically take the long \isi{pronoun} form, such as \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘\textsc{1sg}’ in (\ref{Example_6.4}). Only rarely do speakers employ a short \isi{pronoun} form in clause-final position, such as \textitbf{sa} ‘\textsc{1sg}’ in (\ref{Example_6.5}).
A: word: saya	 gloss: 1SG
B: word: sayang	 gloss: love
C: word: dei	 gloss: 3sg
D: word: ana	 gloss: child
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 10:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): kasi ___ ana satu!
Gloss (with missing item): kasi ___ child one
The English translation of this sentence is:‘give me a certain child!’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In the examples in (\ref{Example_6.6}) to (\ref{Example_6.8}), the pronouns take a direct object slot in \isi{double-object} constructions. In this position the mentioned, distributional preferences are even more pronounced. In clause-internal position, both the long and the short \isi{pronoun} forms occur, such as long \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘\textsc{1sg}’ in (\ref{Example_6.6}) and short \textitbf{dong} ‘\textsc{3pl}’ in (\ref{Example_6.7}). In clause-final position, by contrast, only the long \isi{pronoun} forms are attested, such as \textitbf{dorang} ‘\textsc{3pl}’ in (\ref{Example_6.8}). (Double-object constructions are discussed in detail in §\ref{Para_11.1.3.1}.)
A: word: saya	 gloss: 1SG
B: word: sayang	 gloss: love
C: word: dei	 gloss: 3sg
D: word: yang	 gloss: REL
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 11:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): sa mulay kasi nasihat ___
Gloss (with missing item): 1SG START give advice ___
The English translation of this sentence is:‘I started giving them advice’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In the examples in (\ref{Example_6.6}) to (\ref{Example_6.8}), the pronouns take a direct object slot in \isi{double-object} constructions. In this position the mentioned, distributional preferences are even more pronounced. In clause-internal position, both the long and the short \isi{pronoun} forms occur, such as long \textitbf{saya} ‘\textsc{1sg}’ in (\ref{Example_6.6}) and short \textitbf{dong} ‘\textsc{3pl}’ in (\ref{Example_6.7}). In clause-final position, by contrast, only the long \isi{pronoun} forms are attested, such as \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘\textsc{3pl}’ in (\ref{Example_6.8}). (Double-object constructions are discussed in detail in §\ref{Para_11.1.3.1}.)
A: word: dorang	 gloss: 2PL
B: word: dong/dorang	 gloss: 3PL
C: word: tong	 gloss: 1PL
D: word: kaka	 gloss: oSb
Please only return the letter (A–D).

In this position the mentioned, distributional preferences are even more pronounced. In clause-internal position, both the long and the short \isi{pronoun} forms occur, such as long \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘\textsc{1sg}’ in (\ref{Example_6.6}) and short \textitbf{dong} ‘\textsc{3pl}’ in (\ref{Example_6.7}). In clause-final position, by contrast, only the long \isi{pronoun} forms are attested, such as \textitbf{dorang} ‘\textsc{3pl}’ in (\ref{Example_6.8}). Question 13:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): kaka kirim ___ uang
Gloss (with missing item): oSb send ___ money
The English translation of this sentence is:‘the older sibling sent them money’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In the examples in (\ref{Example_6.6}) to (\ref{Example_6.8}), the pronouns take a direct object slot in \isi{double-object} constructions. In this position the mentioned, distributional preferences are even more pronounced. In clause-internal position, both the long and the short \isi{pronoun} forms occur, such as long \textitbf{saya} ‘\textsc{1sg}’ in (\ref{Example_6.6}) and short \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘\textsc{3pl}’ in (\ref{Example_6.7}). In clause-final position, by contrast, only the long \isi{pronoun} forms are attested, such as \textitbf{dorang} ‘\textsc{3pl}’ in (\ref{Example_6.8}). (Double-object constructions are discussed in detail in §\ref{Para_11.1.3.1}.)
A: word: dong	 gloss: 2PL
B: word: dong/dorang	 gloss: 3PL
C: word: tong	 gloss: 1PL
D: word: cantik	 gloss: be.beautiful
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 14:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): sa mulay kasi nasihat ___
Gloss (with missing item): 1SG START give advice ___
The English translation of this sentence is:‘I started giving them advice’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In the examples in (\ref{Example_6.6}) to (\ref{Example_6.8}), the pronouns take a direct object slot in \isi{double-object} constructions. In this position the mentioned, distributional preferences are even more pronounced. In clause-internal position, both the long and the short \isi{pronoun} forms occur, such as long \textitbf{saya} ‘\textsc{1sg}’ in (\ref{Example_6.6}) and short \textitbf{dong} ‘\textsc{3pl}’ in (\ref{Example_6.7}). In clause-final position, by contrast, only the long \isi{pronoun} forms are attested, such as \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘\textsc{3pl}’ in (\ref{Example_6.8}). (Double-object constructions are discussed in detail in §\ref{Para_11.1.3.1}.)
A: word: dorang	 gloss: 2PL
B: word: dong/dorang	 gloss: 3PL
C: word: tong	 gloss: 1PL
D: word: barce	 gloss: Barce
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 15:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): sa bilang ___ dorang yang di kampung
Gloss (with missing item): 1SG speak ___ 3PL REL at village
The English translation of this sentence is:‘I told them who are in the village’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: As for pronouns in oblique object slots, again both the long and the short \isi{pronoun} forms are used, such as long \textitbf{dorang} ‘\textsc{3pl}’ in (\ref{Example_6.9}) or short \textitbf{sa} ‘\textsc{1sg}’ in (\ref{Example_6.10}). In clause-final position, however, typically the long \isi{pronoun} forms are used, such as \textitbf{dorang} ‘\textsc{3pl}’ in (\ref{Example_6.11}), while short \isi{pronoun} forms such as \textitbf{dong} ‘\textsc{3pl}’ in (\ref{Example_6.12}) are very rare.
A: word: sama	 gloss: to
B: word: sama~sama	 gloss: RDP~be.same
C: word: harus	 gloss: have.to
D: word: senggi	 gloss: Senggi
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 16:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): sa bilang sama ___ yang di kampung
Gloss (with missing item): 1SG speak to ___ REL at village
The English translation of this sentence is:‘I told them who are in the village’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: As for pronouns in oblique object slots, again both the long and the short \isi{pronoun} forms are used, such as long \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘\textsc{3pl}’ in (\ref{Example_6.9}) or short \textitbf{sa} ‘\textsc{1sg}’ in (\ref{Example_6.10}). In clause-final position, however, typically the long \isi{pronoun} forms are used, such as \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘\textsc{3pl}’ in (\ref{Example_6.11}), while short \isi{pronoun} forms such as \textitbf{dong} ‘\textsc{3pl}’ in (\ref{Example_6.12}) are very rare.
A: word: dorang	 gloss: 3PL
B: word: dong/dorang	 gloss: 3PL
C: word: kam	 gloss: 2PL
D: word: mace	 gloss: woman
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 17:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): itu yang sa kas taw ___ dorang
Gloss (with missing item): D.DIST REL 1SG already know ___ 3PL
The English translation of this sentence is:‘that (is) what I let them know’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: As for pronouns in oblique object slots, again both the long and the short \isi{pronoun} forms are used, such as long \textitbf{dorang} ‘\textsc{3pl}’ in (\ref{Example_6.9}) or short \textitbf{sa} ‘\textsc{1sg}’ in (\ref{Example_6.10}). In clause-final position, however, typically the long \isi{pronoun} forms are used, such as \textitbf{dorang} ‘\textsc{3pl}’ in (\ref{Example_6.11}), while short \isi{pronoun} forms such as \textitbf{dong} ‘\textsc{3pl}’ in (\ref{Example_6.12}) are very rare.
A: word: sama	 gloss: to
B: word: sama~sama	 gloss: RDP~be.same
C: word: harus	 gloss: have.to
D: word: ipa	 gloss: natural.sciences
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 18:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): itu yang sa kas taw sama ___
Gloss (with missing item): D.DIST REL 1SG already know to ___
The English translation of this sentence is:‘that (is) what I let them know’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: As for pronouns in oblique object slots, again both the long and the short \isi{pronoun} forms are used, such as long \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘\textsc{3pl}’ in (\ref{Example_6.9}) or short \textitbf{sa} ‘\textsc{1sg}’ in (\ref{Example_6.10}). In clause-final position, however, typically the long \isi{pronoun} forms are used, such as \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘\textsc{3pl}’ in (\ref{Example_6.11}), while short \isi{pronoun} forms such as \textitbf{dong} ‘\textsc{3pl}’ in (\ref{Example_6.12}) are very rare.
A: word: dorang	 gloss: 3PL
B: word: dong/dorang	 gloss: 3PL
C: word: kam	 gloss: 2PL
D: word: dodo	 gloss: Dodo
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 19:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): tete ini bilang ___ dong
Gloss (with missing item): grandfather D.PROX say ___ 3PL
The English translation of this sentence is:‘this grandfather spoke to them’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: As for pronouns in oblique object slots, again both the long and the short \isi{pronoun} forms are used, such as long \textitbf{dorang} ‘\textsc{3pl}’ in (\ref{Example_6.9}) or short \textitbf{sa} ‘\textsc{1sg}’ in (\ref{Example_6.10}). In clause-final position, however, typically the long \isi{pronoun} forms are used, such as \textitbf{dorang} ‘\textsc{3pl}’ in (\ref{Example_6.11}), while short \isi{pronoun} forms such as \textitbf{dong} ‘\textsc{3pl}’ in (\ref{Example_6.12}) are very rare.
A: word: sama	 gloss: to
B: word: sama~sama	 gloss: RDP~be.same
C: word: harus	 gloss: have.to
D: word: isabela	 gloss: Isabela
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 21:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. The English translation of this sentence is:‘so I (emph) am a bride-price child’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Pronouns are readily modified with a number of different constituents, namely demonstratives, locatives, numerals, quantifiers, prepositional phrases, and/or relative clauses, as illustrated with the examples in (\ref{Example_6.13}) to (\ref{Example_6.24}).
A: word: saya	 gloss: 1SG
B: word: sayang	 gloss: love
C: word: dei	 gloss: 3sg
D: word: martina	 gloss: Martina

Question 26:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): jadi ___ ini ana mas-kawing
Gloss (with missing item): so ___ D.PROX child bride.price
The English translation of this sentence is:‘so I (emph) am a bride-price child’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Proximal \isi{demonstrative} \textitbf{ini} ‘\textsc{d.prox}’ modifies long \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘\textsc{1sg}’ in (\ref{Example_6.13}), while distal \textitbf{itu} ‘\textsc{d.dist}’ modifies \textitbf{ko} ‘\textsc{2sg}’ in example (\ref{Example_6.14}). In both examples, the demonstratives signal the speaker's psychological involvement with the events being talked about. In (\ref{Example_6.15}), distal \isi{locative} \textitbf{sana} ‘\textsc{l.dist}’ modifies short \textitbf{dong} ‘\textsc{3sg}’, designating the referent’s location relative to that of the speaker. In the corpus, pronouns are quite often modified with demonstratives, while \isi{modification} with locatives is rare. (For details on demonstratives and locatives and their different functions see \chapref{Para_6}.)
A: word: saya	 gloss: 1SG
B: word: sayang	 gloss: love
C: word: dei	 gloss: 3sg
D: word: oktofina	 gloss: Oktofina
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 28:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Proximal \isi{demonstrative} \textitbf{ini} ‘\textsc{d.prox}’ modifies long \textitbf{saya} ‘\textsc{1sg}’ in (\ref{Example_6.13}), while distal \textitbf{itu} ‘\textsc{d.dist}’ modifies \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘\textsc{2sg}’ in example (\ref{Example_6.14}). In both examples, the demonstratives signal the speaker's psychological involvement with the events being talked about. In (\ref{Example_6.15}), distal \isi{locative} \textitbf{sana} ‘\textsc{l.dist}’ modifies short \textitbf{dong} ‘\textsc{3sg}’, designating the referent’s location relative to that of the speaker. In the corpus, pronouns are quite often modified with demonstratives, while \isi{modification} with locatives is rare. (For details on demonstratives and locatives and their different functions see \chapref{Para_6}.)
A: word: ko	 gloss: 2SG

D: word: jepang	 gloss: Japan

In both examples, the demonstratives signal the speaker's psychological involvement with the events being talked about. Question 32:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ___ dua mandi, pas Nofita de datang
Gloss (with missing item): ___ two bathe precisely Nofita 3SG come
The English translation of this sentence is:‘the two of us were bathing, at that moment Nofita came’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Modification with numerals typically involves the \isi{numeral} \textitbf{dua} ‘two’, as with short \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘\textsc{1pl}’ in (\ref{Example_6.16}), but constructions with \textitbf{tiga} ‘three’ are also found. In the corpus, \isi{modification} with quantifiers is limited to universal \textitbf{smua} ‘all’ and mid-range \textitbf{brapa} ‘several’, as shown with long \textitbf{kamu} ‘\textsc{2pl}’ in (\ref{Example_6.17}) and long \textitbf{dorang} ‘\textsc{3pl}’ in (\ref{Example_6.18}), respectively. Modification with other quantifiers is also possible, as shown with midrange \textitbf{banyak} ‘many’ in the elicited example in (\ref{Example_6.19}). The examples in (\ref{Example_6.16}) to (\ref{Example_6.19}) also demonstrate that the numerals and quantifiers always occur in post-head position. That is, they cannot occur in pre-head position as illustrated with the elicited ungrammatical constructions in (\ref{Example_6.20}) and (\ref{Example_6.21}). (In this respect pronouns differ from nouns in that \isi{noun} phrases with adnominally used numerals or quantifiers can have an \textsc{n-mod} or a \textsc{mod-n} structure, as discussed in §\ref{Para_8.3}.)
A: word: tong	 gloss: 1PL
B: word: kitong	 gloss: 1PL
C: word: kam	 gloss: 2PL
D: word: nene	 gloss: grandmother
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 33:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): tong ___ mandi, pas Nofita de datang
Gloss (with missing item): 1PL ___ bathe precisely Nofita 3SG come
The English translation of this sentence is:‘the two of us were bathing, at that moment Nofita came’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Modification with numerals typically involves the \isi{numeral} \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’, as with short \textitbf{tong} ‘\textsc{1pl}’ in (\ref{Example_6.16}), but constructions with \textitbf{tiga} ‘three’ are also found. In the corpus, \isi{modification} with quantifiers is limited to universal \textitbf{smua} ‘all’ and mid-range \textitbf{brapa} ‘several’, as shown with long \textitbf{kamu} ‘\textsc{2pl}’ in (\ref{Example_6.17}) and long \textitbf{dorang} ‘\textsc{3pl}’ in (\ref{Example_6.18}), respectively. Modification with other quantifiers is also possible, as shown with midrange \textitbf{banyak} ‘many’ in the elicited example in (\ref{Example_6.19}). The examples in (\ref{Example_6.16}) to (\ref{Example_6.19}) also demonstrate that the numerals and quantifiers always occur in post-head position. That is, they cannot occur in pre-head position as illustrated with the elicited ungrammatical constructions in (\ref{Example_6.20}) and (\ref{Example_6.21}). (In this respect pronouns differ from nouns in that \isi{noun} phrases with adnominally used numerals or quantifiers can have an \textsc{n-mod} or a \textsc{mod-n} structure, as discussed in §\ref{Para_8.3}.)
A: word: dua	 gloss: two
B: word: siduasi	 gloss: Siduas
C: word: kedua	 gloss: second
D: word: sungay	 gloss: river
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 34:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Modification with other quantifiers is also possible, as shown with midrange \textitbf{banyak} ‘many’ in the elicited example in (\ref{Example_6.19}). The examples in (\ref{Example_6.16}) to (\ref{Example_6.19}) also demonstrate that the numerals and quantifiers always occur in post-head position. That is, they cannot occur in pre-head position as illustrated with the elicited ungrammatical constructions in (\ref{Example_6.20}) and (\ref{Example_6.21}). (In this respect pronouns differ from nouns in that \isi{noun} phrases with adnominally used numerals or quantifiers can have an \textsc{n-mod} or a \textsc{mod-n} structure, as discussed in §\ref{Para_8.3}.)
A: word: dorang	 gloss: 3PL

Question 35:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Question 36:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): sa maki dorang brapa ___
Gloss (with missing item): 1SG abuse.verbally 3PL several ___
The English translation of this sentence is:‘I verbally abused several of them there’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Modification with numerals typically involves the \isi{numeral} \textitbf{dua} ‘two’, as with short \textitbf{tong} ‘\textsc{1pl}’ in (\ref{Example_6.16}), but constructions with \textitbf{tiga} ‘three’ are also found. In the corpus, \isi{modification} with quantifiers is limited to universal \textitbf{smua} ‘all’ and mid-range \textitbf{brapa} ‘several’, as shown with long \textitbf{kamu} ‘\textsc{2pl}’ in (\ref{Example_6.17}) and long \textitbf{dorang} ‘\textsc{3pl}’ in (\ref{Example_6.18}), respectively. Modification with other quantifiers is also possible, as shown with midrange \textitbf{banyak} ‘many’ in the elicited example in (\ref{Example_6.19}). The examples in (\ref{Example_6.16}) to (\ref{Example_6.19}) also demonstrate that the numerals and quantifiers always occur in post-head position. That is, they cannot occur in pre-head position as illustrated with the elicited ungrammatical constructions in (\ref{Example_6.20}) and (\ref{Example_6.21}). (In this respect pronouns differ from nouns in that \isi{noun} phrases with adnominally used numerals or quantifiers can have an \textsc{n-mod} or a \textsc{mod-n} structure, as discussed in §\ref{Para_8.3}.)
A: word: itu	 gloss: D.DIST
B: word: situ	 gloss: L.MED
C: word: sana	 gloss: L.DIST
D: word: bangsat	 gloss: rascal
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 37:

Question 40:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Question 44:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Modification with numerals typically involves the \isi{numeral} \textitbf{dua} ‘two’, as with short \textitbf{tong} ‘\textsc{1pl}’ in (\ref{Example_6.16}), but constructions with \textitbf{tiga} ‘three’ are also found. That is, they cannot occur in pre-head position as illustrated with the elicited ungrammatical constructions in (\ref{Example_6.20}) and (\ref{Example_6.21}). (In this respect pronouns differ from nouns in that \isi{noun} phrases with adnominally used numerals or quantifiers can have an \textsc{n-mod} or a \textsc{mod-n} structure, as discussed in §\ref{Para_8.3}.)

Question 45:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): langsung mandi, ___ mulay mandi smua
Gloss (with missing item): immediately bathe ___ start bathe all
The English translation of this sentence is:‘[We arrived here, arrived by motorboat,] immediately (we) bathed, we started all bathing’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In the corpus, the numerals and quantifiers typically form constituents with the quantified pronouns. That is, floating numerals or quantifiers are unattested, with one exception though. Quantifier \textitbf{smua} ‘all’ can also float to a clause-final position, as shown in (\ref{Example_6.22}). (This observation that among the numerals and quantifiers only \isi{quantifier} \textitbf{smua} ‘all’ floats also applies to the \isi{modification} of nouns, as discussed in §\ref{Para_8.3}.)
A: word: kitong	 gloss: 1PL
B: word: tong	 gloss: 1PL
C: word: kam	 gloss: 2PL
D: word: dia	 gloss: 3SG
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 46:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): langsung mandi, kitong mulay mandi ___
Gloss (with missing item): immediately bathe 1PL start bathe ___
The English translation of this sentence is:‘[We arrived here, arrived by motorboat,] immediately (we) bathed, we started all bathing’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In the corpus, the numerals and quantifiers typicits gloss ___y form constituents with the quantified pronouns. That is, floating numerals or quantifiers are unattested, with one exception though. Quantifier \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ can also float to a clause-final position, as shown in (\ref{Example_6.22}). (This observation that among the numerals and quantifiers only \isi{quantifier} \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ floats also applies to the \isi{modification} of nouns, as discussed in §\ref{Para_8.3}.)
A: word: smua	 gloss: all
B: word: mulay	 gloss: start
C: word: tiap	 gloss: every
D: word: kaka	 gloss: oSb
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 47:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): tapi ___ di sana tu tida taw pencuri
Gloss (with missing item): but ___ at L.DIST D.DIST NEG know thief/steal
The English translation of this sentence is:‘but them over there (emph) never steal’ (Lit. ‘don’t know to steal’)
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Further, pronouns can be modified with prepositional phrases as illustrated with \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘\textsc{3pl}’ in (\ref{Example_6.23}), or with relative clauses as shown with short \textitbf{sa} ‘\textsc{1sg}’ in (\ref{Example_6.24}).
A: word: dong	 gloss: 3PL
B: word: dong/dorang	 gloss: 3PL
C: word: kam	 gloss: 2PL
D: word: natalia	 gloss: Natalia
Please only return the letter (A–D).

A: word: di	 gloss: at
B: word: dia	 gloss: 3SG
C: word: cuma	 gloss: just

Question 53:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): waktu de kawing mas-kawing itu sa yang ___
Gloss (with missing item): when 3SG marry.unofficially bride.price that 1SG REL ___
The English translation of this sentence is:‘when she marries, that bride-price, (it’s) me who’ll get (it)’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Further, pronouns can be modified with prepositional phrases as illustrated with \textitbf{dong} ‘\textsc{3pl}’ in (\ref{Example_6.23}), or with relative clauses as shown with short \textitbf{sa} ‘\textsc{1sg}’ in (\ref{Example_6.24}).
A: word: ambil	 gloss: get
B: word: bilang	 gloss: say
C: word: bangung	 gloss: get.up
D: word: waim	 gloss: Waim
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 54:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): nanti ___ pu maytua tanya, ko dapat ikang di mana
Gloss (with missing item): very.soon ___ POSS wife ask 2SG get fish at where
The English translation of this sentence is:‘later his wife will ask, ``where did you get the fish?'''
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In (\ref{Example_6.25}), one possessive construction is presented in context with long \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘\textsc{3sg}’ taking the possessor slot in (\ref{Example_6.25}). (For a detailed discussion of adnominal possessive constructions see \chapref{Para_9}.)
A: word: dia	 gloss: 3SG
B: word: diai	 gloss: 3SG
C: word: dei	 gloss: 3sg
D: word: brapa	 gloss: several
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 60:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ... ___ dua deng bapa tu sayang dia
Gloss (with missing item): ... ___ two with father D.DIST love 3SG
The English translation of this sentence is:‘[but this child] I and (my) husband (emph) love her’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Papuan Malay also employs plural pronouns in inclusory \isi{conjunction} constructions, such that ``\textsc{pro-pl} \textitbf{(dua) dengang} \textsc{np}'' or ``\textsc{pro-pl} (two) with \textsc{np}''. The conjunct that designates the entire set is encoded by a plural \isi{pronoun}. This conjunct is inclusory in that it “identifies a set of participants that includes the one or those referred to by the lexical \isi{noun} phrase”, as \citet[1]{Lichtenberk.2000} points out. Hence it is an “inclusory \isi{pronoun}” (\citeyear*[2]{Lichtenberk.2000}) or, as \citet[33]{Haspelmath.2007c} calls it, an “inclusory conjunct”. In Papuan Malay, both conjuncts are linked by means of overt coordination with the \isi{comitative} marker \textitbf{dengang} ‘with’, with its short form \textitbf{deng}. The inclusory conjunct precedes the included conjunct, as shown in (\ref{Example_6.26}) to (\ref{Example_6.29}).
A: word: tong	 gloss: 1PL
B: word: kitong	 gloss: 1PL
C: word: kam	 gloss: 2PL
D: word: ise	 gloss: Ise
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 61:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ... tong ___ deng bapa tu sayang dia
Gloss (with missing item): ... 1PL ___ with father D.DIST love 3SG
The English translation of this sentence is:‘[but this child] I and (my) husband (emph) love her’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Papuan Malay also employs plural pronouns in inclusory \isi{conjunction} constructions, such that ``\textsc{pro-pl} \textitbf{(the morpheme ___) dengang} \textsc{np}'' or ``\textsc{pro-pl} (its gloss ___) with \textsc{np}''. The conjunct that designates the entire set is encoded by a plural \isi{pronoun}. This conjunct is inclusory in that it “identifies a set of participants that includes the one or those referred to by the lexical \isi{noun} phrase”, as \citet[1]{Lichtenberk.2000} points out. Hence it is an “inclusory \isi{pronoun}” (\citeyear*[2]{Lichtenberk.2000}) or, as \citet[33]{Haspelmath.2007c} calls it, an “inclusory conjunct”. In Papuan Malay, both conjuncts are linked by means of overt coordination with the \isi{comitative} marker \textitbf{dengang} ‘with’, with its short form \textitbf{deng}. The inclusory conjunct precedes the included conjunct, as shown in (\ref{Example_6.26}) to (\ref{Example_6.29}).
A: word: dua	 gloss: two
B: word: siduasi	 gloss: Siduas
C: word: kedua	 gloss: second
D: word: pawlus	 gloss: Pawlus
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 62:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ... tong dua ___ bapa tu sayang dia
Gloss (with missing item): ... 1PL two ___ father D.DIST love 3SG
The English translation of this sentence is:‘[but this child] I and (my) husband (emph) love her’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Papuan Malay also employs plural pronouns in inclusory \isi{conjunction} constructions, such that ``\textsc{pro-pl} \textitbf{(dua) the morpheme ___ang} \textsc{np}'' or ``\textsc{pro-pl} (two) its gloss ___ \textsc{np}''. The conjunct that designates the entire set is encoded by a plural \isi{pronoun}. This conjunct is inclusory in that it “identifies a set of participants that includes the one or those referred to by the lexical \isi{noun} phrase”, as \citet[1]{Lichtenberk.2000} points out. Hence it is an “inclusory \isi{pronoun}” (\citeyear*[2]{Lichtenberk.2000}) or, as \citet[33]{Haspelmath.2007c} calls it, an “inclusory conjunct”. In Papuan Malay, both conjuncts are linked by means of overt coordination its gloss ___ the \isi{comitative} marker \textitbf{the morpheme ___ang} ‘its gloss ___’, its gloss ___ its short form \textitbf{the morpheme ___}. The inclusory conjunct precedes the included conjunct, as shown in (\ref{Example_6.26}) to (\ref{Example_6.29}).
A: word: deng	 gloss: with
B: word: dengang	 gloss: with
C: word: dang	 gloss: and
D: word: natalia	 gloss: Natalia
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 63:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. The conjunct that designates the entire set is encoded by a plural \isi{pronoun}. This conjunct is inclusory in that it “identifies a set of participants that includes the one or those referred to by the lexical \isi{noun} phrase”, as \citet[1]{Lichtenberk.2000} points out. Hence it is an “inclusory \isi{pronoun}” (\citeyear*[2]{Lichtenberk.2000}) or, as \citet[33]{Haspelmath.2007c} calls it, an “inclusory conjunct”. Question 65:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Papuan Malay also employs plural pronouns in inclusory \isi{conjunction} constructions, such that ``\textsc{pro-pl} \textitbf{(dua) dengang} \textsc{np}'' or ``\textsc{pro-pl} (two) with \textsc{np}''. Hence it is an “inclusory \isi{pronoun}” (\citeyear*[2]{Lichtenberk.2000}) or, as \citet[33]{Haspelmath.2007c} calls it, an “inclusory conjunct”. The inclusory conjunct precedes the included conjunct, as shown in (\ref{Example_6.26}) to (\ref{Example_6.29}).

Question 71:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ... ___ dua deng bapa tu sayang dia
Gloss (with missing item): ... ___ two with father D.DIST love 3SG
The English translation of this sentence is:‘[but this child] I and (my) husband (emph) love her’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Typically, the inclusory conjunct is encoded by a dual construction formed with a plural \isi{pronoun} and the adnominally used \isi{numeral} \textitbf{dua} ‘two’, such that ``\textsc{pro-pl} \textitbf{dua}''. In (\ref{Example_6.26}), for instance, the speaker talks about herself and her husband. That is, the entire set consists of two referents with the inclusory conjunct \textitbf{the morpheme ___ dua} ‘we two’ including the conjunct \textitbf{bapa} ‘father’ in its reference. Only rarely is the inclusory conjunct encoded by a bare plural \isi{pronoun}, as in (\ref{Example_6.27}). In this example, the entire set consists of the speaker, his wife, and their children, with the included conjunct \textitbf{ana{\Tilde}ana} ‘children’ being subsumed under the inclusory conjunct \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘\textsc{1pl}’.
A: word: tong	 gloss: 1PL
B: word: kitong	 gloss: 1PL
C: word: kam	 gloss: 2PL
D: word: martin	 gloss: Martin
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 72:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ... tong ___ deng bapa tu sayang dia
Gloss (with missing item): ... 1PL ___ with father D.DIST love 3SG
The English translation of this sentence is:‘[but this child] I and (my) husband (emph) love her’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Typically, the inclusory conjunct is encoded by a the morpheme ___l construction formed with a plural \isi{pronoun} and the adnominally used \isi{numeral} \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’, such that ``\textsc{pro-pl} \textitbf{the morpheme ___}''. In (\ref{Example_6.26}), for instance, the speaker talks about herself and her husband. That is, the entire set consists of its gloss ___ referents with the inclusory conjunct \textitbf{tong the morpheme ___} ‘we its gloss ___’ including the conjunct \textitbf{bapa} ‘father’ in its reference. Only rarely is the inclusory conjunct encoded by a bare plural \isi{pronoun}, as in (\ref{Example_6.27}). In this example, the entire set consists of the speaker, his wife, and their children, with the included conjunct \textitbf{ana{\Tilde}ana} ‘children’ being subsumed under the inclusory conjunct \textitbf{tong} ‘\textsc{1pl}’.
A: word: dua	 gloss: two
B: word: siduasi	 gloss: Siduas
C: word: kedua	 gloss: second
D: word: martin	 gloss: Martin
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 73:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ... tong dua ___ bapa tu sayang dia
Gloss (with missing item): ... 1PL two ___ father D.DIST love 3SG
The English translation of this sentence is:‘[but this child] I and (my) husband (emph) love her’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Typically, the inclusory conjunct is encoded by a dual construction formed its gloss ___ a plural \isi{pronoun} and the adnominally used \isi{numeral} \textitbf{dua} ‘two’, such that ``\textsc{pro-pl} \textitbf{dua}''. In (\ref{Example_6.26}), for instance, the speaker talks about herself and her husband. That is, the entire set consists of two referents its gloss ___ the inclusory conjunct \textitbf{tong dua} ‘we two’ including the conjunct \textitbf{bapa} ‘father’ in its reference. Only rarely is the inclusory conjunct encoded by a bare plural \isi{pronoun}, as in (\ref{Example_6.27}). In this example, the entire set consists of the speaker, his wife, and their children, its gloss ___ the included conjunct \textitbf{ana{\Tilde}ana} ‘children’ being subsumed under the inclusory conjunct \textitbf{tong} ‘\textsc{1pl}’.
A: word: deng	 gloss: with
B: word: dengang	 gloss: with
C: word: dang	 gloss: and
D: word: kaka	 gloss: oSb
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 74:

The English translation of this sentence is:‘[but this child] I and (my) husband (emph) love her’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Typically, the inclusory conjunct is encoded by a dual construction formed with a plural \isi{pronoun} and the adnominally used \isi{numeral} \textitbf{dua} ‘two’, such that ``\textsc{pro-pl} \textitbf{dua}''. In (\ref{Example_6.26}), for instance, the speaker talks about herself and her husband. In this example, the entire set consists of the speaker, his wife, and their children, with the included conjunct \textitbf{ana{\Tilde}ana} ‘children’ being subsumed under the inclusory conjunct \textitbf{tong} ‘\textsc{1pl}’.

Question 76:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): malam hari atur ___ deng {\bluebold{ana\Tildeana}} makang
Gloss (with missing item): night day arrange ___ with RDP\Tildechild eat
The English translation of this sentence is:‘in the evening (my wife) arranges (the food), we and the children eat’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Typically, the inclusory conjunct is encoded by a dual construction formed with a plural \isi{pronoun} and the adnominally used \isi{numeral} \textitbf{dua} ‘two’, such that ``\textsc{pro-pl} \textitbf{dua}''. In (\ref{Example_6.26}), for instance, the speaker talks about herself and her husband. That is, the entire set consists of two referents with the inclusory conjunct \textitbf{the morpheme ___ dua} ‘we two’ including the conjunct \textitbf{bapa} ‘father’ in its reference. Only rarely is the inclusory conjunct encoded by a bare plural \isi{pronoun}, as in (\ref{Example_6.27}). In this example, the entire set consists of the speaker, his wife, and their children, with the included conjunct \textitbf{ana{\Tilde}ana} ‘children’ being subsumed under the inclusory conjunct \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘\textsc{1pl}’.
A: word: tong	 gloss: 1PL
B: word: kitong	 gloss: 1PL
C: word: kam	 gloss: 2PL
D: word: pawlus	 gloss: Pawlus
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 77:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option.

In this example, the entire set consists of the speaker, his wife, and their children, its gloss ___ the included conjunct \textitbf{ana{\Tilde}ana} ‘children’ being subsumed under the inclusory conjunct \textitbf{tong} ‘\textsc{1pl}’.

C: word: dang	 gloss: and
D: word: orang	 gloss: person

Question 78:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ... ___ dua deng bapa tu sayang dia
Gloss (with missing item): ... ___ two with father D.DIST love 3SG
The English translation of this sentence is:‘[but this child] I and (my) husband (emph) love her’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: All three plural pronouns can take the inclusory conjunct slot, such as first person plural \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘\textsc{1pl}’ in (\ref{Example_6.26}) and (\ref{Example_6.27}), second plural \textitbf{kam} ‘\textsc{2pl}’ in (\ref{Example_6.28}) and third person plural \textitbf{dong} ‘\textsc{3pl}’ in (\ref{Example_6.29}). Most often the included conjunct is encoded by a \isi{proper noun} as in (\ref{Example_6.28}), or less frequently by a \isi{noun} phrase as in (\ref{Example_6.29}), or also in (\ref{Example_6.26}).
A: word: tong	 gloss: 1PL
B: word: kitong	 gloss: 1PL
C: word: kam	 gloss: 2PL
D: word: sama	 gloss: to
Please only return the letter (A–D).

A: word: dua	 gloss: two

Question 85:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ___ dua deng Isabela pergi cek kapal di plabuang
Gloss (with missing item): ___ two with Isabela go check ship at harbor
The English translation of this sentence is:‘you(SG) and Isabela go check the ship at the harbor’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: All three plural pronouns can take the inclusory conjunct slot, such as first person plural \textitbf{tong} ‘\textsc{1pl}’ in (\ref{Example_6.26}) and (\ref{Example_6.27}), second plural \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘\textsc{2pl}’ in (\ref{Example_6.28}) and third person plural \textitbf{dong} ‘\textsc{3pl}’ in (\ref{Example_6.29}). Most often the included conjunct is encoded by a \isi{proper noun} as in (\ref{Example_6.28}), or less frequently by a \isi{noun} phrase as in (\ref{Example_6.29}), or also in (\ref{Example_6.26}).
A: word: kam	 gloss: 2PL
B: word: kamar	 gloss: room
C: word: tong	 gloss: 1PL
D: word: puti	 gloss: be.white
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 89:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ___ dua dengang Natanael pu maytua langsung pake spit
Gloss (with missing item): ___ two with Natanael POSS wife immediately use speedboat
The English translation of this sentence is:‘he/she and Natanael’s wife immediately took the speedboat’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: All three plural pronouns can take the inclusory conjunct slot, such as first person plural \textitbf{tong} ‘\textsc{1pl}’ in (\ref{Example_6.26}) and (\ref{Example_6.27}), second plural \textitbf{kam} ‘\textsc{2pl}’ in (\ref{Example_6.28}) and third person plural \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘\textsc{3pl}’ in (\ref{Example_6.29}). Most often the included conjunct is encoded by a \isi{proper noun} as in (\ref{Example_6.28}), or less frequently by a \isi{noun} phrase as in (\ref{Example_6.29}), or also in (\ref{Example_6.26}).
A: word: dong	 gloss: 3PL
B: word: dong/dorang	 gloss: 3PL
C: word: kam	 gloss: 2PL
D: word: saya	 gloss: 1SG
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 105:

C: word: kam	 gloss: 2PL
D: word: dia	 gloss: 3SG
Please only return the letter (A–D).

The English translation of this sentence is:‘[but this child] I and (my) husband (emph) love her’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: All three plural pronouns can take the inclusory conjunct slot, such as first person plural \textitbf{tong} ‘\textsc{1pl}’ in (\ref{Example_6.26}) and (\ref{Example_6.27}), second plural \textitbf{kam} ‘\textsc{2pl}’ in (\ref{Example_6.28}) and third person plural \textitbf{dong} ‘\textsc{3pl}’ in (\ref{Example_6.29}). Most often the included conjunct is encoded by a \isi{proper noun} as in (\ref{Example_6.28}), or less frequently by a \isi{noun} phrase as in (\ref{Example_6.29}), or also in (\ref{Example_6.26}).
A: word: bapa	 gloss: father
B: word: bapa-ade	 gloss: uncle
C: word: tete	 gloss: grandfather
D: word: satu	 gloss: one
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 109:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ... tong dua deng bapa ___ sayang dia
Gloss (with missing item): ... 1PL two with father ___ love 3SG
The English translation of this sentence is:‘[but this child] I and (my) husband (emph) love her’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: All three plural pronouns can take the inclusory conjunct slot, such as first person plural \textitbf{tong} ‘\textsc{1pl}’ in (\ref{Example_6.26}) and (\ref{Example_6.27}), second plural \textitbf{kam} ‘\textsc{2pl}’ in (\ref{Example_6.28}) and third person plural \textitbf{dong} ‘\textsc{3pl}’ in (\ref{Example_6.29}). Most often the included conjunct is encoded by a \isi{proper noun} as in (\ref{Example_6.28}), or less frequently by a \isi{noun} phrase as in (\ref{Example_6.29}), or also in (\ref{Example_6.26}).
A: word: tu	 gloss: D.DIST
B: word: satu	 gloss: one
C: word: sana	 gloss: L.DIST
D: word: dorang	 gloss: 3PL
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 110:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ___ kam dua deng Waim ceritrakang dulu
Gloss (with missing item): ___ 2PL two with Waim tell first
The English translation of this sentence is:‘you (sg) Dodo and Waim talk first’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In addition, the corpus contains two inclusory \isi{conjunction} constructions, presented in (\ref{Example_6.30}) and (\ref{Example_6.31}), in which the inclusory conjuncts are used for joining two \isi{noun} phrases. Such inclusory \isi{conjunction} constructions have also been described for other languages, especially in Polynesia, as \citet{Haspelmath.2007c} points out. More specifically, \citet[35]{Haspelmath.2007c} notes that in such a construction the “first conjunct precedes the inclusory \isi{pronoun}, which is then followed by the other included conjunct(s) in the usual way”.
A: word: dodo	 gloss: Dodo
B: word: bodo	 gloss: be.stupid
C: word: mateus	 gloss: Mateus
D: word: anging	 gloss: wind
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 115:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Gloss (with missing item): ___ 3PL two with Martina D.PROX 3PL two run be.continuous 3PL two run reach at river
The English translation of this sentence is:‘Tinus and Martina here, the two of them drove continuously, the two of them drove all the way to the river’

Such inclusory \isi{conjunction} constructions have also been described for other languages, especially in Polynesia, as \citet{Haspelmath.2007c} points out. More specifically, \citet[35]{Haspelmath.2007c} notes that in such a construction the “first conjunct precedes the inclusory \isi{pronoun}, which is then followed by the other included conjunct(s) in the usual way”.

C: word: kaleng	 gloss: tin.can
D: word: dodo	 gloss: Dodo
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Such inclusory \isi{conjunction} constructions have also been described for other languages, especially in Polynesia, as \citet{Haspelmath.2007c} points out. Question 121:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ... ___ dua deng bapa tu sayang dia
Gloss (with missing item): ... ___ two with father D.DIST love 3SG
The English translation of this sentence is:‘[but this child] I and (my) husband (emph) love her’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The inclusory \isi{conjunction} constructions presented in (\ref{Example_6.26}) to (\ref{Example_6.29}) contrast with what \citet[33]{Haspelmath.2007c} calls “\isi{comitative} \isi{conjunction} constructions”, which denote additive relations. In Papuan Malay, such \isi{comitative} constructions are formed with \isi{comitative} \textitbf{dengang} ‘with’. The inclusory \isi{conjunction} constructions in (\ref{Example_6.26}) to (\ref{Example_6.29}) also contrast with ``\textsc{n} \textsc{pro-pl}'' \isi{noun} phrases with an \isi{associative} inclusory reading. Both contrasts are illustrated with the examples in (\ref{Example_6.32}) and (\ref{Example_6.33}).
A: word: tong	 gloss: 1PL
B: word: kitong	 gloss: 1PL
C: word: kam	 gloss: 2PL
D: word: pace	 gloss: man
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 127:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): {dong} ___ dengang Natanael pu maytua langsung pake spit
Gloss (with missing item): 3PL ___ with Natanael POSS wife immediately use speedboat
The English translation of this sentence is:‘he/she and Natanael’s wife immediately took the speedboat’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The inclusory \isi{conjunction} constructions presented in (\ref{Example_6.26}) to (\ref{Example_6.29}) contrast with what \citet[33]{Haspelmath.2007c} calls “\isi{comitative} \isi{conjunction} constructions”, which denote additive relations. In Papuan Malay, such \isi{comitative} constructions are formed with \isi{comitative} \textitbf{dengang} ‘with’. The inclusory \isi{conjunction} constructions in (\ref{Example_6.26}) to (\ref{Example_6.29}) also contrast with ``\textsc{n} \textsc{pro-pl}'' \isi{noun} phrases with an \isi{associative} inclusory reading. Both contrasts are illustrated with the examples in (\ref{Example_6.32}) and (\ref{Example_6.33}).
A: word: dua	 gloss: two
B: word: siduasi	 gloss: Siduas
C: word: kedua	 gloss: second
D: word: kam	 gloss: 2PL
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 128:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. In Papuan Malay, such \isi{comitative} constructions are formed its gloss ___ \isi{comitative} \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’. D: word: puti	 gloss: be.white
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 132:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ... ___ dua deng bapa tu sayang dia
Gloss (with missing item): ... ___ two with father D.DIST love 3SG
The English translation of this sentence is:‘[but this child] I and (my) husband (emph) love her’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The inclusory \isi{conjunction} constructions presented in (\ref{Example_6.26}) to (\ref{Example_6.29}) contrast with what \citet[33]{Haspelmath.2007c} calls “\isi{comitative} \isi{conjunction} constructions”, which denote additive relations. Both contrasts are illustrated with the examples in (\ref{Example_6.32}) and (\ref{Example_6.33}).
A: word: tong	 gloss: 1PL
B: word: kitong	 gloss: 1PL
C: word: kam	 gloss: 2PL
D: word: markus	 gloss: Markus
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 143:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Question 145:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): {baru} siapa Sarles dengang ___ dua turung bli ni
Gloss (with missing item): and.then who Sarles with ___ two descend buy D.PROX
The English translation of this sentence is:‘and then, who-is-it, Sarles and the two of them came down and bought this’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The inclusory \isi{conjunction} constructions presented in (\ref{Example_6.26}) to (\ref{Example_6.29}) contrast with what \citet[33]{Haspelmath.2007c} calls “\isi{comitative} \isi{conjunction} constructions”, which denote additive relations. In Papuan Malay, such \isi{comitative} constructions are formed with \isi{comitative} \textitbf{dengang} ‘with’. The inclusory \isi{conjunction} constructions in (\ref{Example_6.26}) to (\ref{Example_6.29}) also contrast with ``\textsc{n} \textsc{pro-pl}'' \isi{noun} phrases with an \isi{associative} inclusory reading. Both contrasts are illustrated with the examples in (\ref{Example_6.32}) and (\ref{Example_6.33}).
A: word: dong	 gloss: 3PL
B: word: dong/dorang	 gloss: 3PL
C: word: kam	 gloss: 2PL
D: word: mama-tua	 gloss: aunt
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 146:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): {baru} siapa Sarles dengang dong ___ turung bli ni
Gloss (with missing item): and.then who Sarles with 3PL ___ descend buy D.PROX
The English translation of this sentence is:‘and then, who-is-it, Sarles and the two of them came down and bought this’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The inclusory \isi{conjunction} constructions presented in (\ref{Example_6.26}) to (\ref{Example_6.29}) contrast with what \citet[33]{Haspelmath.2007c} calls “\isi{comitative} \isi{conjunction} constructions”, which denote additive relations. In Papuan Malay, such \isi{comitative} constructions are formed with \isi{comitative} \textitbf{dengang} ‘with’. The inclusory \isi{conjunction} constructions in (\ref{Example_6.26}) to (\ref{Example_6.29}) also contrast with ``\textsc{n} \textsc{pro-pl}'' \isi{noun} phrases with an \isi{associative} inclusory reading. Both contrasts are illustrated with the examples in (\ref{Example_6.32}) and (\ref{Example_6.33}).
A: word: dua	 gloss: two
B: word: siduasi	 gloss: Siduas
C: word: kedua	 gloss: second
D: word: banyak	 gloss: many
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 147:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ___ dorang dua pulang hari minggu cepat
Gloss (with missing item): ___ 3PL two go.home day Sunday be.fast
The English translation of this sentence is:‘father and he returned home quickly on Sunday’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The inclusory \isi{conjunction} constructions presented in (\ref{Example_6.26}) to (\ref{Example_6.29}) contrast with what \citet[33]{Haspelmath.2007c} calls “\isi{comitative} \isi{conjunction} constructions”, which denote additive relations. In Papuan Malay, such \isi{comitative} constructions are formed with \isi{comitative} \textitbf{dengang} ‘with’. The inclusory \isi{conjunction} constructions in (\ref{Example_6.26}) to (\ref{Example_6.29}) also contrast with ``\textsc{n} \textsc{pro-pl}'' \isi{noun} phrases with an \isi{associative} inclusory reading. Both contrasts are illustrated with the examples in (\ref{Example_6.32}) and (\ref{Example_6.33}).
A: word: bapa	 gloss: father
B: word: bapa-ade	 gloss: uncle
C: word: tete	 gloss: grandfather
D: word: dari	 gloss: from
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The inclusory \isi{conjunction} constructions presented in (\ref{Example_6.26}) to (\ref{Example_6.29}) contrast with what \citet[33]{Haspelmath.2007c} calls “\isi{comitative} \isi{conjunction} constructions”, which denote additive relations.
