Question 149:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): bapa dorang ___ pulang hari minggu cepat
Gloss (with missing item): father 3PL ___ go.home day Sunday be.fast
The English translation of this sentence is:‘father and he returned home quickly on Sunday’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The inclusory \isi{conjunction} constructions presented in (\ref{Example_6.26}) to (\ref{Example_6.29}) contrast with what \citet[33]{Haspelmath.2007c} calls “\isi{comitative} \isi{conjunction} constructions”, which denote additive relations. In Papuan Malay, such \isi{comitative} constructions are formed with \isi{comitative} \textitbf{dengang} ‘with’. The inclusory \isi{conjunction} constructions in (\ref{Example_6.26}) to (\ref{Example_6.29}) also contrast with ``\textsc{n} \textsc{pro-pl}'' \isi{noun} phrases with an \isi{associative} inclusory reading. Both contrasts are illustrated with the examples in (\ref{Example_6.32}) and (\ref{Example_6.33}).
A: word: dua	 gloss: two
B: word: siduasi	 gloss: Siduas

Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 150:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ... ___ dua deng bapa tu sayang dia
Gloss (with missing item): ... ___ two with father D.DIST love 3SG
The English translation of this sentence is:‘[but this child] I and (my) husband (emph) love her’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: As for the distinction of \isi{comitative} and inclusory \isi{conjunction} constructions, \citet[33]{Haspelmath.2007c} makes the following cross-linguistic observations. In a \isi{comitative} \isi{conjunction} construction, the \isi{conjunction} of “two set-denoting \textsc{np}s [{\ldots}] ‘\{A, B\} and \{C, D\}’ yields the set \{A, B, C, D\}” (\citeyear*[33]{Haspelmath.2007c}). In inclusory \isi{conjunction} constructions, by contrast, “some members of the second conjunct set are already included in the first conjunct set”; hence the result of the coordination is not the “union, but the \textitbf{unification} of the sets [such that] ‘\{A, B, C\} and \{B\}’ yields the set \{A, B, C\}” (\citeyear*[33]{Haspelmath.2007c}). This distinction also applies to Papuan Malay. While the constructions in (\ref{Example_6.26}) to (\ref{Example_6.29}) receive an inclusory reading, the \isi{comitative} ‘N1 \textitbf{dengang} ‘with’ \textsc{N2}’ \isi{conjunction} construction in (\ref{Example_6.32}) receives an additive reading. (Comitative \isi{conjunction} constructions with \textitbf{dengang} ‘with’ are discussed in see §\ref{Para_14.2.1.1}.)
A: word: tong	 gloss: 1PL
B: word: kitong	 gloss: 1PL
C: word: kam	 gloss: 2PL
D: word: cantik	 gloss: be.beautiful
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 151:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ... tong ___ deng bapa tu sayang dia
Gloss (with missing item): ... 1PL ___ with father D.DIST love 3SG
The English translation of this sentence is:‘[but this child] I and (my) husband (emph) love her’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: As for the distinction of \isi{comitative} and inclusory \isi{conjunction} constructions, \citet[33]{Haspelmath.2007c} makes the following cross-linguistic observations. In a \isi{comitative} \isi{conjunction} construction, the \isi{conjunction} of “its gloss ___ set-denoting \textsc{np}s [{\ldots}] ‘\{A, B\} and \{C, D\}’ yields the set \{A, B, C, D\}” (\citeyear*[33]{Haspelmath.2007c}). In inclusory \isi{conjunction} constructions, by contrast, “some members of the second conjunct set are already included in the first conjunct set”; hence the result of the coordination is not the “union, but the \textitbf{unification} of the sets [such that] ‘\{A, B, C\} and \{B\}’ yields the set \{A, B, C\}” (\citeyear*[33]{Haspelmath.2007c}). This distinction also applies to Papuan Malay. (Comitative \isi{conjunction} constructions with \textitbf{dengang} ‘with’ are discussed in see §\ref{Para_14.2.1.1}.)
A: word: dua	 gloss: two
B: word: siduasi	 gloss: Siduas
C: word: kedua	 gloss: second
D: word: yang	 gloss: REL
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 152:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ... tong dua ___ bapa tu sayang dia
Gloss (with missing item): ... 1PL two ___ father D.DIST love 3SG
The English translation of this sentence is:‘[but this child] I and (my) husband (emph) love her’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: As for the distinction of \isi{comitative} and inclusory \isi{conjunction} constructions, \citet[33]{Haspelmath.2007c} makes the following cross-linguistic observations. In a \isi{comitative} \isi{conjunction} construction, the \isi{conjunction} of “two set-denoting \textsc{np}s [{\ldots}] ‘\{A, B\} and \{C, D\}’ yields the set \{A, B, C, D\}” (\citeyear*[33]{Haspelmath.2007c}). In inclusory \isi{conjunction} constructions, by contrast, “some members of the second conjunct set are already included in the first conjunct set”; hence the result of the coordination is not the “union, but the \textitbf{unification} of the sets [such that] ‘\{A, B, C\} and \{B\}’ yields the set \{A, B, C\}” (\citeyear*[33]{Haspelmath.2007c}). This distinction also applies to Papuan Malay. While the constructions in (\ref{Example_6.26}) to (\ref{Example_6.29}) receive an inclusory reading, the \isi{comitative} ‘N1 \textitbf{the morpheme ___ang} ‘its gloss ___’ \textsc{N2}’ \isi{conjunction} construction in (\ref{Example_6.32}) receives an additive reading. (Comitative \isi{conjunction} constructions its gloss ___ \textitbf{the morpheme ___ang} ‘its gloss ___’ are discussed in see §\ref{Para_14.2.1.1}.)
A: word: deng	 gloss: with
B: word: dengang	 gloss: with
C: word: dang	 gloss: and
D: word: mama-ade	 gloss: aunt
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 155:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ___ dua dengang Natanael pu maytua langsung pake spit
Gloss (with missing item): ___ two with Natanael POSS wife immediately use speedboat
The English translation of this sentence is:‘he/she and Natanael’s wife immediately took the speedboat’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: As for the distinction of \isi{comitative} and inclusory \isi{conjunction} constructions, \citet[33]{Haspelmath.2007c} makes the following cross-linguistic observations. This distinction also applies to Papuan Malay. B: word: dong/dorang	 gloss: 3PL
C: word: kam	 gloss: 2PL
D: word: anging	 gloss: wind
Please only return the letter (A–D).

In inclusory \isi{conjunction} constructions, by contrast, “some members of the second conjunct set are already included in the first conjunct set”; hence the result of the coordination is not the “union, but the \textitbf{unification} of the sets [such that] ‘\{A, B, C\} and \{B\}’ yields the set \{A, B, C\}” (\citeyear*[33]{Haspelmath.2007c}). Question 158:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Question 159:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): {dong} dua dengang Natanael ___ maytua langsung pake spit
Gloss (with missing item): 3PL two with Natanael ___ wife immediately use speedboat
The English translation of this sentence is:‘he/she and Natanael’s wife immediately took the speedboat’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: As for the distinction of \isi{comitative} and inclusory \isi{conjunction} constructions, \citet[33]{Haspelmath.2007c} makes the following cross-linguistic observations. In a \isi{comitative} \isi{conjunction} construction, the \isi{conjunction} of “two set-denoting \textsc{np}s [{\ldots}] ‘\{A, B\} and \{C, D\}’ yields the set \{A, B, C, D\}” (\citeyear*[33]{Haspelmath.2007c}). In inclusory \isi{conjunction} constructions, by contrast, “some members of the second conjunct set are already included in the first conjunct set”; hence the result of the coordination is not the “union, but the \textitbf{unification} of the sets [such that] ‘\{A, B, C\} and \{B\}’ yields the set \{A, B, C\}” (\citeyear*[33]{Haspelmath.2007c}). This distinction also applies to Pathe morpheme ___an Malay. While the constructions in (\ref{Example_6.26}) to (\ref{Example_6.29}) receive an inclusory reading, the \isi{comitative} ‘N1 \textitbf{dengang} ‘with’ \textsc{N2}’ \isi{conjunction} construction in (\ref{Example_6.32}) receives an additive reading. (Comitative \isi{conjunction} constructions with \textitbf{dengang} ‘with’ are discussed in see §\ref{Para_14.2.1.1}.)
A: word: pu	 gloss: POSS
B: word: pukul	 gloss: hit
C: word: hendro	 gloss: POSSR
D: word: ana	 gloss: child
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 160:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): {dong} dua dengang Natanael pu ___ langsung pake spit
Gloss (with missing item): 3PL two with Natanael POSS ___ immediately use speedboat
The English translation of this sentence is:‘he/she and Natanael’s wife immediately took the speedboat’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: As for the distinction of \isi{comitative} and inclusory \isi{conjunction} constructions, \citet[33]{Haspelmath.2007c} makes the following cross-linguistic observations. In a \isi{comitative} \isi{conjunction} construction, the \isi{conjunction} of “two set-denoting \textsc{np}s [{\ldots}] ‘\{A, B\} and \{C, D\}’ yields the set \{A, B, C, D\}” (\citeyear*[33]{Haspelmath.2007c}). In inclusory \isi{conjunction} constructions, by contrast, “some members of the second conjunct set are already included in the first conjunct set”; hence the result of the coordination is not the “union, but the \textitbf{unification} of the sets [such that] ‘\{A, B, C\} and \{B\}’ yields the set \{A, B, C\}” (\citeyear*[33]{Haspelmath.2007c}). This distinction also applies to Papuan Malay. While the constructions in (\ref{Example_6.26}) to (\ref{Example_6.29}) receive an inclusory reading, the \isi{comitative} ‘N1 \textitbf{dengang} ‘with’ \textsc{N2}’ \isi{conjunction} construction in (\ref{Example_6.32}) receives an additive reading. (Comitative \isi{conjunction} constructions with \textitbf{dengang} ‘with’ are discussed in see §\ref{Para_14.2.1.1}.)
A: word: maytua	 gloss: wife
B: word: paytua	 gloss: husband
C: word: janda	 gloss: widow
D: word: tong	 gloss: 1PL
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 161:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: As for the distinction of \isi{comitative} and inclusory \isi{conjunction} constructions, \citet[33]{Haspelmath.2007c} makes the following cross-linguistic observations. Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: As for the distinction of \isi{comitative} and inclusory \isi{conjunction} constructions, \citet[33]{Haspelmath.2007c} makes the following cross-linguistic observations. In a \isi{comitative} \isi{conjunction} construction, the \isi{conjunction} of “two set-denoting \textsc{np}s [{\ldots}] ‘\{A, B\} and \{C, D\}’ yields the set \{A, B, C, D\}” (\citeyear*[33]{Haspelmath.2007c}). Question 164:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): {baru} siapa Sarles dengang dong ___ turung bli ni
Gloss (with missing item): and.then who Sarles with 3PL ___ descend buy D.PROX
The English translation of this sentence is:‘and then, who-is-it, Sarles and the two of them came down and bought this’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: As for the distinction of \isi{comitative} and inclusory \isi{conjunction} constructions, \citet[33]{Haspelmath.2007c} makes the following cross-linguistic observations. In a \isi{comitative} \isi{conjunction} construction, the \isi{conjunction} of “its gloss ___ set-denoting \textsc{np}s [{\ldots}] ‘\{A, B\} and \{C, D\}’ yields the set \{A, B, C, D\}” (\citeyear*[33]{Haspelmath.2007c}). In inclusory \isi{conjunction} constructions, by contrast, “some members of the second conjunct set are already included in the first conjunct set”; hence the result of the coordination is not the “union, but the \textitbf{unification} of the sets [such that] ‘\{A, B, C\} and \{B\}’ yields the set \{A, B, C\}” (\citeyear*[33]{Haspelmath.2007c}). This distinction also applies to Papuan Malay. While the constructions in (\ref{Example_6.26}) to (\ref{Example_6.29}) receive an inclusory reading, the \isi{comitative} ‘N1 \textitbf{dengang} ‘with’ \textsc{N2}’ \isi{conjunction} construction in (\ref{Example_6.32}) receives an additive reading. (Comitative \isi{conjunction} constructions with \textitbf{dengang} ‘with’ are discussed in see §\ref{Para_14.2.1.1}.)
A: word: dua	 gloss: two
B: word: siduasi	 gloss: Siduas
C: word: kedua	 gloss: second
D: word: tiga	 gloss: one
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 165:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ... ___ dua deng bapa tu sayang dia
Gloss (with missing item): ... ___ two with father D.DIST love 3SG
The English translation of this sentence is:‘[but this child] I and (my) husband (emph) love her’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Papuan Malay inclusory \isi{conjunction} constructions, that is, ``\textsc{pro-pl} \textitbf{(dua) dengang} \textsc{np}’ constructions, are also distinct from ``\textsc{n} \textsc{pro-pl}'' \isi{noun} phrases with an \isi{associative} inclusory plural reading. The pragmatic differences between the constituent order found in (\ref{Example_6.26}) to (\ref{Example_6.29}) as compared to that found in (\ref{Example_6.33}) are similar to the differences found in \ili{Toqabaqit}, another \ili{Austronesian} language, as observed by \citet[27]{Lichtenberk.2000}: the contrast concerns “the relative degrees of discourse salience of the two sets of participants, the overtly and the covertly encoded ones”. This contrast also applies to Papuan Malay. In (\ref{Example_6.28}) to (\ref{Example_6.29}), the covertly encoded participants subsumed under the adnominal dual constructions are more salient and therefore mentioned first. The overtly encoded participants, by contrast, are less salient and therefore mentioned second. In the \textsc{n} \textsc{pro-pl} \isi{noun} phrase in (\ref{Example_6.33}), by contrast, the overtly encoded participant \textitbf{bapa} ‘father’ is more salient and therefore mentioned first. The covertly encoded participants subsumed under the adnominal dual construction \textitbf{dorang dua} ‘they two’ are less salient and of subordinate status. (For details on \textsc{n} \textsc{pro-pl} \isi{noun} phrases with an \isi{associative} inclusory plural reading, see §\ref{Para_6.2.2.2}.)
A: word: tong	 gloss: 1PL
B: word: kitong	 gloss: 1PL
C: word: kam	 gloss: 2PL
D: word: hurki	 gloss: Hurki
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 166:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ... tong ___ deng bapa tu sayang dia
Gloss (with missing item): ... 1PL ___ with father D.DIST love 3SG
The English translation of this sentence is:‘[but this child] I and (my) husband (emph) love her’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Papuan Malay inclusory \isi{conjunction} constructions, that is, ``\textsc{pro-pl} \textitbf{(the morpheme ___) dengang} \textsc{np}’ constructions, are also distinct from ``\textsc{n} \textsc{pro-pl}'' \isi{noun} phrases with an \isi{associative} inclusory plural reading. The pragmatic differences between the constituent order found in (\ref{Example_6.26}) to (\ref{Example_6.29}) as compared to that found in (\ref{Example_6.33}) are similar to the differences found in \ili{Toqabaqit}, another \ili{Austronesian} language, as observed by \citet[27]{Lichtenberk.2000}: the contrast concerns “the relative degrees of discourse salience of the its gloss ___ sets of participants, the overtly and the covertly encoded ones”. This contrast also applies to Papuan Malay. In (\ref{Example_6.28}) to (\ref{Example_6.29}), the covertly encoded participants subsumed under the adnominal the morpheme ___l constructions are more salient and therefore mentioned first. The overtly encoded participants, by contrast, are less salient and therefore mentioned second. In the \textsc{n} \textsc{pro-pl} \isi{noun} phrase in (\ref{Example_6.33}), by contrast, the overtly encoded participant \textitbf{bapa} ‘father’ is more salient and therefore mentioned first. The covertly encoded participants subsumed under the adnominal the morpheme ___l construction \textitbf{dorang the morpheme ___} ‘they its gloss ___’ are less salient and of subordinate status. (For details on \textsc{n} \textsc{pro-pl} \isi{noun} phrases with an \isi{associative} inclusory plural reading, see §\ref{Para_6.2.2.2}.)
A: word: dua	 gloss: two
B: word: siduasi	 gloss: Siduas
C: word: kedua	 gloss: second

Question 171:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Sentence (with missing item): {dong} ___ dengang Natanael pu maytua langsung pake spit
Gloss (with missing item): 3PL ___ with Natanael POSS wife immediately use speedboat

Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Papuan Malay inclusory \isi{conjunction} constructions, that is, ``\textsc{pro-pl} \textitbf{(the morpheme ___) dengang} \textsc{np}’ constructions, are also distinct from ``\textsc{n} \textsc{pro-pl}'' \isi{noun} phrases with an \isi{associative} inclusory plural reading. The pragmatic differences between the constituent order found in (\ref{Example_6.26}) to (\ref{Example_6.29}) as compared to that found in (\ref{Example_6.33}) are similar to the differences found in \ili{Toqabaqit}, another \ili{Austronesian} language, as observed by \citet[27]{Lichtenberk.2000}: the contrast concerns “the relative degrees of discourse salience of the its gloss ___ sets of participants, the overtly and the covertly encoded ones”. This contrast also applies to Papuan Malay. In (\ref{Example_6.28}) to (\ref{Example_6.29}), the covertly encoded participants subsumed under the adnominal the morpheme ___l constructions are more salient and therefore mentioned first. The overtly encoded participants, by contrast, are less salient and therefore mentioned second. In the \textsc{n} \textsc{pro-pl} \isi{noun} phrase in (\ref{Example_6.33}), by contrast, the overtly encoded participant \textitbf{bapa} ‘father’ is more salient and therefore mentioned first. The covertly encoded participants subsumed under the adnominal the morpheme ___l construction \textitbf{dorang the morpheme ___} ‘they its gloss ___’ are less salient and of subordinate status. (For details on \textsc{n} \textsc{pro-pl} \isi{noun} phrases with an \isi{associative} inclusory plural reading, see §\ref{Para_6.2.2.2}.)
A: word: dua	 gloss: two
B: word: siduasi	 gloss: Siduas
C: word: kedua	 gloss: second
D: word: ise	 gloss: Ise
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 172:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): {dong} dua ___ Natanael pu maytua langsung pake spit
Gloss (with missing item): 3PL two ___ Natanael POSS wife immediately use speedboat
The English translation of this sentence is:‘he/she and Natanael’s wife immediately took the speedboat’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Papuan Malay inclusory \isi{conjunction} constructions, that is, ``\textsc{pro-pl} \textitbf{(dua) the morpheme ___} \textsc{np}’ constructions, are also distinct from ``\textsc{n} \textsc{pro-pl}'' \isi{noun} phrases its gloss ___ an \isi{associative} inclusory plural reading. The pragmatic differences between the constituent order found in (\ref{Example_6.26}) to (\ref{Example_6.29}) as compared to that found in (\ref{Example_6.33}) are similar to the differences found in \ili{Toqabaqit}, another \ili{Austronesian} language, as observed by \citet[27]{Lichtenberk.2000}: the contrast concerns “the relative degrees of discourse salience of the two sets of participants, the overtly and the covertly encoded ones”. This contrast also applies to Papuan Malay. In (\ref{Example_6.28}) to (\ref{Example_6.29}), the covertly encoded participants subsumed under the adnominal dual constructions are more salient and therefore mentioned first. The overtly encoded participants, by contrast, are less salient and therefore mentioned second. In the \textsc{n} \textsc{pro-pl} \isi{noun} phrase in (\ref{Example_6.33}), by contrast, the overtly encoded participant \textitbf{bapa} ‘father’ is more salient and therefore mentioned first. The covertly encoded participants subsumed under the adnominal dual construction \textitbf{dorang dua} ‘they two’ are less salient and of subordinate status. (For details on \textsc{n} \textsc{pro-pl} \isi{noun} phrases its gloss ___ an \isi{associative} inclusory plural reading, see §\ref{Para_6.2.2.2}.)
A: word: dengang	 gloss: with
B: word: jangang	 gloss: NEG.IMP
C: word: dang	 gloss: and
D: word: smua	 gloss: all
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 176:

D: word: prempuang	 gloss: 10pt
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 184:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): {dong} ___ dengang Natanael pu maytua langsung pake spit
Gloss (with missing item): 3PL ___ with Natanael POSS wife immediately use speedboat
The English translation of this sentence is:‘he/she and Natanael’s wife immediately took the speedboat’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Papuan Malay inclusory \isi{conjunction} constructions, that is, ``\textsc{pro-pl} \textitbf{(the morpheme ___) dengang} \textsc{np}’ constructions, are also distinct from ``\textsc{n} \textsc{pro-pl}'' \isi{noun} phrases with an \isi{associative} inclusory plural reading. The pragmatic differences between the constituent order found in (\ref{Example_6.26}) to (\ref{Example_6.29}) as compared to that found in (\ref{Example_6.33}) are similar to the differences found in \ili{Toqabaqit}, another \ili{Austronesian} language, as observed by \citet[27]{Lichtenberk.2000}: the contrast concerns “the relative degrees of discourse salience of the its gloss ___ sets of participants, the overtly and the covertly encoded ones”. This contrast also applies to Papuan Malay. In (\ref{Example_6.28}) to (\ref{Example_6.29}), the covertly encoded participants subsumed under the adnominal the morpheme ___l constructions are more salient and therefore mentioned first. The overtly encoded participants, by contrast, are less salient and therefore mentioned second. In the \textsc{n} \textsc{pro-pl} \isi{noun} phrase in (\ref{Example_6.33}), by contrast, the overtly encoded participant \textitbf{bapa} ‘father’ is more salient and therefore mentioned first. The covertly encoded participants subsumed under the adnominal the morpheme ___l construction \textitbf{dorang the morpheme ___} ‘they its gloss ___’ are less salient and of subordinate status. (For details on \textsc{n} \textsc{pro-pl} \isi{noun} phrases with an \isi{associative} inclusory plural reading, see §\ref{Para_6.2.2.2}.)
A: word: dua	 gloss: two
B: word: siduasi	 gloss: Siduas
C: word: kedua	 gloss: second
D: word: dia	 gloss: 3SG
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 185:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): {dong} dua ___ Natanael pu maytua langsung pake spit
Gloss (with missing item): 3PL two ___ Natanael POSS wife immediately use speedboat
The English translation of this sentence is:‘he/she and Natanael’s wife immediately took the speedboat’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Papuan Malay inclusory \isi{conjunction} constructions, that is, ``\textsc{pro-pl} \textitbf{(dua) the morpheme ___} \textsc{np}’ constructions, are also distinct from ``\textsc{n} \textsc{pro-pl}'' \isi{noun} phrases its gloss ___ an \isi{associative} inclusory plural reading. The pragmatic differences between the constituent order found in (\ref{Example_6.26}) to (\ref{Example_6.29}) as compared to that found in (\ref{Example_6.33}) are similar to the differences found in \ili{Toqabaqit}, another \ili{Austronesian} language, as observed by \citet[27]{Lichtenberk.2000}: the contrast concerns “the relative degrees of discourse salience of the two sets of participants, the overtly and the covertly encoded ones”. This contrast also applies to Papuan Malay. In (\ref{Example_6.28}) to (\ref{Example_6.29}), the covertly encoded participants subsumed under the adnominal dual constructions are more salient and therefore mentioned first. The overtly encoded participants, by contrast, are less salient and therefore mentioned second. In the \textsc{n} \textsc{pro-pl} \isi{noun} phrase in (\ref{Example_6.33}), by contrast, the overtly encoded participant \textitbf{bapa} ‘father’ is more salient and therefore mentioned first. The covertly encoded participants subsumed under the adnominal dual construction \textitbf{dorang dua} ‘they two’ are less salient and of subordinate status. (For details on \textsc{n} \textsc{pro-pl} \isi{noun} phrases its gloss ___ an \isi{associative} inclusory plural reading, see §\ref{Para_6.2.2.2}.)
A: word: dengang	 gloss: with
B: word: jangang	 gloss: NEG.IMP
C: word: dang	 gloss: and
D: word: mambramo	 gloss: Mambramo
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 189:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ___ dorang dua pulang hari minggu cepat
Gloss (with missing item): ___ 3PL two go.home day Sunday be.fast
The English translation of this sentence is:‘father and he returned home quickly on Sunday’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Papuan Malay inclusory \isi{conjunction} constructions, that is, ``\textsc{pro-pl} \textitbf{(dua) dengang} \textsc{np}’ constructions, are also distinct from ``\textsc{n} \textsc{pro-pl}'' \isi{noun} phrases with an \isi{associative} inclusory plural reading. In (\ref{Example_6.28}) to (\ref{Example_6.29}), the covertly encoded participants subsumed under the adnominal dual constructions are more salient and therefore mentioned first. The overtly encoded participants, by contrast, are less salient and therefore mentioned second. In the \textsc{n} \textsc{pro-pl} \isi{noun} phrase in (\ref{Example_6.33}), by contrast, the overtly encoded participant \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ is more salient and therefore mentioned first. The covertly encoded participants subsumed under the adnominal dual construction \textitbf{dorang dua} ‘they two’ are less salient and of subordinate status. (For details on \textsc{n} \textsc{pro-pl} \isi{noun} phrases with an \isi{associative} inclusory plural reading, see §\ref{Para_6.2.2.2}.)

Question 192:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ___ bapa tong mo sembayang
Gloss (with missing item): ___ father 1PL want worship
The English translation of this sentence is:‘we mother and father want to worship’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In Papuan Malay, by contrast, the final constituent that sums up the set of conjuncts is a plural \isi{pronoun}. This is illustrated in the examples in (\ref{Example_6.34}) to (\ref{Example_6.36}). The set can consist of just two conjuncts as in (\ref{Example_6.34}), or of three or more as in (\ref{Example_6.35}). Typically the conjuncts are conjoined without an overt coordinator, as in (\ref{Example_6.34}) and (\ref{Example_6.35}). When the set of conjuncts is limited to two, as in (\ref{Example_6.36}), the conjuncts may also be linked with an overt coordinator, usually \isi{comitative} \textitbf{dengang} ‘with’. (For details on the combining of \isi{noun} phrases, see §\ref{Para_14.2}.)
A: word: mama	 gloss: mother
B: word: mama-ade	 gloss: aunt
C: word: orang-tua	 gloss: parent
D: word: cantik	 gloss: be.beautiful
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 198:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): mama deng bapa ___ su meninggal
Gloss (with missing item): mother with father ___ already die
The English translation of this sentence is:‘they mother and father have already died’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In Papuan Malay, by contrast, the final constituent that sums up the set of conjuncts is a plural \isi{pronoun}. This is illustrated in the examples in (\ref{Example_6.34}) to (\ref{Example_6.36}). The set can consist of just two conjuncts as in (\ref{Example_6.34}), or of three or more as in (\ref{Example_6.35}). Typically the conjuncts are conjoined without an overt coordinator, as in (\ref{Example_6.34}) and (\ref{Example_6.35}). When the set of conjuncts is limited to two, as in (\ref{Example_6.36}), the conjuncts may also be linked with an overt coordinator, usually \isi{comitative} \textitbf{dengang} ‘with’. (For details on the combining of \isi{noun} phrases, see §\ref{Para_14.2}.)
A: word: dong	 gloss: 3PL
B: word: dong/dorang	 gloss: 3PL
C: word: kam	 gloss: 2PL
D: word: maytua	 gloss: wife
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 199:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ___ bapa tong mo sembayang
Gloss (with missing item): ___ father 1PL want worship
The English translation of this sentence is:‘we mother and father want to worship’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In Papuan Malay, by contrast, the final constituent that sums up the set of conjuncts is a plural \isi{pronoun}. This is illustrated in the examples in (\ref{Example_6.34}) to (\ref{Example_6.36}). The set can consist of just two conjuncts as in (\ref{Example_6.34}), or of three or more as in (\ref{Example_6.35}). Typically the conjuncts are conjoined without an overt coordinator, as in (\ref{Example_6.34}) and (\ref{Example_6.35}). When the set of conjuncts is limited to two, as in (\ref{Example_6.36}), the conjuncts may also be linked with an overt coordinator, usually \isi{comitative} \textitbf{dengang} ‘with’. (For details on the combining of \isi{noun} phrases, see §\ref{Para_14.2}.)
A: word: mama	 gloss: mother
B: word: mama-ade	 gloss: aunt
C: word: orang-tua	 gloss: parent
D: word: anging	 gloss: wind
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 200:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): mama ___ tong mo sembayang
Gloss (with missing item): mother ___ 1PL want worship
The English translation of this sentence is:‘we mother and father want to worship’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In Papuan Malay, by contrast, the final constituent that sums up the set of conjuncts is a plural \isi{pronoun}. This is illustrated in the examples in (\ref{Example_6.34}) to (\ref{Example_6.36}). The set can consist of just two conjuncts as in (\ref{Example_6.34}), or of three or more as in (\ref{Example_6.35}). Typically the conjuncts are conjoined without an overt coordinator, as in (\ref{Example_6.34}) and (\ref{Example_6.35}). When the set of conjuncts is limited to two, as in (\ref{Example_6.36}), the conjuncts may also be linked with an overt coordinator, usually \isi{comitative} \textitbf{dengang} ‘with’. A: word: bapa	 gloss: father
B: word: bapa-ade	 gloss: uncle
C: word: tete	 gloss: grandfather
D: word: agus	 gloss: Agus
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 201:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In Papuan Malay, by contrast, the final constituent that sums up the set of conjuncts is a plural \isi{pronoun}. This is illustrated in the examples in (\ref{Example_6.34}) to (\ref{Example_6.36}). The set can consist of just two conjuncts as in (\ref{Example_6.34}), or of three or more as in (\ref{Example_6.35}). Typically the conjuncts are conjoined without an overt coordinator, as in (\ref{Example_6.34}) and (\ref{Example_6.35}). When the set of conjuncts is limited to two, as in (\ref{Example_6.36}), the conjuncts may also be linked with an overt coordinator, usually \isi{comitative} \textitbf{dengang} ‘with’. C: word: kam	 gloss: 2PL
D: word: hurki	 gloss: Hurki
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 202:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ... ___ e Herman Nusa, em, Oktofina kamu duduk situ
Gloss (with missing item): ... ___ uh Herman Nusa uh Oktofina 2PL sit L.MED
The English translation of this sentence is:‘[in the evening (I said),] ``you (pl) Hurki, uh Herman, Nusa, uh Oktofina sit there'''
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In Papuan Malay, by contrast, the final constituent that sums up the set of conjuncts is a plural \isi{pronoun}. This is illustrated in the examples in (\ref{Example_6.34}) to (\ref{Example_6.36}). The set can consist of just two conjuncts as in (\ref{Example_6.34}), or of three or more as in (\ref{Example_6.35}). Typically the conjuncts are conjoined without an overt coordinator, as in (\ref{Example_6.34}) and (\ref{Example_6.35}). When the set of conjuncts is limited to two, as in (\ref{Example_6.36}), the conjuncts may also be linked with an overt coordinator, usually \isi{comitative} \textitbf{dengang} ‘with’. (For details on the combining of \isi{noun} phrases, see §\ref{Para_14.2}.)
A: word: hurki	 gloss: Hurki
B: word: hancurkang	 gloss: shatter
C: word: fredi	 gloss: Fredi
D: word: ade	 gloss: LIG
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 203:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ... Hurki e ___ Nusa, em, Oktofina kamu duduk situ
Gloss (with missing item): ... Hurki uh ___ Nusa uh Oktofina 2PL sit L.MED
The English translation of this sentence is:‘[in the evening (I said),] ``you (pl) Hurki, uh Herman, Nusa, uh Oktofina sit there'''
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In Papuan Malay, by contrast, the final constituent that sums up the set of conjuncts is a plural \isi{pronoun}. This is illustrated in the examples in (\ref{Example_6.34}) to (\ref{Example_6.36}). The set can consist of just two conjuncts as in (\ref{Example_6.34}), or of three or more as in (\ref{Example_6.35}). Typically the conjuncts are conjoined without an overt coordinator, as in (\ref{Example_6.34}) and (\ref{Example_6.35}). When the set of conjuncts is limited to two, as in (\ref{Example_6.36}), the conjuncts may also be linked with an overt coordinator, usually \isi{comitative} \textitbf{dengang} ‘with’. (For details on the combining of \isi{noun} phrases, see §\ref{Para_14.2}.)
A: word: herman	 gloss: Herman
B: word: mandi	 gloss: bathe
C: word: fredi	 gloss: Fredi
D: word: mama	 gloss: mother
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In Papuan Malay, by contrast, the final constituent that sums up the set of conjuncts is a plural \isi{pronoun}. Question 205:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ... Hurki e Herman Nusa, em, ___ kamu duduk situ
Gloss (with missing item): ... Hurki uh Herman Nusa uh ___ 2PL sit L.MED
The English translation of this sentence is:‘[in the evening (I said),] ``you (pl) Hurki, uh Herman, Nusa, uh Oktofina sit there'''
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In Papuan Malay, by contrast, the final constituent that sums up the set of conjuncts is a plural \isi{pronoun}. This is illustrated in the examples in (\ref{Example_6.34}) to (\ref{Example_6.36}). The set can consist of just two conjuncts as in (\ref{Example_6.34}), or of three or more as in (\ref{Example_6.35}). Typically the conjuncts are conjoined without an overt coordinator, as in (\ref{Example_6.34}) and (\ref{Example_6.35}). When the set of conjuncts is limited to two, as in (\ref{Example_6.36}), the conjuncts may also be linked with an overt coordinator, usually \isi{comitative} \textitbf{dengang} ‘with’. (For details on the combining of \isi{noun} phrases, see §\ref{Para_14.2}.)
A: word: oktofina	 gloss: Oktofina
B: word: oktofernus	 gloss: Oktofernus
C: word: pas	 gloss: precisely
D: word: dari	 gloss: from
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 206:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option.

Gloss (with missing item): ... Hurki uh Herman Nusa uh Oktofina ___ sit L.MED
The English translation of this sentence is:‘[in the evening (I said),] ``you (pl) Hurki, uh Herman, Nusa, uh Oktofina sit there'''
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In Papuan Malay, by contrast, the final constituent that sums up the set of conjuncts is a plural \isi{pronoun}. This is illustrated in the examples in (\ref{Example_6.34}) to (\ref{Example_6.36}). The set can consist of just two conjuncts as in (\ref{Example_6.34}), or of three or more as in (\ref{Example_6.35}). Typically the conjuncts are conjoined without an overt coordinator, as in (\ref{Example_6.34}) and (\ref{Example_6.35}). When the set of conjuncts is limited to two, as in (\ref{Example_6.36}), the conjuncts may also be linked with an overt coordinator, usually \isi{comitative} \textitbf{dengang} ‘with’. (For details on the combining of \isi{noun} phrases, see §\ref{Para_14.2}.)

B: word: kamu~kamu	 gloss: RDP~2PL
C: word: tong	 gloss: 1PL
D: word: tanta	 gloss: aunt
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 215:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Sentence (with missing item): ___ deng bapa dong su meninggal
Gloss (with missing item): ___ with father 3PL already die
The English translation of this sentence is:‘they mother and father have already died’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In Papuan Malay, by contrast, the final constituent that sums up the set of conjuncts is a plural \isi{pronoun}. This is illustrated in the examples in (\ref{Example_6.34}) to (\ref{Example_6.36}). The set can consist of just two conjuncts as in (\ref{Example_6.34}), or of three or more as in (\ref{Example_6.35}). Typically the conjuncts are conjoined without an overt coordinator, as in (\ref{Example_6.34}) and (\ref{Example_6.35}). When the set of conjuncts is limited to two, as in (\ref{Example_6.36}), the conjuncts may also be linked with an overt coordinator, usually \isi{comitative} \textitbf{dengang} ‘with’. (For details on the combining of \isi{noun} phrases, see §\ref{Para_14.2}.)
A: word: mama	 gloss: mother
B: word: mama-ade	 gloss: aunt
C: word: orang-tua	 gloss: parent
D: word: banyak	 gloss: many
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 216:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): mama ___ bapa dong su meninggal
Gloss (with missing item): mother ___ father 3PL already die
The English translation of this sentence is:‘they mother and father have already died’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In Papuan Malay, by contrast, the final constituent that sums up the set of conjuncts is a plural \isi{pronoun}. This is illustrated in the examples in (\ref{Example_6.34}) to (\ref{Example_6.36}). The set can consist of just two conjuncts as in (\ref{Example_6.34}), or of three or more as in (\ref{Example_6.35}). Typically the conjuncts are conjoined its gloss ___out an overt coordinator, as in (\ref{Example_6.34}) and (\ref{Example_6.35}). When the set of conjuncts is limited to two, as in (\ref{Example_6.36}), the conjuncts may also be linked its gloss ___ an overt coordinator, usually \isi{comitative} \textitbf{the morpheme ___ang} ‘its gloss ___’. (For details on the combining of \isi{noun} phrases, see §\ref{Para_14.2}.)
A: word: deng	 gloss: with
B: word: dengang	 gloss: with
C: word: dang	 gloss: and
D: word: wili	 gloss: Wili
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In Papuan Malay, by contrast, the final constituent that sums up the set of conjuncts is a plural \isi{pronoun}. This is illustrated in the examples in (\ref{Example_6.34}) to (\ref{Example_6.36}). The set can consist of just two conjuncts as in (\ref{Example_6.34}), or of three or more as in (\ref{Example_6.35}). Typically the conjuncts are conjoined without an overt coordinator, as in (\ref{Example_6.34}) and (\ref{Example_6.35}). When the set of conjuncts is limited to two, as in (\ref{Example_6.36}), the conjuncts may also be linked with an overt coordinator, usually \isi{comitative} \textitbf{dengang} ‘with’. Question 219:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ___ deng Eferdina kitong dua pi berdoa tugu itu
Gloss (with missing item): ___ with Eferdina 1PL two go pray monument D.DIST
The English translation of this sentence is:‘I and Eferdina, the two of us go (and) pray over that statue’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: When the number of conjuncts is limited to two, Papuan Malay speakers often employ a dual construction in which the adnominal \isi{pronoun} is modified with the \isi{numeral} \textitbf{dua} ‘two’ as in (\ref{Example_6.37}) and (\ref{Example_6.38}). In such a “dual \isi{conjunction}” construction, a term also adopted from \citet[36]{Haspelmath.2007c}, the conjuncts are most often conjoined with an overt coordinator, as in (\ref{Example_6.37}), although coordination without an overt coordinator is also possible, as in (\ref{Example_6.38}).
A: word: sa	 gloss: 1SG
B: word: bisa	 gloss: be.able
C: word: dei	 gloss: 3sg
D: word: dorang	 gloss: 3PL
Please only return the letter (A–D).

In such a “dual \isi{conjunction}” construction, a term also adopted from \citet[36]{Haspelmath.2007c}, the conjuncts are most often conjoined its gloss ___ an overt coordinator, as in (\ref{Example_6.37}), although coordination its gloss ___out an overt coordinator is also possible, as in (\ref{Example_6.38}).
A: word: deng	 gloss: with
B: word: dengang	 gloss: with
C: word: dang	 gloss: and

Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 223:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. B: word: siduasi	 gloss: Siduas
C: word: kedua	 gloss: second
D: word: rahab	 gloss: Rahab
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 224:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Question 234:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): Rahab de bilang, bapa ___ kam dua liat dulu
Gloss (with missing item): Rahab 3SG say father ___ 2PL two see first
The English translation of this sentence is:‘Rahab said, ``father and mother, the two of you have a look!'''
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: When the number of conjuncts is limited to two, Papuan Malay speakers often employ a dual construction in which the adnominal \isi{pronoun} is modified with the \isi{numeral} \textitbf{dua} ‘two’ as in (\ref{Example_6.37}) and (\ref{Example_6.38}). In such a “dual \isi{conjunction}” construction, a term also adopted from \citet[36]{Haspelmath.2007c}, the conjuncts are most often conjoined with an overt coordinator, as in (\ref{Example_6.37}), although coordination without an overt coordinator is also possible, as in (\ref{Example_6.38}).
A: word: mama	 gloss: mother
B: word: mama-ade	 gloss: aunt
C: word: orang-tua	 gloss: parent
D: word: deng	 gloss: with
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 235:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): Rahab de bilang, bapa mama ___ dua liat dulu
Gloss (with missing item): Rahab 3SG say father mother ___ two see first
The English translation of this sentence is:‘Rahab said, ``father and mother, the two of you have a look!'''
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: When the number of conjuncts is limited to two, Papuan Malay speakers often employ a dual construction in which the adnominal \isi{pronoun} is modified with the \isi{numeral} \textitbf{dua} ‘two’ as in (\ref{Example_6.37}) and (\ref{Example_6.38}). In such a “dual \isi{conjunction}” construction, a term also adopted from \citet[36]{Haspelmath.2007c}, the conjuncts are most often conjoined with an overt coordinator, as in (\ref{Example_6.37}), although coordination without an overt coordinator is also possible, as in (\ref{Example_6.38}).
A: word: kam	 gloss: 2PL
B: word: kamar	 gloss: room
C: word: tong	 gloss: 1PL
D: word: cantik	 gloss: be.beautiful
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 236:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): Rahab de bilang, bapa mama kam ___ liat dulu
Gloss (with missing item): Rahab 3SG say father mother 2PL ___ see first
The English translation of this sentence is:‘Rahab said, ``father and mother, the two of you have a look!'''
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: When the number of conjuncts is limited to its gloss ___, Papuan Malay speakers often employ a the morpheme ___l construction in which the adnominal \isi{pronoun} is modified with the \isi{numeral} \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ as in (\ref{Example_6.37}) and (\ref{Example_6.38}). In such a “the morpheme ___l \isi{conjunction}” construction, a term also adopted from \citet[36]{Haspelmath.2007c}, the conjuncts are most often conjoined with an overt coordinator, as in (\ref{Example_6.37}), although coordination without an overt coordinator is also possible, as in (\ref{Example_6.38}).
A: word: dua	 gloss: two
B: word: siduasi	 gloss: Siduas
C: word: kedua	 gloss: second
D: word: orang	 gloss: person
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 237:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ... tida perna dia liat, ___ sungay ko bisa terbuka begini
Gloss (with missing item): ... NEG once 3SG see ___ river 2SG be.able be.opened like.this
The English translation of this sentence is:[Seeing the ocean for the first time:] ‘[never before has he seen, what, a river that is so very big like this ocean,] never before has he seen you, you river can be wide like this?’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Appositions may be restrictive or nonrestrictive. In restrictive \isi{apposition}, the second appositive limits or clarifies the first unit. In nonrestrictive \isi{apposition}, by contrast, the second appositive is added as an optional additional piece of information \citep[182–188]{Morley.2000}. The same applies to Papuan Malay \textsc{pro} \textsc{np} appositions; that is, depending on their semantic function within the clause, the appositions may be restrictive or nonrestrictive. The referent is typically human with consultants agreeing that \textsc{pro} \textsc{np} expressions with nonhuman referents are unacceptable. The corpus contains only one exception in which the referent is an inanimate entity, presented in (\ref{Example_6.1}), repeated as (\ref{Example_6.41}). The construction in (\ref{Example_6.41}), however, involves “a \textstyleChItalic{personification} of the nonhuman object that is addressed”, as \citet[314]{Abrams.2009} describe it (for details on such figures of speech see §\ref{Para_6.2.1.1.3}).
A: word: ko	 gloss: 2SG
B: word: skola	 gloss: go.to.school
C: word: mungking	 gloss: maybe
D: word: hurki	 gloss: Hurki
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 246:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ... yo, akirnya ___ ... \textbar ... mama berdoa berdoa
Gloss (with missing item): ... yes finally ___ ... ... ... mother pray pray
The English translation of this sentence is:‘[so in fifth grade she broke-off school,] yes, finally I, (a/her) mother, prayed (and) prayed’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Appositional \textsc{pro} \textsc{np} constructions are formed with all persons and number; those with singular pronouns are presented in (\ref{Example_6.39}) to (\ref{Example_6.43}) and those with plural pronouns in (\ref{Example_6.44}) to (\ref{Example_6.47}). Dual constructions are also possible, as shown in (\ref{Example_6.48}). Appositions can be bare nouns as in (\ref{Example_6.39}), \isi{noun} phrases with modifiers as in (\ref{Example_6.40}), or coordinate \isi{noun} phrases as in (\ref{Example_6.48}). In terms of intonation, the data in the corpus does not indicate a clear pattern: the \isi{apposition} can be set off from the preceding \isi{pronoun} by a \isi{comma intonation} (“{\textbar}”), as in (\ref{Example_6.39}), or can follow it with no intonation break as in (\ref{Example_6.40}).
A: word: sa	 gloss: 1SG
B: word: bisa	 gloss: be.able
C: word: dei	 gloss: 3sg
D: word: itu	 gloss: D.DIST
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 250:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ___ pemuda ini mati smua
Gloss (with missing item): ___ youth D.PROX die all
The English translation of this sentence is:‘we, the young people here, have all lost enthusiasm’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Appositional \textsc{pro} \textsc{np} constructions are formed with all persons and number; those with singular pronouns are presented in (\ref{Example_6.39}) to (\ref{Example_6.43}) and those with plural pronouns in (\ref{Example_6.44}) to (\ref{Example_6.47}). Dual constructions are also possible, as shown in (\ref{Example_6.48}). Appositions can be bare nouns as in (\ref{Example_6.39}), \isi{noun} phrases with modifiers as in (\ref{Example_6.40}), or coordinate \isi{noun} phrases as in (\ref{Example_6.48}). In terms of intonation, the data in the corpus does not indicate a clear pattern: the \isi{apposition} can be set off from the preceding \isi{pronoun} by a \isi{comma intonation} (“{\textbar}”), as in (\ref{Example_6.39}), or can follow it with no intonation break as in (\ref{Example_6.40}).
A: word: tong	 gloss: 1PL
B: word: kitong	 gloss: 1PL
C: word: kam	 gloss: 2PL
D: word: barce	 gloss: Barce
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 261:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ... yo, akirnya ___ ... \textbar ... mama berdoa berdoa
Gloss (with missing item): ... yes finally ___ ... ... ... mother pray pray
The English translation of this sentence is:‘[so in fifth grade she broke-off school,] yes, finally I, (a/her) mother, prayed (and) prayed’

In terms of intonation, the data in the corpus does not indicate a clear pattern: the \isi{apposition} can be set off from the preceding \isi{pronoun} by a \isi{comma intonation} (“{\textbar}”), as in (\ref{Example_6.39}), or can follow it with no intonation break as in (\ref{Example_6.40}).
A: word: sa	 gloss: 1SG
B: word: bisa	 gloss: be.able
C: word: dei	 gloss: 3sg
D: word: banyak	 gloss: many
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 263:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. A: word: ko	 gloss: 2SG
B: word: skola	 gloss: go.to.school
C: word: niwerawar	 gloss: Niwerawar
D: word: sarles	 gloss: Sarles
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ___ dua ade kaka itu Agus dengang Fredi tra baik
Gloss (with missing item): ___ two ySb oSb D.DIST Agus with Fredi NEG be.good
The English translation of this sentence is:‘the two of them, those siblings, Agus and Fredi, are not good’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Appositional \textsc{pro} \textsc{np} constructions are formed with all persons and number; those with singular pronouns are presented in (\ref{Example_6.39}) to (\ref{Example_6.43}) and those with plural pronouns in (\ref{Example_6.44}) to (\ref{Example_6.47}). Dual constructions are also possible, as shown in (\ref{Example_6.48}). Appositions can be bare nouns as in (\ref{Example_6.39}), \isi{noun} phrases with modifiers as in (\ref{Example_6.40}), or coordinate \isi{noun} phrases as in (\ref{Example_6.48}). In terms of intonation, the data in the corpus does not indicate a clear pattern: the \isi{apposition} can be set off from the preceding \isi{pronoun} by a \isi{comma intonation} (“{\textbar}”), as in (\ref{Example_6.39}), or can follow it with no intonation break as in (\ref{Example_6.40}).
A: word: dorang	 gloss: 3PL
B: word: dong/dorang	 gloss: 3PL
C: word: kam	 gloss: 2PL
D: word: sidaq	 gloss: 3PL
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 271:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. A: word: sa	 gloss: 1SG
B: word: bisa	 gloss: be.able
C: word: dei	 gloss: 3sg
D: word: tiga	 gloss: one
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 273:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Gloss (with missing item): if 2SG NEG go.to.school ___ woman be.beautiful very.soon ...
The English translation of this sentence is:‘if you don’t go to school, later you, a beautiful woman, ...’

In terms of intonation, the data in the corpus does not indicate a clear pattern: the \isi{apposition} can be set off from the preceding \isi{pronoun} by a \isi{comma intonation} (“{\textbar}”), as in (\ref{Example_6.39}), or can follow it with no intonation break as in (\ref{Example_6.40}).
A: word: ko	 gloss: 2SG
B: word: skola	 gloss: go.to.school
C: word: apa	 gloss: what
D: word: dorang	 gloss: 3PL
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 276:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ... yo, akirnya ___ ... \textbar ... mama berdoa berdoa
Gloss (with missing item): ... yes finally ___ ... ... ... mother pray pray
The English translation of this sentence is:‘[so in fifth grade she broke-off school,] yes, finally I, (a/her) mother, prayed (and) prayed’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The appositional constructions with singular pronouns (``\textsc{pro-sg} \textsc{np}'') in (\ref{Example_6.39}), (\ref{Example_6.40}) and (\ref{Example_6.43}) are nonrestrictive with the appositions \textitbf{mama} ‘mother’ in (\ref{Example_6.39}), \textitbf{prempuang cantik} ‘beautiful woman’ in (\ref{Example_6.40}), and \textitbf{ana} ‘child’ in (\ref{Example_6.43}) providing additional optional information not needed for the identification of their pronominal referents. The constructions in (\ref{Example_6.41}) and (\ref{Example_6.42}), by contrast, are restrictive with the appositions \textitbf{sungay ko} ‘you river’ and \textitbf{Agus ni} ‘this Agus’ giving information needed for the identification of the referents \textitbf{ko} ‘\textsc{2sg}’ and \textitbf{dia} ‘\textsc{3sg}’, respectively.
A: word: sa	 gloss: 1SG
B: word: bisa	 gloss: be.able
C: word: dei	 gloss: 3sg
D: word: agus	 gloss: Agus
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 282:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ... tapi de ___ juga cepat ikut terpengaru
Gloss (with missing item): ... but 3SG ___ also be.fast follow be.influenced
The English translation of this sentence is:‘\ldots but he/she, a kid, also quickly follows (others) to be influenced’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The appositional constructions with singular pronouns (``\textsc{pro-sg} \textsc{np}'') in (\ref{Example_6.39}), (\ref{Example_6.40}) and (\ref{Example_6.43}) are nonrestrictive with the appositions \textitbf{mama} ‘mother’ in (\ref{Example_6.39}), \textitbf{prempuang cantik} ‘beautiful woman’ in (\ref{Example_6.40}), and \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ in (\ref{Example_6.43}) providing additional optional information not needed for the identification of their pronominal referents. The constructions in (\ref{Example_6.41}) and (\ref{Example_6.42}), by contrast, are restrictive with the appositions \textitbf{sungay ko} ‘you river’ and \textitbf{Agus ni} ‘this Agus’ giving information needed for the identification of the referents \textitbf{ko} ‘\textsc{2sg}’ and \textitbf{dia} ‘\textsc{3sg}’, respectively.
A: word: ana	 gloss: child
B: word: sana	 gloss: L.DIST
C: word: bayi	 gloss: baby
D: word: kaka	 gloss: oSb
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 283:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. D: word: tiga	 gloss: one
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 285:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Question 290:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ... tida perna dia liat, ___ sungay ko bisa terbuka begini
Gloss (with missing item): ... NEG once 3SG see ___ river 2SG be.able be.opened like.this
The English translation of this sentence is:[Seeing the ocean for the first time:] ‘[never before has he seen, what, a river that is so very big like this ocean,] never before has he seen you, you river can be wide like this?’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The appositional constructions with singular pronouns (``\textsc{pro-sg} \textsc{np}'') in (\ref{Example_6.39}), (\ref{Example_6.40}) and (\ref{Example_6.43}) are nonrestrictive with the appositions \textitbf{mama} ‘mother’ in (\ref{Example_6.39}), \textitbf{prempuang cantik} ‘beautiful woman’ in (\ref{Example_6.40}), and \textitbf{ana} ‘child’ in (\ref{Example_6.43}) providing additional optional information not needed for the identification of their pronominal referents. The constructions in (\ref{Example_6.41}) and (\ref{Example_6.42}), by contrast, are restrictive with the appositions \textitbf{sungay the morpheme ___} ‘you river’ and \textitbf{Agus ni} ‘this Agus’ giving information needed for the identification of the referents \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘\textsc{2sg}’ and \textitbf{dia} ‘\textsc{3sg}’, respectively.
A: word: ko	 gloss: 2SG
B: word: skola	 gloss: go.to.school
C: word: pinda	 gloss: move
D: word: smua	 gloss: all
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The appositional constructions with singular pronouns (``\textsc{pro-sg} \textsc{np}'') in (\ref{Example_6.39}), (\ref{Example_6.40}) and (\ref{Example_6.43}) are nonrestrictive with the appositions \textitbf{mama} ‘mother’ in (\ref{Example_6.39}), \textitbf{prempuang cantik} ‘beautiful woman’ in (\ref{Example_6.40}), and \textitbf{ana} ‘child’ in (\ref{Example_6.43}) providing additional optional information not needed for the identification of their pronominal referents. C: word: air	 gloss: water
D: word: dengang	 gloss: with

Question 293:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Gloss (with missing item): 3SG ask ___ ... ... ... Agus D.PROX 2SG exist lime or
The English translation of this sentence is:‘he asked him, Agus here, ``do you have lime (powder)?'''

The constructions in (\ref{Example_6.41}) and (\ref{Example_6.42}), by contrast, are restrictive with the appositions \textitbf{sungay ko} ‘you river’ and \textitbf{Agus the morpheme ___} ‘this Agus’ giving information needed for the identification of the referents \textitbf{ko} ‘\textsc{2sg}’ and \textitbf{dia} ‘\textsc{3sg}’, respectively.

Question 296:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ___ pemuda ini mati smua
Gloss (with missing item): ___ youth D.PROX die all
The English translation of this sentence is:‘we, the young people here, have all lost enthusiasm’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Most often appositional constructions are formed with plural pronouns, such that ``\textsc{pro-pl} \textsc{np}''. Semantically, \textsc{pro-pl} \textsc{np} are distinct from \textsc{pro-sg} \textsc{np} constructions in that they not only indicate the definiteness of the apposited \isi{noun} phrases, but also their plurality, as shown in (\ref{Example_6.44}) to (\ref{Example_6.47}). For instance, \textitbf{pemuda} ‘youth’ in (\ref{Example_6.44}) or \textitbf{IPA satu} ‘Natural Science I (student)’ in (\ref{Example_6.45}) receive their plural reading from the preceding plural pronouns. If deemed necessary, speakers can specify the number of the apposited \isi{noun} phrases with an adnominal \isi{numeral} or \isi{quantifier}, as in \textitbf{tiga orang itu} ‘those three people’ in (\ref{Example_6.46}), or in \textitbf{brapa prempuang} ‘several women’ in (\ref{Example_6.47}).
A: word: tong	 gloss: 1PL
B: word: kitong	 gloss: 1PL
C: word: kam	 gloss: 2PL
D: word: yoram	 gloss: Yoram
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 297:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): tong ___ ini mati smua
Gloss (with missing item): 1PL ___ D.PROX die all
The English translation of this sentence is:‘we, the young people here, have all lost enthusiasm’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Most often appositional constructions are formed with plural pronouns, such that ``\textsc{pro-pl} \textsc{np}''. Semantically, \textsc{pro-pl} \textsc{np} are distinct from \textsc{pro-sg} \textsc{np} constructions in that they not only indicate the definiteness of the apposited \isi{noun} phrases, but also their plurality, as shown in (\ref{Example_6.44}) to (\ref{Example_6.47}). For instance, \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ in (\ref{Example_6.44}) or \textitbf{IPA satu} ‘Natural Science I (student)’ in (\ref{Example_6.45}) receive their plural reading from the preceding plural pronouns. If deemed necessary, speakers can specify the number of the apposited \isi{noun} phrases with an adnominal \isi{numeral} or \isi{quantifier}, as in \textitbf{tiga orang itu} ‘those three people’ in (\ref{Example_6.46}), or in \textitbf{brapa prempuang} ‘several women’ in (\ref{Example_6.47}).
A: word: pemuda	 gloss: youth
B: word: pe–muda	 gloss: AG–be.young
C: word: blas	 gloss: teens
D: word: dorang	 gloss: 3PL
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 313:
