Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ... sa maki dorang ___ prempuang di situ
Gloss (with missing item): ... 1SG abuse.verbally 3PL ___ woman at L.MED
The English translation of this sentence is:‘[last month,] I verbally abused them, several women, there’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Most often appositional constructions are formed with plural pronouns, such that ``\textsc{pro-pl} \textsc{np}''. Semantically, \textsc{pro-pl} \textsc{np} are distinct from \textsc{pro-sg} \textsc{np} constructions in that they not only indicate the definiteness of the apposited \isi{noun} phrases, but also their plurality, as shown in (\ref{Example_6.44}) to (\ref{Example_6.47}). For instance, \textitbf{pemuda} ‘youth’ in (\ref{Example_6.44}) or \textitbf{IPA satu} ‘Natural Science I (student)’ in (\ref{Example_6.45}) receive their plural reading from the preceding plural pronouns. If deemed necessary, speakers can specify the number of the apposited \isi{noun} phrases with an adnominal \isi{numeral} or \isi{quantifier}, as in \textitbf{tiga orang itu} ‘those three people’ in (\ref{Example_6.46}), or in \textitbf{the morpheme ___ prempuang} ‘its gloss ___ women’ in (\ref{Example_6.47}).
A: word: brapa	 gloss: several
B: word: parapara	 gloss: platform
C: word: banyak	 gloss: many
D: word: tong	 gloss: 1PL
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 314:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ... sa maki dorang brapa ___ di situ
Gloss (with missing item): ... 1SG abuse.verbally 3PL several ___ at L.MED
The English translation of this sentence is:‘[last month,] I verbally abused them, several women, there’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Most often appositional constructions are formed with plural pronouns, such that ``\textsc{pro-pl} \textsc{np}''. Semantically, \textsc{pro-pl} \textsc{np} are distinct from \textsc{pro-sg} \textsc{np} constructions in that they not only indicate the definiteness of the apposited \isi{noun} phrases, but also their plurality, as shown in (\ref{Example_6.44}) to (\ref{Example_6.47}). For instance, \textitbf{pemuda} ‘youth’ in (\ref{Example_6.44}) or \textitbf{IPA satu} ‘Natural Science I (student)’ in (\ref{Example_6.45}) receive their plural reading from the preceding plural pronouns. If deemed necessary, speakers can specify the number of the apposited \isi{noun} phrases with an adnominal \isi{numeral} or \isi{quantifier}, as in \textitbf{tiga orang itu} ‘those three people’ in (\ref{Example_6.46}), or in \textitbf{brapa the morpheme ___} ‘several women’ in (\ref{Example_6.47}).
A: word: prempuang	 gloss: woman
B: word: uang	 gloss: money
C: word: maytua	 gloss: wife
D: word: kaka	 gloss: oSb
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 315:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ___ dua ade kaka itu Agus dengang Fredi tra baik
Gloss (with missing item): ___ two ySb oSb D.DIST Agus with Fredi NEG be.good
The English translation of this sentence is:‘the two of them, those siblings, Agus and Fredi, are not good’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: When the number of referents encoded by the apposited \isi{noun} phrase is limited to two, Papuan Malay speakers also use dual constructions in which the \isi{pronoun} is modified with the \isi{numeral} \textitbf{dua} ‘two’, such that ``\textsc{pro-pl} \textitbf{dua} \textsc{np}'', as in (\ref{Example_6.48}). In the corpus, however, such constructions are rare and the dual constructions are always formed with the third person plural \isi{pronoun}.\footnote{The \textsc{pro} \textsc{np} constructions presented in this section were analyzed as appositions. One question for further research is whether these constructions could instead be analyzed as \isi{noun} phrases with pre-head pronouns. It is expected that such preposed pronouns would have an individuating function given that other pre-head determiners, namely numerals and quantifiers, also have an individuating function (see §\ref{Para_8.3}). One problem with such an analysis, however, would be \textsc{pro} \textsc{np} constructions with singular pronouns, as in (\ref{Example_6.39}) to (\ref{Example_6.43}), given that singular pronouns would hardly have an individuating function. (For a discussion of the determiner function of post-head pronouns see §\ref{Para_6.2}.)}
A: word: dorang	 gloss: 3PL
B: word: dong/dorang	 gloss: 3PL
C: word: kam	 gloss: 2PL
D: word: pendeta	 gloss: pastor
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 316:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): dorang ___ ade kaka itu Agus dengang Fredi tra baik
Gloss (with missing item): 3PL ___ ySb oSb D.DIST Agus with Fredi NEG be.good
The English translation of this sentence is:‘the two of them, those siblings, Agus and Fredi, are not good’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: When the number of referents encoded by the apposited \isi{noun} phrase is limited to its gloss ___, Papuan Malay speakers also use the morpheme ___l constructions in which the \isi{pronoun} is modified with the \isi{numeral} \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’, such that ``\textsc{pro-pl} \textitbf{the morpheme ___} \textsc{np}'', as in (\ref{Example_6.48}). In the corpus, however, such constructions are rare and the the morpheme ___l constructions are always formed with the third person plural \isi{pronoun}.\footnote{The \textsc{pro} \textsc{np} constructions presented in this section were analyzed as appositions. One question for further research is whether these constructions could instead be analyzed as \isi{noun} phrases with pre-head pronouns. It is expected that such preposed pronouns would have an indivithe morpheme ___ting function given that other pre-head determiners, namely numerals and quantifiers, also have an indivithe morpheme ___ting function (see §\ref{Para_8.3}). One problem with such an analysis, however, would be \textsc{pro} \textsc{np} constructions with singular pronouns, as in (\ref{Example_6.39}) to (\ref{Example_6.43}), given that singular pronouns would hardly have an indivithe morpheme ___ting function. (For a discussion of the determiner function of post-head pronouns see §\ref{Para_6.2}.)}
A: word: dua	 gloss: two
B: word: siduasi	 gloss: Siduas
C: word: kedua	 gloss: second
D: word: dong	 gloss: 3PL
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 319:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Question 320:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ... yo, akirnya ___ ... \textbar ... mama berdoa berdoa
Gloss (with missing item): ... yes finally ___ ... ... ... mother pray pray
The English translation of this sentence is:‘[so in fifth grade she broke-off school,] yes, finally I, (a/her) mother, prayed (and) prayed’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: When the number of referents encoded by the apposited \isi{noun} phrase is limited to two, Papuan Malay speakers also use dual constructions in which the \isi{pronoun} is modified with the \isi{numeral} \textitbf{dua} ‘two’, such that ``\textsc{pro-pl} \textitbf{dua} \textsc{np}'', as in (\ref{Example_6.48}). In the corpus, however, such constructions are rare and the dual constructions are always formed with the third person plural \isi{pronoun}.\footnote{The \textsc{pro} \textsc{np} constructions presented in this section were analyzed as appositions. One question for further research is whether these constructions could instead be analyzed as \isi{noun} phrases with pre-head pronouns. It is expected that such preposed pronouns would have an individuating function given that other pre-head determiners, namely numerals and quantifiers, also have an individuating function (see §\ref{Para_8.3}). One problem with such an analysis, however, would be \textsc{pro} \textsc{np} constructions with singular pronouns, as in (\ref{Example_6.39}) to (\ref{Example_6.43}), given that singular pronouns would hardly have an individuating function. (For a discussion of the determiner function of post-head pronouns see §\ref{Para_6.2}.)}
A: word: sa	 gloss: 1SG
B: word: bisa	 gloss: be.able
C: word: dei	 gloss: 3sg
D: word: mama-tua	 gloss: aunt
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 321:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Gloss (with missing item): ... yes finally 1SG ... ... ... ___ pray pray
The English translation of this sentence is:‘[so in fifth grade she broke-off school,] yes, finally I, (a/her) mother, prayed (and) prayed’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: When the number of referents encoded by the apposited \isi{noun} phrase is limited to two, Papuan Malay speakers also use dual constructions in which the \isi{pronoun} is modified with the \isi{numeral} \textitbf{dua} ‘two’, such that ``\textsc{pro-pl} \textitbf{dua} \textsc{np}'', as in (\ref{Example_6.48}). One question for further research is whether these constructions could instead be analyzed as \isi{noun} phrases with pre-head pronouns. It is expected that such preposed pronouns would have an individuating function given that other pre-head determiners, namely numerals and quantifiers, also have an individuating function (see §\ref{Para_8.3}). One problem with such an analysis, however, would be \textsc{pro} \textsc{np} constructions with singular pronouns, as in (\ref{Example_6.39}) to (\ref{Example_6.43}), given that singular pronouns would hardly have an individuating function. Question 322:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. One question for further research is whether these constructions could instead be analyzed as \isi{noun} phrases with pre-head pronouns. It is expected that such preposed pronouns would have an individuating function given that other pre-head the morpheme ___terminers, namely numerals and quantifiers, also have an individuating function (see §\ref{Para_8.3}). One problem with such an analysis, however, would be \textsc{pro} \textsc{np} constructions with singular pronouns, as in (\ref{Example_6.39}) to (\ref{Example_6.43}), given that singular pronouns would hardly have an individuating function. Question 323:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. One question for further research is whether these constructions could instead be the morpheme ___lyzed as \isi{noun} phrases with pre-head pronouns. It is expected that such preposed pronouns would have an individuating function given that other pre-head determiners, namely numerals and quantifiers, also have an individuating function (see §\ref{Para_8.3}). One problem with such an the morpheme ___lysis, however, would be \textsc{pro} \textsc{np} constructions with singular pronouns, as in (\ref{Example_6.39}) to (\ref{Example_6.43}), given that singular pronouns would hardly have an individuating function. (For a discussion of the determiner function of post-head pronouns see §\ref{Para_6.2}.)}

Question 324:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ___ ko] jangang {gara\Tildegara} [tanta dia itu]!
Gloss (with missing item): ___ 2SG NEG.IMP RDP\Tildeirritate aunt 3SG D.DIST
The English translation of this sentence is:[Addressing a young boy:] ‘you Wili don’t irritate that aunt!’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: This is illustrated with the example in (\ref{Example_6.49}). In the \textsc{np} \textsc{2sg} \isi{noun} phrase \textitbf{its gloss ___ ko} ‘you its gloss ___’, the second person \isi{pronoun} marks the person spoken to as the intended addressee. In the \textsc{np} \textsc{3sg} \isi{noun} phrase \textitbf{tanta dia itu} ‘that aunt’ (literally ‘that she aunt’), the third person \isi{pronoun} signals that the interlocutors are assumed to know the referent. The brackets indicate the constituent structure within the \isi{noun} phrase. Details are discussed in §\ref{Para_6.2.1} and §\ref{Para_6.2.2}.
A: word: wili	 gloss: Wili
B: word: liat	 gloss: see
C: word: fredi	 gloss: Fredi
D: word: iskia	 gloss: Iskia
Please only return the letter (A–D).

In the \textsc{np} \textsc{3sg} \isi{noun} phrase \textitbf{tanta dia itu} ‘that aunt’ (literally ‘that she aunt’), the third person \isi{pronoun} signals that the interlocutors are assumed to know the referent. The brackets indicate the constituent structure within the \isi{noun} phrase. Details are discussed in §\ref{Para_6.2.1} and §\ref{Para_6.2.2}.
A: word: ko	 gloss: 2SG
B: word: skola	 gloss: go.to.school
C: word: karna	 gloss: because
D: word: banyak	 gloss: many
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 327:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: This is illustrated with the example in (\ref{Example_6.49}). In the \textsc{np} \textsc{3sg} \isi{noun} phrase \textitbf{tanta the morpheme ___ itu} ‘that aunt’ (literally ‘that she aunt’), the third person \isi{pronoun} signals that the interlocutors are assumed to know the referent. The brackets indicate the constituent structure within the \isi{noun} phrase. Details are discussed in §\ref{Para_6.2.1} and §\ref{Para_6.2.2}.
A: word: dia	 gloss: 3SG
B: word: diai	 gloss: 3SG
C: word: dei	 gloss: 3sg
D: word: yoram	 gloss: Yoram
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 328:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): [Wili ko] jangang {gara\Tildegara} [tanta dia ___
Gloss (with missing item): Wili 2SG NEG.IMP RDP\Tildeirritate aunt 3SG ___
The English translation of this sentence is:[Addressing a young boy:] ‘you Wili don’t irritate that aunt!’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: This is illustrated with the example in (\ref{Example_6.49}). In the \textsc{np} \textsc{2sg} \isi{noun} phrase \textitbf{Wili ko} ‘you Wili’, the second person \isi{pronoun} marks the person spoken to as the intended addressee. In the \textsc{np} \textsc{3sg} \isi{noun} phrase \textitbf{tanta dia the morpheme ___} ‘that aunt’ (literally ‘that she aunt’), the third person \isi{pronoun} signals that the interlocutors are assumed to know the referent. The brackets indicate the constthe morpheme ___ent structure within the \isi{noun} phrase. Details are discussed in §\ref{Para_6.2.1} and §\ref{Para_6.2.2}.
A: word: itu	 gloss: D.DIST
B: word: situ	 gloss: L.MED
C: word: sana	 gloss: L.DIST
D: word: ambil	 gloss: fetch
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 329:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ___ ko] masak daging sa biking papeda e?
Gloss (with missing item): ___ 2SG cook meat 1SG make sagu.porridge eh
The English translation of this sentence is:‘you aunt cook the meat, I make the sagu porridge, eh?’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In \isi{direct speech}, speakers employ \textsc{np} \textsc{2sg} \isi{noun} phrases when they want to send an unambiguous signal that the person spoken to is indeed the intended addressee. In such \isi{noun} phrases, the second person \textitbf{ko} ‘\textsc{2sg}’ marks the referent encoded in the head nominal as the addressee of the utterance. The head nominal can be a common \isi{noun} or a \isi{proper noun}, as shown in (\ref{Example_6.51}) to (\ref{Example_6.54}).
A: word: mama-ade	 gloss: aunt
B: word: mama-tua	 gloss: aunt
C: word: nene	 gloss: grandmother
D: word: anjing	 gloss: dog
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 333:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ___ ko] masak daging sa biking papeda e?
Gloss (with missing item): ___ 2SG cook meat 1SG make sagu.porridge eh
The English translation of this sentence is:‘you aunt cook the meat, I make the sagu porridge, eh?’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: When the head nominal is a common \isi{noun}, second person \textitbf{ko} ‘\textsc{2sg}’ indicates which particular individual is being referred to. Thereby the \isi{pronoun} allows the unambiguous identification of the addressee as the intended referent. Often speakers choose this strategy when they address an individual in a group of several interlocutors as in (\ref{Example_6.51}) and (\ref{Example_6.52}), or when they give an order to someone, as in (\ref{Example_6.53}) and (\ref{Example_6.54}).
A: word: mama-ade	 gloss: aunt
B: word: mama-tua	 gloss: aunt
C: word: nene	 gloss: grandmother
D: word: markus	 gloss: Markus
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 341:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ___ ko] jangang {gara\Tildegara} tanta dia itu!
Gloss (with missing item): ___ 2SG NEG.IMP RDP\Tildeirritate aunt 3SG D.DIST
The English translation of this sentence is:[Addressing a young boy:] ‘you Wili don’t irritate that aunt!’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: When \textitbf{ko} ‘\textsc{2sg}’ co-occurs with a \isi{proper noun}, as in (\ref{Example_6.53}) or (\ref{Example_6.54}), one might argue that such \isi{noun} phrases are redundant with the \isi{pronoun} as adnominal determiner being superfluous, since proper nouns are inherently \isi{definite}. In Papuan Malay, however, \textsc{np} \textsc{2sg} expressions constitute direct speech-act strategies which allow speakers to single out participants and to mark them unambiguously as the intended referents of the proper nouns. Being addressed with such a \textsc{np} \textsc{2sg} \isi{noun} phrase leaves the addressees little room for interpretation. Thereby, \textsc{np} \textsc{2sg} nouns phrases are much more direct than the indirect strategies presented in (\ref{Example_6.55}) and (\ref{Example_6.56}),
A: word: wili	 gloss: Wili
B: word: liat	 gloss: see
C: word: fredi	 gloss: Fredi
D: word: miflal	 gloss: Miflal
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 346:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ___ ingat tong itu uang!
Gloss (with missing item): ___ remember 1PL D.DIST money
The English translation of this sentence is:‘you (‘father’) remember our, what’s-its-name, money!’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Most often, speakers do not address their interlocutor with a direct \textsc{np} \textsc{2sg} expression. Instead, they tend to use more indirect, face-preserving strategies by addressing their interlocutor with a \isi{kinship term} or their proper name. This applies especially when issuing a request or an order, as shown in (\ref{Example_6.55}) and (\ref{Example_6.56}). In (\ref{Example_6.55}), a daughter asks her its gloss ___ for money by addressing him with the \isi{kinship term} \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’. In (\ref{Example_6.56}), a its gloss ___ requests his daughter to talk to him by addressing her with her proper name \textitbf{Nofela}.
A: word: bapa	 gloss: father
B: word: bapa-ade	 gloss: uncle
C: word: tete	 gloss: grandfather
D: word: agus	 gloss: Agus
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 347:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ___ ingat tong itu uang!
Gloss (with missing item): ___ remember 1PL D.DIST money
The English translation of this sentence is:‘you (‘father’) remember our, what’s-its-name, money!’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Most often, speakers do not address their interlocutor with a direct \textsc{np} \textsc{2sg} expression. Instead, they tend to use more indirect, face-preserving strategies by addressing their interlocutor with a \isi{kinship term} or their proper name. This applies especially when issuing a request or an order, as shown in (\ref{Example_6.55}) and (\ref{Example_6.56}). In (\ref{Example_6.55}), a daughter asks her its gloss ___ for money by addressing him with the \isi{kinship term} \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’. In (\ref{Example_6.56}), a its gloss ___ requests his daughter to talk to him by addressing her with her proper name \textitbf{Nofela}.
A: word: bapa	 gloss: father
B: word: bapa-ade	 gloss: uncle
C: word: tete	 gloss: grandfather
D: word: brapa	 gloss: several
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 348:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): de bilang, ___ ko bisa liat orang di luar?
Gloss (with missing item): 3SG say ___ 2SG be.able see person at outside
The English translation of this sentence is:[About hospitality:] ‘[(my father said to me,) ``if you close the door, can you see the people outside?'',] he said, ``can you Natalia see the people outside?'''
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Speakers also employ \textsc{np} \textsc{2sg} \isi{noun} phrases when they report \isi{direct speech}. This reporting is usually done through quoting. Cross-linguistically, direct quotations serve “to dramatize and highlight important elements in a narrative”, while in\isi{direct speech} “seems less vivid and colorful”, as \citet[552]{Bublitz.2006} point out. The same applies to Papuan Malay, as speakers typically use quotes when reporting \isi{direct speech}, as demonstrated in (\ref{Example_6.57}) and (\ref{Example_6.58}).
A: word: natalia	 gloss: Natalia
B: word: natal	 gloss: Christmas
C: word: martina	 gloss: Martina
D: word: kaka	 gloss: oSb
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 350:

The English translation of this sentence is:‘the two of us said to Iskia, ``you Iskia come with (us), you come with (us) because it’s already a bit late in the evening'''

This reporting is usually done through quoting. Cross-linguistically, direct quotations serve “to dramatize and highlight important elements in a narrative”, while in\isi{direct speech} “seems less vivid and colorful”, as \citet[552]{Bublitz.2006} point out. Question 351:

Question 353:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): de bilang, ___ ko bisa liat orang di luar?
Gloss (with missing item): 3SG say ___ 2SG be.able see person at outside
The English translation of this sentence is:[About hospitality:] ‘[(my father said to me,) ``if you close the door, can you see the people outside?'',] he said, ``can you Natalia see the people outside?'''
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: When relating what had been said to a particular individual, speakers usually begin the quote with an \textsc{np} \textsc{2sg} \isi{noun} phrase, as (\ref{Example_6.57}) and (\ref{Example_6.58}). This has two functions. First, it indicates the referent as the addressee of the \isi{reported speech}. Second, \textsc{np} \textsc{2sg} \isi{noun} phrases mark the referent as familiar or given. Thereby they signal to the hearers that they should be able to identify the referent. Subsequently, speakers continue the direct quote by referring to, or “addressing”, the referent with bare \textitbf{ko} ‘\textsc{2sg}’, as in (\ref{Example_6.58}). Note that the first occurrence of \textitbf{Iskia} in (\ref{Example_6.58}) is not part of the quote but the direct object of \textitbf{bilang} ‘say’.
A: word: natalia	 gloss: Natalia
B: word: natal	 gloss: Christmas
C: word: martina	 gloss: Martina
D: word: banyak	 gloss: many
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 363:

This has two functions. First, it indicates the referent as the addressee of the \isi{reported speech}. Second, \textsc{np} \textsc{2sg} \isi{noun} phrases mark the referent as familiar or given. Thereby they signal to the hearers that they should be able to identify the referent. Subsequently, speakers continue the direct quote by referring to, or “addressing”, the referent with bare \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘\textsc{2sg}’, as in (\ref{Example_6.58}). Note that the first occurrence of \textitbf{Iskia} in (\ref{Example_6.58}) is not part of the quote but the direct object of \textitbf{bilang} ‘say’.
A: word: ko	 gloss: 2SG
B: word: skola	 gloss: go.to.school
C: word: katalq	 gloss: Katalq
D: word: puti	 gloss: be.white
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 364:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ___ {dia} {lewat} {tete,} {de} {lompat} {mo} pukul Fitri ... Fitri kas naik kaki di sini, Martin ko jatu, dia lari ke mari, dia mo pukul Fitri
Gloss (with missing item): ___ 3sg pass.by grandfather 3sg jump want hit Fitri ... Fitri give ascend foot at L.PROX Martin 2SG fall 3SG run to hither 3SG want hit Fitri
The English translation of this sentence is:[About a fight between Fitri and Martin:] ‘Martin went past grandfather, he jumped (and) wanted to hit Fitri [and Fitri caught his foot and] Fitri kicked (Martin) here, you Martin fell, (then) he ran (over) here, he wanted to hit Fitri’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: This explanation also applies to \textsc{np} \textsc{2sg} \isi{noun} phrase apostrophes in Papuan Malay as illustrated in (\ref{Example_6.59}) to (\ref{Example_6.61}). Structurally, these utterances resemble direct quotations. Contrasting with the \isi{direct speech} situations in (\ref{Example_6.51}) to (\ref{Example_6.54}), however, the addressed referents were not present when the utterances occurred. And in contrast to the \isi{reported speech} situation in (\ref{Example_6.57}) and (\ref{Example_6.58}), the speakers in (\ref{Example_6.59}) to (\ref{Example_6.61}) do not relate direct quotes. Instead, they “turn away” from their audience to “address a second audience” of human or nonhuman referents.
A: word: martin	 gloss: Martin
B: word: martina	 gloss: Martina
C: word: siapa	 gloss: who
D: word: dengang	 gloss: with
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 368:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Gloss (with missing item): ... NEG once 3SG see ___ river 2SG be.able be.opened like.this
The English translation of this sentence is:[Seeing the ocean for the first time:] ‘[never before has he seen, what, a river that is so very big like this ocean,] never before has he seen you, you river can be wide like this?’

Instead, they “turn away” from their audience to “address a second audience” of human or nonhuman referents.

D: word: rahab	 gloss: Rahab

Question 373:

Question 379:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Gloss (with missing item): 1PL two say Iskia Iskia 2SG accompany ___ accompany because already be.protracted night few
The English translation of this sentence is:‘the two of us said to Iskia, ``you Iskia come with (us), you come with (us) because it’s already a bit late in the evening'''
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: This explanation also applies to \textsc{np} \textsc{2sg} \isi{noun} phrase apostrophes in Papuan Malay as illustrated in (\ref{Example_6.59}) to (\ref{Example_6.61}). Structurally, these utterances resemble direct quotations. Contrasting with the \isi{direct speech} situations in (\ref{Example_6.51}) to (\ref{Example_6.54}), however, the addressed referents were not present when the utterances occurred. And in contrast to the \isi{reported speech} situation in (\ref{Example_6.57}) and (\ref{Example_6.58}), the speakers in (\ref{Example_6.59}) to (\ref{Example_6.61}) do not relate direct quotes. Instead, they “turn away” from their audience to “address a second audience” of human or nonhuman referents.
A: word: ko	 gloss: 2SG
B: word: skola	 gloss: go.to.school
C: word: kembang-api	 gloss: fire-cracker
D: word: natalia	 gloss: Natalia
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 380:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Gloss (with missing item): ___ 3sg pass.by grandfather 3sg jump want hit Fitri ... Fitri give ascend foot at L.PROX Martin 2SG fall 3SG run to hither 3SG want hit Fitri
The English translation of this sentence is:[About a fight between Fitri and Martin:] ‘Martin went past grandfather, he jumped (and) wanted to hit Fitri [and Fitri caught his foot and] Fitri kicked (Martin) here, you Martin fell, (then) he ran (over) here, he wanted to hit Fitri’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: This explanation also applies to \textsc{np} \textsc{2sg} \isi{noun} phrase apostrophes in Papuan Malay as illustrated in (\ref{Example_6.59}) to (\ref{Example_6.61}). Structurally, these utterances resemble direct quotations. Question 384:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Sentence (with missing item): ... tida perna dia liat, ___ [sungay ko] bisa terbuka begini
Gloss (with missing item): ... NEG once 3SG see ___ river 2SG be.able be.opened like.this
The English translation of this sentence is:[Seeing the ocean for the first time:] ‘[never before has he seen, what, a river that is so very big like this ocean,] never before has he seen you, you river can be wide like this?’

Instead, they “turn away” from their audience to “address a second audience” of human or nonhuman referents.

Question 387:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ___ {dia} {lewat} {tete,} {de} {lompat} {mo} pukul Fitri ... Fitri kas naik kaki di sini, Martin ko jatu, dia lari ke mari, dia mo pukul Fitri
Gloss (with missing item): ___ 3sg pass.by grandfather 3sg jump want hit Fitri ... Fitri give ascend foot at L.PROX Martin 2SG fall 3SG run to hither 3SG want hit Fitri
The English translation of this sentence is:[About a fight between Fitri and Martin:] ‘Martin went past grandfather, he jumped (and) wanted to hit Fitri [and Fitri caught his foot and] Fitri kicked (Martin) here, you Martin fell, (then) he ran (over) here, he wanted to hit Fitri’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The example in (\ref{Example_6.59}) is part of a story about a fight between \textitbf{its gloss ___} and \textitbf{Fitri}, with the speaker relating how \textitbf{its gloss ___} attacked \textitbf{Fitri}. Notably, neither \textitbf{its gloss ___} nor \textitbf{Fitri} were present when the speaker recounted the incident. When mentioned the first time, \textitbf{its gloss ___} is marked as a third-person actor, as is typical of narratives with non-speech-act participants. Later in the discourse, however, \textitbf{its gloss ___} is marked as the addressee. More specifically, the speaker first refers to \textitbf{its gloss ___} with the \textsc{np} \textsc{3sg} \isi{noun} phrase \textitbf{its gloss ___ dia lewat} ‘its gloss ___ went past’ (literally ‘he its gloss ___’) (see also §\ref{Para_6.2.1.2}). Next, the speaker refers to \textitbf{its gloss ___} with the third person singular \isi{pronoun} in \textitbf{de lompat} ‘he jumped’. Now \textitbf{Fitri} returns the attack and kicks \textitbf{its gloss ___} badly. At this point, the speaker interrupts the flow of her narrative about the two non-speech-act participants and employs the \textsc{np} \textsc{2sg} \isi{noun} phrase \textitbf{its gloss ___ ko} ‘you its gloss ___’ to relate that \textitbf{its gloss ___} fell to the ground. In turning away from her audience and addressing absent \textitbf{its gloss ___}, the speaker gives “emotional impetus” to the fact that \textitbf{its gloss ___} went down after having been kicked by a woman, thereby creating an emotional reaction in her audience.
A: word: martin	 gloss: Martin
B: word: martina	 gloss: Martina
C: word: siapa	 gloss: who
D: word: ana	 gloss: child
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 388:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): {Martin} ___ {lewat} {tete,} {de} {lompat} {mo} pukul Fitri ... Fitri kas naik kaki di sini, Martin ko jatu, dia lari ke mari, dia mo pukul Fitri
Gloss (with missing item): Martin ___ pass.by grandfather 3sg jump want hit Fitri ... Fitri give ascend foot at L.PROX Martin 2SG fall 3SG run to hither 3SG want hit Fitri
The English translation of this sentence is:[About a fight between Fitri and Martin:] ‘Martin went past grandfather, he jumped (and) wanted to hit Fitri [and Fitri caught his foot and] Fitri kicked (Martin) here, you Martin fell, (then) he ran (over) here, he wanted to hit Fitri’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The example in (\ref{Example_6.59}) is part of a story about a fight between \textitbf{Martin} and \textitbf{Fitri}, with the speaker relating how \textitbf{Martin} attacked \textitbf{Fitri}. Notably, neither \textitbf{Martin} nor \textitbf{Fitri} were present when the speaker recounted the incident. When mentioned the first time, \textitbf{Martin} is marked as a third-person actor, as is typical of narratives with non-speech-act participants. Later in the discourse, however, \textitbf{Martin} is marked as the addressee. More specifically, the speaker first refers to \textitbf{Martin} with the \textsc{np} \textsc{its gloss ___} \isi{noun} phrase \textitbf{Martin the morpheme ___ lewat} ‘Martin went past’ (literally ‘he Martin’) (see also §\ref{Para_6.2.1.2}). Next, the speaker refers to \textitbf{Martin} with the third person singular \isi{pronoun} in \textitbf{de lompat} ‘he jumped’. Now \textitbf{Fitri} returns the attack and kicks \textitbf{Martin} badly. At this point, the speaker interrupts the flow of her narrative about the two non-speech-act participants and employs the \textsc{np} \textsc{2sg} \isi{noun} phrase \textitbf{Martin ko} ‘you Martin’ to relate that \textitbf{Martin} fell to the ground. In turning away from her audience and addressing absent \textitbf{Martin}, the speaker gives “emotional impetus” to the fact that \textitbf{Martin} went down after having been kicked by a woman, thereby creating an emotional reaction in her audience.

B: word: diai	 gloss: 3SG
C: word: dɪa	 gloss: 3SG
D: word: maytua	 gloss: wife
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 390:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): {Martin} {dia} {lewat} {tete,} {de} {lompat} {mo} pukul Fitri ... Fitri kas naik kaki di sini, Martin ___ jatu, dia lari ke mari, dia mo pukul Fitri
Gloss (with missing item): Martin 3sg pass.by grandfather 3sg jump want hit Fitri ... Fitri give ascend foot at L.PROX Martin ___ fall 3SG run to hither 3SG want hit Fitri
The English translation of this sentence is:[About a fight between Fitri and Martin:] ‘Martin went past grandfather, he jumped (and) wanted to hit Fitri [and Fitri caught his foot and] Fitri kicked (Martin) here, you Martin fell, (then) he ran (over) here, he wanted to hit Fitri’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The example in (\ref{Example_6.59}) is part of a story about a fight between \textitbf{Martin} and \textitbf{Fitri}, with the speaker relating how \textitbf{Martin} attacked \textitbf{Fitri}. Notably, neither \textitbf{Martin} nor \textitbf{Fitri} were present when the speaker recounted the incident. When mentioned the first time, \textitbf{Martin} is marked as a third-person actor, as is typical of narratives with non-speech-act participants. Later in the discourse, however, \textitbf{Martin} is marked as the addressee. More specifically, the speaker first refers to \textitbf{Martin} with the \textsc{np} \textsc{3sg} \isi{noun} phrase \textitbf{Martin dia lewat} ‘Martin went past’ (literally ‘he Martin’) (see also §\ref{Para_6.2.1.2}). Next, the speaker refers to \textitbf{Martin} with the third person singular \isi{pronoun} in \textitbf{de lompat} ‘he jumped’. Now \textitbf{Fitri} returns the attack and kicks \textitbf{Martin} badly. At this point, the speaker interrupts the flow of her narrative about the two non-speech-act participants and employs the \textsc{np} \textsc{2sg} \isi{noun} phrase \textitbf{Martin the morpheme ___} ‘you Martin’ to relate that \textitbf{Martin} fell to the ground. In turning away from her audience and addressing absent \textitbf{Martin}, the speaker gives “emotional impetus” to the fact that \textitbf{Martin} went down after having been kicked by a woman, thereby creating an emotional reaction in her audience.
A: word: ko	 gloss: 2SG
B: word: skola	 gloss: go.to.school
C: word: mungking	 gloss: maybe
D: word: saya	 gloss: 1SG
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 391:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ... ___ ko datang suda, hujang besar datang suda
Gloss (with missing item): ... ___ 2SG come already rain be.big come already
The English translation of this sentence is:[About a storm during a boat trip:] ‘you wind already came up, a big rain already came up’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: \textsc{np} \textsc{2sg} apostrophes are also formed with nonhuman referents. They “imply a \textstyleChItalic{personification} of the nonhuman object that is addressed” {(Abrams and Harpham 2009: 314)}. In (\ref{Example_6.60}), for instance, the speaker recounts a stormy boat trip. Suddenly, she turns away from her audience to address the main protagonist \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ with the \textsc{np} \textsc{2sg} \isi{noun} phrase \textitbf{the morpheme ___ ko} ‘you its gloss ___’. In the example in (\ref{Example_6.1}), repeated as (\ref{Example_6.61}), the speaker relates how one of his ancestors came down to the coast. Seeing the ocean for the first time, he mistakes it for a wide river. At this point the speaker turns away from his audience to address this \textitbf{sungay} ‘river’ with the \textsc{np} \textsc{2sg} \isi{noun} phrase \textitbf{sungay ko} ‘you river’. Note that the \isi{apostrophe} is part of an appositional \textsc{pro} \textsc{np} construction with preposed \textitbf{ko} ‘\textsc{2sg}’, such that \textitbf{ko sungay ko} ‘you, you river’ (see §\ref{Para_6.1.6}).
A: word: anging	 gloss: wind
B: word: dinging	 gloss: be.cold
C: word: langit	 gloss: sky
D: word: tiga	 gloss: one
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 392:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ... anging ___ datang suda, hujang besar datang suda
Gloss (with missing item): ... wind ___ come already rain be.big come already
The English translation of this sentence is:[About a storm during a boat trip:] ‘you wind already came up, a big rain already came up’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: \textsc{np} \textsc{2sg} apostrophes are also formed with nonhuman referents. They “imply a \textstyleChItalic{personification} of the nonhuman object that is addressed” {(Abrams and Harpham 2009: 314)}. In (\ref{Example_6.60}), for instance, the speaker recounts a stormy boat trip. Suddenly, she turns away from her audience to address the main protagonist \textitbf{anging} ‘wind’ with the \textsc{np} \textsc{2sg} \isi{noun} phrase \textitbf{anging the morpheme ___} ‘you wind’. In the example in (\ref{Example_6.1}), repeated as (\ref{Example_6.61}), the speaker relates how one of his ancestors came down to the coast. Seeing the ocean for the first time, he mistakes it for a wide river. At this point the speaker turns away from his audience to address this \textitbf{sungay} ‘river’ with the \textsc{np} \textsc{2sg} \isi{noun} phrase \textitbf{sungay the morpheme ___} ‘you river’. Note that the \isi{apostrophe} is part of an appositional \textsc{pro} \textsc{np} construction with preposed \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘\textsc{2sg}’, such that \textitbf{the morpheme ___ sungay the morpheme ___} ‘you, you river’ (see §\ref{Para_6.1.6}).
A: word: ko	 gloss: 2SG
B: word: skola	 gloss: go.to.school
C: word: lurus	 gloss: be.straight
D: word: anjing	 gloss: dog
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 393:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ... tida perna dia liat, ___ sungay ko bisa terbuka begini
Gloss (with missing item): ... NEG once 3SG see ___ river 2SG be.able be.opened like.this
The English translation of this sentence is:[Seeing the ocean for the first time:] ‘[never before has he seen, what, a river that is so very big like this ocean,] never before has he seen you, you river can be wide like this?’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: \textsc{np} \textsc{2sg} apostrophes are also formed with nonhuman referents. They “imply a \textstyleChItalic{personification} of the nonhuman object that is addressed” {(Abrams and Harpham 2009: 314)}. In (\ref{Example_6.60}), for instance, the speaker recounts a stormy boat trip. Suddenly, she turns away from her audience to address the main protagonist \textitbf{anging} ‘wind’ with the \textsc{np} \textsc{2sg} \isi{noun} phrase \textitbf{anging the morpheme ___} ‘you wind’. In the example in (\ref{Example_6.1}), repeated as (\ref{Example_6.61}), the speaker relates how one of his ancestors came down to the coast. Note that the \isi{apostrophe} is part of an appositional \textsc{pro} \textsc{np} construction with preposed \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘\textsc{2sg}’, such that \textitbf{the morpheme ___ sungay the morpheme ___} ‘you, you river’ (see §\ref{Para_6.1.6}).
A: word: ko	 gloss: 2SG
B: word: skola	 gloss: go.to.school

D: word: markus	 gloss: Markus

Question 399:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): de bilang, ___ ko bisa liat orang di luar?
Gloss (with missing item): 3SG say ___ 2SG be.able see person at outside
The English translation of this sentence is:[About hospitality:] ‘[(my father said to me,) ``if you close the door, can you see the people outside?'',] he said, ``can you Natalia see the people outside?'''
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In the corpus, \textsc{np} \textsc{2sg} \isi{noun} phrases typically take the subject slot in clause-initial position, as in (\ref{Example_6.57}) to (\ref{Example_6.61}). There are a few exceptions, however: in (\ref{Example_6.62}) \textitbf{babi ko} ‘you pig’ occurs as an exclamation in clause-final position; in (\ref{Example_6.64}) \textitbf{kaka ko} ‘you older sibling’ denotes the possessor in an \isi{adnominal possessive construction} which, in turn, takes the clausal object slot; and in (\ref{Example_6.65}) \textitbf{pace ko} ‘you man’ expresses the possessor in an \isi{adnominal possessive construction} which, in turn, takes the complement slot in a \isi{prepositional phrase}. The referent can be encoded with a common \isi{noun} as in (\ref{Example_6.62}), a \isi{proper noun} as in (\ref{Example_6.67}), or a \isi{noun} phrase with an adnominal modifier as in (\ref{Example_6.63}). The referent is typically human; it can, however, also be inanimate such as \textitbf{anging} ‘wind’ in (\ref{Example_6.60}).
A: word: natalia	 gloss: Natalia
B: word: natal	 gloss: Christmas
C: word: martina	 gloss: Martina
D: word: babi	 gloss: pig
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 404:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Question 405:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In the corpus, \textsc{np} \textsc{2sg} \isi{noun} phrases typically take the subject slot in clause-initial position, as in (\ref{Example_6.57}) to (\ref{Example_6.61}). There are a few exceptions, however: in (\ref{Example_6.62}) \textitbf{babi the morpheme ___} ‘you pig’ occurs as an exclamation in clause-final position; in (\ref{Example_6.64}) \textitbf{kaka the morpheme ___} ‘you older sibling’ denotes the possessor in an \isi{adnominal possessive construction} which, in turn, takes the clausal object slot; and in (\ref{Example_6.65}) \textitbf{pace the morpheme ___} ‘you man’ expresses the possessor in an \isi{adnominal possessive construction} which, in turn, takes the complement slot in a \isi{prepositional phrase}. The referent can be encoded with a common \isi{noun} as in (\ref{Example_6.62}), a \isi{proper noun} as in (\ref{Example_6.67}), or a \isi{noun} phrase with an adnominal modifier as in (\ref{Example_6.63}). The referent is typically human; it can, however, also be inanimate such as \textitbf{anging} ‘wind’ in (\ref{Example_6.60}).
A: word: ko	 gloss: 2SG
B: word: skola	 gloss: go.to.school
C: word: besar~besar	 gloss: RDP~be.big
D: word: wili	 gloss: Wili
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 419:

Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In the corpus, \textsc{np} \textsc{2sg} \isi{noun} phrases typically take the subject slot in clause-initial position, as in (\ref{Example_6.57}) to (\ref{Example_6.61}). There are a few exceptions, however: in (\ref{Example_6.62}) \textitbf{babi the morpheme ___} ‘you pig’ occurs as an exclamation in clause-final position; in (\ref{Example_6.64}) \textitbf{kaka the morpheme ___} ‘you older sibling’ denotes the possessor in an \isi{adnominal possessive construction} which, in turn, takes the clausal object slot; and in (\ref{Example_6.65}) \textitbf{pace the morpheme ___} ‘you man’ expresses the possessor in an \isi{adnominal possessive construction} which, in turn, takes the complement slot in a \isi{prepositional phrase}. The referent can be encoded with a common \isi{noun} as in (\ref{Example_6.62}), a \isi{proper noun} as in (\ref{Example_6.67}), or a \isi{noun} phrase with an adnominal modifier as in (\ref{Example_6.63}). The referent is typically human; it can, however, also be inanimate such as \textitbf{anging} ‘wind’ in (\ref{Example_6.60}).
A: word: ko	 gloss: 2SG
B: word: skola	 gloss: go.to.school
C: word: ulang-taung	 gloss: birthday
D: word: kamu	 gloss: 2PL
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 420:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): de bilang, ___ ko bisa liat orang di luar?
Gloss (with missing item): 3SG say ___ 2SG be.able see person at outside
The English translation of this sentence is:[About hospitality:] ‘[(my father said to me,) ``if you close the door, can you see the people outside?'',] he said, ``can you Natalia see the people outside?'''
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The utterances in (\ref{Example_6.57}) to (\ref{Example_6.61}) and (\ref{Example_6.64}) to (\ref{Example_6.68}) also show that \textitbf{ko} ‘\textsc{2sg}’ is freely used as a determiner; that is, its uses are not limited to exclamations, such as \textitbf{babi (puti) ko} ‘you (white) pig’ in (\ref{Example_6.62}) and (\ref{Example_6.63}).
A: word: natalia	 gloss: Natalia
B: word: natal	 gloss: Christmas
C: word: martina	 gloss: Martina
D: word: babi	 gloss: pig
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 435:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): Wili ko jangang {gara\Tildegara} ___ dia itu]!
Gloss (with missing item): Wili 2SG NEG.IMP RDP\Tildeirritate ___ 3SG D.DIST
The English translation of this sentence is:‘you Wili don’t irritate that aunt!’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In the situational uses of adnominal pronouns, “the physical situation in which the speaker and hearer are located contributes to the familiarity of the referent of the \isi{definite} \isi{noun} phrase” \citep[4]{Lyons.1999}. This cross-linguistic observation also applies to the situational uses of adnominally used \textitbf{dia}/\textitbf{de} ‘\textsc{3sg}’, as illustrated in (\ref{Example_6.69}) to (\ref{Example_6.71}).
A: word: tanta	 gloss: aunt
B: word: mantang	 gloss: former
C: word: nene	 gloss: grandmother
D: word: susana	 gloss: Susana
Please only return the letter (A–D).

You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): Wili ko jangang {gara\Tildegara} ___ dia itu]!
Gloss (with missing item): Wili 2SG NEG.IMP RDP\Tildeirritate ___ 3SG D.DIST
The English translation of this sentence is:‘you Wili don’t irritate that aunt!’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In (\ref{Example_6.69}), the situation is an obvious one: the hearer \textitbf{Wili} has been irritating his \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ and is told to stop doing this. In (\ref{Example_6.70}), the speaker illustrates local bride-price customs with an example. The determiner \textitbf{de} ‘\textsc{3sg}’ marks the familiarity of the referent \textitbf{bapa} ‘father’. This in turn leads the interlocutor to interpret \textitbf{bapa} ‘father’ as the speaker’s husband. In (\ref{Example_6.71}), the interlocutors discuss motorbike problems. Suddenly, the speaker quotes what \textitbf{Dodo de} ‘Dodo’ (literally ‘he Dodo’) had said. \textitbf{Dodo} had not been mentioned earlier and was not present at this conversation. Determiner \textitbf{de} ‘\textsc{3sg}’, however, signals to the hearers that they are familiar with the referent which, in turn, leads them to interpret the referent as the speaker’s older brother \textitbf{Dodo}.
A: word: tanta	 gloss: aunt
B: word: mantang	 gloss: former
C: word: nene	 gloss: grandmother
D: word: ana	 gloss: child
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 441:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): Wili ko jangang {gara\Tildegara} [tanta ___ itu]!
Gloss (with missing item): Wili 2SG NEG.IMP RDP\Tildeirritate aunt ___ D.DIST
The English translation of this sentence is:‘you Wili don’t irritate that aunt!’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In (\ref{Example_6.69}), the situation is an obvious one: the hearer \textitbf{Wili} has been irritating his \textitbf{tanta} ‘aunt’ and is told to stop doing this. In (\ref{Example_6.70}), the speaker illustrates local bride-price customs with an example. The determiner \textitbf{de} ‘\textsc{3sg}’ marks the familiarity of the referent \textitbf{bapa} ‘father’. This in turn leads the interlocutor to interpret \textitbf{bapa} ‘father’ as the speaker’s husband. In (\ref{Example_6.71}), the interlocutors discuss motorbike problems. Suddenly, the speaker quotes what \textitbf{Dodo de} ‘Dodo’ (literally ‘he Dodo’) had said. \textitbf{Dodo} had not been mentioned earlier and was not present at this conversation. Determiner \textitbf{de} ‘\textsc{3sg}’, however, signals to the hearers that they are familiar with the referent which, in turn, leads them to interpret the referent as the speaker’s older brother \textitbf{Dodo}.
A: word: dia	 gloss: 3SG
B: word: diai	 gloss: 3SG
C: word: dei	 gloss: 3sg
D: word: prempuang	 gloss: 10pt
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 442:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): Wili ko jangang {gara\Tildegara} [tanta dia ___
Gloss (with missing item): Wili 2SG NEG.IMP RDP\Tildeirritate aunt 3SG ___
The English translation of this sentence is:‘you Wili don’t irritate that aunt!’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In (\ref{Example_6.69}), the sthe morpheme ___ation is an obvious one: the hearer \textitbf{Wili} has been irritating his \textitbf{tanta} ‘aunt’ and is told to stop doing this. In (\ref{Example_6.70}), the speaker illustrates local bride-price customs with an example. The determiner \textitbf{de} ‘\textsc{3sg}’ marks the familiarity of the referent \textitbf{bapa} ‘father’. This in turn leads the interlocutor to interpret \textitbf{bapa} ‘father’ as the speaker’s husband. In (\ref{Example_6.71}), the interlocutors discuss motorbike problems. Suddenly, the speaker quotes what \textitbf{Dodo de} ‘Dodo’ (literally ‘he Dodo’) had said. \textitbf{Dodo} had not been mentioned earlier and was not present at this conversation. Determiner \textitbf{de} ‘\textsc{3sg}’, however, signals to the hearers that they are familiar with the referent which, in turn, leads them to interpret the referent as the speaker’s older brother \textitbf{Dodo}.
A: word: itu	 gloss: D.DIST
B: word: situ	 gloss: L.MED
C: word: sana	 gloss: L.DIST
D: word: deng	 gloss: with
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 443:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ___ de] bilang, adu coba ko kas taw sa
Gloss (with missing item): ___ 3SG say oh.no! if.only 2SG give know 1SG
The English translation of this sentence is:‘Dodo said, ``oh no, if only you had let me know'''
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In (\ref{Example_6.69}), the situation is an obvious one: the hearer \textitbf{Wili} has been irritating his \textitbf{tanta} ‘aunt’ and is told to stop doing this. In (\ref{Example_6.70}), the speaker illustrates local bride-price customs with an example. The determiner \textitbf{de} ‘\textsc{3sg}’ marks the familiarity of the referent \textitbf{bapa} ‘father’. This in turn leads the interlocutor to interpret \textitbf{bapa} ‘father’ as the speaker’s husband. In (\ref{Example_6.71}), the interlocutors discuss motorbike problems. Suddenly, the speaker quotes what \textitbf{its gloss ___ de} ‘its gloss ___’ (literally ‘he its gloss ___’) had said. \textitbf{its gloss ___} had not been mentioned earlier and was not present at this conversation. Determiner \textitbf{de} ‘\textsc{3sg}’, however, signals to the hearers that they are familiar with the referent which, in turn, leads them to interpret the referent as the speaker’s older brother \textitbf{its gloss ___}.
A: word: dodo	 gloss: Dodo
B: word: bodo	 gloss: be.stupid
C: word: mateus	 gloss: Mateus
D: word: bangsat	 gloss: rascal
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 444:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): [Dodo ___ bilang, adu coba ko kas taw sa
Gloss (with missing item): Dodo ___ say oh.no! if.only 2SG give know 1SG
The English translation of this sentence is:‘Dodo said, ``oh no, if only you had let me know'''
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In (\ref{Example_6.69}), the situation is an obvious one: the hearer \textitbf{Wili} has been irritating his \textitbf{tanta} ‘aunt’ and is told to stop doing this. In (\ref{Example_6.70}), the speaker illustrates local brithe morpheme ___-price customs with an example. The the morpheme ___terminer \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘\textsc{3sg}’ marks the familiarity of the referent \textitbf{bapa} ‘father’. This in turn leads the interlocutor to interpret \textitbf{bapa} ‘father’ as the speaker’s husband. In (\ref{Example_6.71}), the interlocutors discuss motorbike problems. Sudthe morpheme ___nly, the speaker quotes what \textitbf{Dodo the morpheme ___} ‘Dodo’ (literally ‘he Dodo’) had said. \textitbf{Dodo} had not been mentioned earlier and was not present at this conversation. Determiner \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘\textsc{3sg}’, however, signals to the hearers that they are familiar with the referent which, in turn, leads them to interpret the referent as the speaker’s olthe morpheme ___r brother \textitbf{Dodo}.
A: word: de	 gloss: 3SG
B: word: deng	 gloss: with
C: word: dei	 gloss: 3sg
D: word: rahab	 gloss: Rahab
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 445:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ... {pas} ketemu {deng} sa {pu} ___ nene, trus kaka {laki\Tildelaki,} mama-tua pu ana
Gloss (with missing item): ... precisely meet with 1SG POSS ___ grandmother next oSb {RDP\Tildehusband} aunt POSS child
The English translation of this sentence is:‘[I passed by (and) reached the village market there, I was sitting, standing there,] right then (I) met my grandmother, grandmother and then (my) older brother, aunt’s child’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In Papuan Malay, when introducing new protagonists, speakers typically introduce these individuals or entities with bare common or proper nouns. At their next mention, these non-speech-act participants are encoded with \textsc{np} \textsc{3sg} \isi{noun} phrases, with the third person \isi{pronoun} marking the referents as \isi{definite}. This, in turn, signals to the hearers that they are assumed to be familiar with the referents. This strategy is illustrated with the two narrative extracts in (\ref{Example_6.72}) and (\ref{Example_6.73}).\footnote{Introducing new characters with a bare \isi{noun} and subsequently marking them as familiar with the adnominally used third person \isi{pronoun} as a potential discourse strategy in Papuan Malay was brought to the author’s attention by A. van Engelenhoven (p.c. 2013).}
A: word: nene	 gloss: grandmother
B: word: beneraf	 gloss: Beneraf
C: word: tanta	 gloss: aunt
D: word: mama-tua	 gloss: aunt
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 446:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ... {pas} ketemu {deng} sa {pu} {nene,} ___ trus kaka {laki\Tildelaki,} mama-tua pu ana
Gloss (with missing item): ... precisely meet with 1SG POSS grandmother ___ next oSb {RDP\Tildehusband} aunt POSS child
The English translation of this sentence is:‘[I passed by (and) reached the village market there, I was sitting, standing there,] right then (I) met my grandmother, grandmother and then (my) older brother, aunt’s child’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In Papuan Malay, when introducing new protagonists, speakers typically introduce these individuals or entities with bare common or proper nouns. At their next mention, these non-speech-act participants are encoded with \textsc{np} \textsc{3sg} \isi{noun} phrases, with the third person \isi{pronoun} marking the referents as \isi{definite}. This, in turn, signals to the hearers that they are assumed to be familiar with the referents. This strategy is illustrated with the two narrative extracts in (\ref{Example_6.72}) and (\ref{Example_6.73}).\footnote{Introducing new characters with a bare \isi{noun} and subsequently marking them as familiar with the adnominally used third person \isi{pronoun} as a potential discourse strategy in Papuan Malay was brought to the author’s attention by A. van Engelenhoven (p.c. 2013).}
A: word: nene	 gloss: grandmother
B: word: beneraf	 gloss: Beneraf
C: word: tanta	 gloss: aunt
D: word: cantik	 gloss: be.beautiful
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 447:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): baru {de} {{luda\Tildeluda}} keee, ... ___ {yang} liat, {Rahab} de {jemur\Tildejemur} pakeang begini baru de perhatikang, ...
Gloss (with missing item): and.then 3SG {RDP\Tildespit} spoot! ... ___ REL see Rahab 3SG {RDP\Tildebe.dry} clothes like.this and.then 3SG observe ...
The English translation of this sentence is:[About a bad-mannered intruder:] ‘and then he was spitting ``spoot!'' ... (it was) Rahab who saw (it), Rahab was drying clothes at that moment, then she noticed ...’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In Papuan Malay, when introducing new protagonists, speakers typically introduce these individuals or entities with bare common or proper nouns. At their next mention, these non-speech-act participants are encoded with \textsc{np} \textsc{3sg} \isi{noun} phrases, with the third person \isi{pronoun} marking the referents as \isi{definite}. This, in turn, signals to the hearers that they are assumed to be familiar with the referents. This strategy is illustrated with the two narrative extracts in (\ref{Example_6.72}) and (\ref{Example_6.73}).\footnote{Introducing new characters with a bare \isi{noun} and subsequently marking them as familiar with the adnominally used third person \isi{pronoun} as a potential discourse strategy in Papuan Malay was brought to the author’s attention by A. van Engelenhoven (p.c. 2013).}
A: word: rahab	 gloss: Rahab
B: word: istirahat	 gloss: rest
C: word: musa	 gloss: Musa
D: word: herman	 gloss: Herman
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 448:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Question 451:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ... {pas} ketemu {deng} sa {pu} ___ nene, trus kaka {laki\Tildelaki,} mama-tua pu ana
Gloss (with missing item): ... precisely meet with 1SG POSS ___ grandmother next oSb {RDP\Tildehusband} aunt POSS child
The English translation of this sentence is:‘[I passed by (and) reached the village market there, I was sitting, standing there,] right then (I) met my grandmother, grandmother and then (my) older brother, aunt’s child’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The utterances in (\ref{Example_6.72}) are part of a narrative about some bad news that the speaker received from his its gloss ___. The speaker introduces his its gloss ___ as a new protagonist with the bare \isi{kinship term} \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’. This introduction involves two mentions of \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’; the \isi{repetition} gives the speaker time to reflect who it was that had been accompanying his its gloss ___ when they met. Following this introduction, the speaker employs the \textsc{np} \textsc{3sg} \isi{noun} phrase \textitbf{the morpheme ___ de} ‘its gloss ___’ (literally ‘she its gloss ___’), which marks the new character as given and familiar.
A: word: nene	 gloss: grandmother
B: word: beneraf	 gloss: Beneraf
C: word: tanta	 gloss: aunt
D: word: wili	 gloss: Wili
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 452:

Question 453:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): baru {de} {{luda\Tildeluda}} keee, ... ___ {yang} liat, {Rahab} de {jemur\Tildejemur} pakeang begini baru de perhatikang, ...
Gloss (with missing item): and.then 3SG {RDP\Tildespit} spoot! ... ___ REL see Rahab 3SG {RDP\Tildebe.dry} clothes like.this and.then 3SG observe ...
The English translation of this sentence is:[About a bad-mannered intruder:] ‘and then he was spitting ``spoot!'' ... (it was) Rahab who saw (it), Rahab was drying clothes at that moment, then she noticed ...’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The utterance in (\ref{Example_6.73}) occurred during a narrative about a bad-mannered intruder and a young woman named \textitbf{its gloss ___} who observed this person’s behavior. Employing a bare \isi{proper noun}, the speaker introduces \textitbf{its gloss ___} as a new character on the scene. At her next mention, this new protagonist is encoded by the \textsc{np} \textsc{3sg} \isi{noun} phrase \textitbf{its gloss ___ de} ‘its gloss ___’ (literally ‘she its gloss ___’), which marks this non-speech-act participant as given and familiar. In the following, the speaker refers to \textitbf{its gloss ___} with the bare third person \isi{pronoun} \textitbf{de} ‘\textsc{3sg}’.
A: word: rahab	 gloss: Rahab
B: word: istirahat	 gloss: rest
C: word: musa	 gloss: Musa
D: word: kaka	 gloss: oSb
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 455:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): baru {de} {{luda\Tildeluda}} keee, ... {Rahab} {yang} liat, {Rahab} ___ {jemur\Tildejemur} pakeang begini baru de perhatikang, ...
Gloss (with missing item): and.then 3SG {RDP\Tildespit} spoot! ... Rahab REL see Rahab ___ {RDP\Tildebe.dry} clothes like.this and.then 3SG observe ...
The English translation of this sentence is:[About a bad-mannered intruder:] ‘and then he was spitting ``spoot!'' ... (it was) Rahab who saw (it), Rahab was drying clothes at that moment, then she noticed ...’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The utterance in (\ref{Example_6.73}) occurred during a narrative about a bad-mannered intruthe morpheme ___r and a young woman named \textitbf{Rahab} who observed this person’s behavior. Employing a bare \isi{proper noun}, the speaker introduces \textitbf{Rahab} as a new character on the scene. At her next mention, this new protagonist is encothe morpheme ___d by the \textsc{np} \textsc{3sg} \isi{noun} phrase \textitbf{Rahab the morpheme ___} ‘Rahab’ (literally ‘she Rahab’), which marks this non-speech-act participant as given and familiar. In the following, the speaker refers to \textitbf{Rahab} with the bare third person \isi{pronoun} \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘\textsc{3sg}’.
A: word: de	 gloss: 3SG
B: word: deng	 gloss: with
C: word: dei	 gloss: 3sg
D: word: martin	 gloss: Martin
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 456:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. The English translation of this sentence is:[About a bad-mannered intruder:] ‘and then he was spitting ``spoot!'' ... (it was) Rahab who saw (it), Rahab was drying clothes at that moment, then she noticed ...’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The utterance in (\ref{Example_6.73}) occurred during a narrative about a bad-mannered intruthe morpheme ___r and a young woman named \textitbf{Rahab} who observed this person’s behavior. Employing a bare \isi{proper noun}, the speaker introduces \textitbf{Rahab} as a new character on the scene. At her next mention, this new protagonist is encothe morpheme ___d by the \textsc{np} \textsc{3sg} \isi{noun} phrase \textitbf{Rahab the morpheme ___} ‘Rahab’ (literally ‘she Rahab’), which marks this non-speech-act participant as given and familiar. In the following, the speaker refers to \textitbf{Rahab} with the bare third person \isi{pronoun} \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘\textsc{3sg}’.
