Question 457:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): baru {de} {{luda\Tildeluda}} keee, ... ___ {yang} liat, {Rahab} de {jemur\Tildejemur} pakeang begini baru de perhatikang, ...
Gloss (with missing item): and.then 3SG {RDP\Tildespit} spoot! ... ___ REL see Rahab 3SG {RDP\Tildebe.dry} clothes like.this and.then 3SG observe ...
The English translation of this sentence is:[About a bad-mannered intruder:] ‘and then he was spitting ``spoot!'' ... (it was) Rahab who saw (it), Rahab was drying clothes at that moment, then she noticed ...’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: \textsc{np} \textsc{3sg} \isi{noun} phrases in the corpus typically take the subject slot in clause-initial position, as in (\ref{Example_6.70}) to (\ref{Example_6.73}). Other slots, however, are also possible, such as the direct object slot in (\ref{Example_6.69}), or the possessor slot in (\ref{Example_6.74}). The referent can be expressed with common nouns as in (\ref{Example_6.72}), proper nouns as in (\ref{Example_6.73}), or \isi{noun} phrases with adnominal modifiers, as in (\ref{Example_6.74}). Further, determiner \textitbf{dia}/\textitbf{de} ‘\textsc{3sg}’ also occurs in complex \isi{noun} phrases, as in \textitbf{bapa dari Jepang dia} ‘the man from Japan’ (literally ‘he man from Japan’) in (\ref{Example_6.75}), or \textitbf{kaka pendeta di Mambramo de tu} ‘that older pastor sibling in the Mambramo area’ (literally ‘that he older pastor in the Mambramo area’) in (\ref{Example_6.76}). The referents in \textsc{np} \textsc{3sg} \isi{noun} phrases are usually human, but they can also be animate nonhuman such as \textitbf{kaswari} ‘cassowary’ in (\ref{Example_6.77}), or inanimate such as \textitbf{bua mangga} ‘mango fruit’ in (\ref{Example_6.78}).
A: word: rahab	 gloss: Rahab
B: word: istirahat	 gloss: rest
C: word: musa	 gloss: Musa
D: word: miflal	 gloss: Miflal
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 464:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Question 467:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ... {pas} ketemu {deng} sa {pu} {nene,} ___ trus kaka {laki\Tildelaki,} mama-tua pu ana
Gloss (with missing item): ... precisely meet with 1SG POSS grandmother ___ next oSb {RDP\Tildehusband} aunt POSS child
The English translation of this sentence is:‘[I passed by (and) reached the village market there, I was sitting, standing there,] right then (I) met my grandmother, grandmother and then (my) older brother, aunt’s child’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: \textsc{np} \textsc{3sg} \isi{noun} phrases in the corpus typically take the subject slot in clause-initial position, as in (\ref{Example_6.70}) to (\ref{Example_6.73}). Other slots, however, are also possible, such as the direct object slot in (\ref{Example_6.69}), or the possessor slot in (\ref{Example_6.74}). The referent can be expressed with common nouns as in (\ref{Example_6.72}), proper nouns as in (\ref{Example_6.73}), or \isi{noun} phrases with adnominal modifiers, as in (\ref{Example_6.74}). Further, determiner \textitbf{dia}/\textitbf{de} ‘\textsc{3sg}’ also occurs in complex \isi{noun} phrases, as in \textitbf{bapa dari Jepang dia} ‘the man from Japan’ (literally ‘he man from Japan’) in (\ref{Example_6.75}), or \textitbf{kaka pendeta di Mambramo de tu} ‘that older pastor sibling in the Mambramo area’ (literally ‘that he older pastor in the Mambramo area’) in (\ref{Example_6.76}). The referents in \textsc{np} \textsc{3sg} \isi{noun} phrases are usually human, but they can also be animate nonhuman such as \textitbf{kaswari} ‘cassowary’ in (\ref{Example_6.77}), or inanimate such as \textitbf{bua mangga} ‘mango fruit’ in (\ref{Example_6.78}).
A: word: nene	 gloss: grandmother
B: word: beneraf	 gloss: Beneraf
C: word: tanta	 gloss: aunt
D: word: barce	 gloss: Barce
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 468:

Question 474:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: \textsc{np} \textsc{3sg} \isi{noun} phrases in the corpus typically take the subject slot in clause-initial position, as in (\ref{Example_6.70}) to (\ref{Example_6.73}). Other slots, however, are also possible, such as the direct object slot in (\ref{Example_6.69}), or the possessor slot in (\ref{Example_6.74}). The referent can be expressed with common nouns as in (\ref{Example_6.72}), proper nouns as in (\ref{Example_6.73}), or \isi{noun} phrases with adnominal modifiers, as in (\ref{Example_6.74}). Further, determiner \textitbf{dia}/\textitbf{de} ‘\textsc{3sg}’ also occurs in complex \isi{noun} phrases, as in \textitbf{the morpheme ___ dari Jepang dia} ‘the man from Japan’ (literally ‘he man from Japan’) in (\ref{Example_6.75}), or \textitbf{kaka pendeta di Mambramo de tu} ‘that older pastor sibling in the Mambramo area’ (literally ‘that he older pastor in the Mambramo area’) in (\ref{Example_6.76}). The referents in \textsc{np} \textsc{3sg} \isi{noun} phrases are usually human, but they can also be animate nonhuman such as \textitbf{kaswari} ‘cassowary’ in (\ref{Example_6.77}), or inanimate such as \textitbf{bua mangga} ‘mango fruit’ in (\ref{Example_6.78}).

Further, determiner \textitbf{dia}/\textitbf{de} ‘\textsc{3sg}’ also occurs in complex \isi{noun} phrases, as in \textitbf{bapa the morpheme ___ Jepang dia} ‘the man its gloss ___ Japan’ (literally ‘he man its gloss ___ Japan’) in (\ref{Example_6.75}), or \textitbf{kaka pendeta di Mambramo de tu} ‘that older pastor sibling in the Mambramo area’ (literally ‘that he older pastor in the Mambramo area’) in (\ref{Example_6.76}). Question 478:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: \textsc{np} \textsc{3sg} \isi{noun} phrases in the corpus typically take the subject slot in clause-initial position, as in (\ref{Example_6.70}) to (\ref{Example_6.73}). Further, determiner \textitbf{dia}/\textitbf{de} ‘\textsc{3sg}’ also occurs in complex \isi{noun} phrases, as in \textitbf{bapa dari Jepang dia} ‘the man from Japan’ (literally ‘he man from Japan’) in (\ref{Example_6.75}), or \textitbf{the morpheme ___ pendeta di Mambramo de tu} ‘that older pastor sibling in the Mambramo area’ (literally ‘that he older pastor in the Mambramo area’) in (\ref{Example_6.76}). The referents in \textsc{np} \textsc{3sg} \isi{noun} phrases are usually human, but they can also be animate nonhuman such as \textitbf{kaswari} ‘cassowary’ in (\ref{Example_6.77}), or inanimate such as \textitbf{bua mangga} ‘mango fruit’ in (\ref{Example_6.78}).
A: word: kaka	 gloss: oSb
B: word: br–ade-kaka	 gloss: VBLZ–siblings
C: word: komputer	 gloss: computer
D: word: mace	 gloss: woman
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 479:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): kaka ___ di Mambramo de tu jual RW
Gloss (with missing item): oSb ___ at Mambramo 3SG D.DIST sell cooked.dog.meat
The English translation of this sentence is:‘that older sibling pastor in (the) Mambramo (area) sells cooked dog meat’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: \textsc{np} \textsc{3sg} \isi{noun} phrases in the corpus typically take the subject slot in clause-initial position, as in (\ref{Example_6.70}) to (\ref{Example_6.73}). Other slots, however, are also possible, such as the direct object slot in (\ref{Example_6.69}), or the possessor slot in (\ref{Example_6.74}). The referent can be expressed with common nouns as in (\ref{Example_6.72}), proper nouns as in (\ref{Example_6.73}), or \isi{noun} phrases with adnominal modifiers, as in (\ref{Example_6.74}). Further, determiner \textitbf{dia}/\textitbf{de} ‘\textsc{3sg}’ also occurs in complex \isi{noun} phrases, as in \textitbf{bapa dari Jepang dia} ‘the man from Japan’ (literally ‘he man from Japan’) in (\ref{Example_6.75}), or \textitbf{kaka the morpheme ___ di Mambramo de tu} ‘that older its gloss ___ sibling in the Mambramo area’ (literally ‘that he older its gloss ___ in the Mambramo area’) in (\ref{Example_6.76}). The referents in \textsc{np} \textsc{3sg} \isi{noun} phrases are usually human, but they can also be animate nonhuman such as \textitbf{kaswari} ‘cassowary’ in (\ref{Example_6.77}), or inanimate such as \textitbf{bua mangga} ‘mango fruit’ in (\ref{Example_6.78}).
A: word: pendeta	 gloss: pastor
B: word: kalender	 gloss: calendar
C: word: injil	 gloss: Gospel
D: word: ise	 gloss: Ise
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Other slots, however, are also possible, such as the the morpheme ___rect object slot in (\ref{Example_6.69}), or the possessor slot in (\ref{Example_6.74}). The referent can be expressed with common nouns as in (\ref{Example_6.72}), proper nouns as in (\ref{Example_6.73}), or \isi{noun} phrases with adnominal mothe morpheme ___fiers, as in (\ref{Example_6.74}). Question 484:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. The English translation of this sentence is:‘and then Martina asked me, ``mother, how do you feel?''
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The corpus also contains \textsc{np} \textsc{pro-sg} expressions in which the nouns are set off from the following pronouns by a \isi{comma intonation} (“{\textbar}”), as in (\ref{Example_6.79}) to (\ref{Example_6.82}).

B: word: mama-ade	 gloss: aunt
C: word: orang-tua	 gloss: parent

Question 487:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): trus Martina de tanya saya, ___ ... \textbar ... ko rasa bagemana?
Gloss (with missing item): next Martina 3SG ask 1SG ___ ... ... ... 2SG feel how
The English translation of this sentence is:‘and then Martina asked me, ``mother, how do you feel?''
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In \textsc{np} \textsc{pro-sg} expressions with second person \textitbf{ko} ‘\textsc{2sg}’, the marked-off nouns function as vocatives, that is, as forms of direct address, such that ``\textsc{voc} \textsc{pro}''. Cross-linguistically, \textsc{voc} \textsc{pro} expressions serve to specify “a person out of a group of persons while using a second person singular \isi{pronoun}” with the vocative \isi{noun} being “separated from the rest of the sentence by intonation” \citep[46]{Bhat.2007}. This strategy of singling out and addressing particular individuals through a \textsc{voc} \textsc{pro} expression is shown in (\ref{Example_6.79}) and (\ref{Example_6.80}), respectively: \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ and \textitbf{Ise} are vocatives which are set off from second person \textitbf{ko} ‘2\textsc{sg}’ with a distinct \isi{comma intonation} (“{\textbar}”). Hence, these expressions cannot be interpreted as \textsc{np} \textsc{2sg} \isi{noun} phrases.
A: word: mama	 gloss: mother
B: word: mama-ade	 gloss: aunt
C: word: orang-tua	 gloss: parent
D: word: brapa	 gloss: several
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 488:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In \textsc{np} \textsc{pro-sg} expressions with second person \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘\textsc{2sg}’, the marked-off nouns function as vocatives, that is, as forms of direct address, such that ``\textsc{voc} \textsc{pro}''. Cross-linguistically, \textsc{voc} \textsc{pro} expressions serve to specify “a person out of a group of persons while using a second person singular \isi{pronoun}” with the vocative \isi{noun} being “separated from the rest of the sentence by intonation” \citep[46]{Bhat.2007}. This strategy of singling out and addressing particular individuals through a \textsc{voc} \textsc{pro} expression is shown in (\ref{Example_6.79}) and (\ref{Example_6.80}), respectively: \textitbf{mama} ‘mother’ and \textitbf{Ise} are vocatives which are set off from second person \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘2\textsc{sg}’ with a distinct \isi{comma intonation} (“{\textbar}”). Hence, these expressions cannot be interpreted as \textsc{np} \textsc{2sg} \isi{noun} phrases.
A: word: ko	 gloss: 2SG

Question 489:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): {jadi} Ise {ni} tong su bilang dia, ___ ... \textbar ... ko tinggal di sini suda!
Gloss (with missing item): so Ise D.PROX 1PL already say 3SG ___ ... ... ... 2SG stay at L.PROX already
The English translation of this sentence is:‘so Ise here, we already told her, ``Ise, you stay here!'''
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In \textsc{np} \textsc{pro-sg} expressions with second person \textitbf{ko} ‘\textsc{2sg}’, the marked-off nouns function as vocatives, that is, as forms of direct address, such that ``\textsc{voc} \textsc{pro}''. Cross-linguistically, \textsc{voc} \textsc{pro} expressions serve to specify “a person out of a group of persons while using a second person singular \isi{pronoun}” with the vocative \isi{noun} being “separated from the rest of the sentence by intonation” \citep[46]{Bhat.2007}. This strategy of singling out and addressing particular individuals through a \textsc{voc} \textsc{pro} expression is shown in (\ref{Example_6.79}) and (\ref{Example_6.80}), respectively: \textitbf{mama} ‘mother’ and \textitbf{its gloss ___} are vocatives which are set off from second person \textitbf{ko} ‘2\textsc{sg}’ with a distinct \isi{comma intonation} (“{\textbar}”). Hence, these expressions cannot be interpreted as \textsc{np} \textsc{2sg} \isi{noun} phrases.
A: word: ise	 gloss: Ise
B: word: bisa	 gloss: be.able
C: word: andi	 gloss: Andi
D: word: ipa	 gloss: natural.sciences
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 490:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In \textsc{np} \textsc{pro-sg} expressions with second person \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘\textsc{2sg}’, the marked-off nouns function as vocatives, that is, as forms of direct address, such that ``\textsc{voc} \textsc{pro}''. Cross-linguistically, \textsc{voc} \textsc{pro} expressions serve to specify “a person out of a group of persons while using a second person singular \isi{pronoun}” with the vocative \isi{noun} being “separated from the rest of the sentence by intonation” \citep[46]{Bhat.2007}. This strategy of singling out and addressing particular individuals through a \textsc{voc} \textsc{pro} expression is shown in (\ref{Example_6.79}) and (\ref{Example_6.80}), respectively: \textitbf{mama} ‘mother’ and \textitbf{Ise} are vocatives which are set off from second person \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘2\textsc{sg}’ with a distinct \isi{comma intonation} (“{\textbar}”). Hence, these expressions cannot be interpreted as \textsc{np} \textsc{2sg} \isi{noun} phrases.

Question 491:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): {baru} dia {datang,} {orang} {Jayapura} sana, kawang itu, ___ Senggi ... \textbar ... dia datang de duduk
Gloss (with missing item): and.then 3SG come person Jayapura L.DIST friend D.DIST ___ Senggi ... ... ... 3SG come 3SG sit
The English translation of this sentence is:[Talking about a friend:] ‘and then she came, (the) person (from) Jayapura over there, that friend, (the) person (from) Senggi, she came (and) she sat (down)’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: \textsc{np} \textsc{3sg} expressions with a \isi{comma intonation} are analyzed as topic-comment constructions. Cross-linguistically, in topic-comment constructions, the “topic is generally expected to continue” and therefore “third its gloss ___ pronouns [{\ldots}] are used in order to represent the continued occurrence of a topic” \citep[209]{Bhat.2007}. This observation also applies to Papuan Malay \textsc{np} {\textbar} \textsc{3sg} expressions, that is, the preposed \isi{noun} phrase signals the topic, while coreferential \textitbf{dia}/\textitbf{de} ‘\textsc{3sg}’ has comment function. This strategy of forming topic-comment constructions is shown in (\ref{Example_6.81}) and (\ref{Example_6.82}): \textitbf{the morpheme ___ Senggi} and \textitbf{Klara} designate the topics while \textitbf{dia} ‘\textsc{3sg}’ and \textitbf{de} ‘\textsc{3sg}’ function as comments, respectively.
A: word: orang	 gloss: person
B: word: dorang	 gloss: 3PL
C: word: manusia	 gloss: human.being
D: word: saya	 gloss: 1SG
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 492:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): {baru} dia {datang,} {orang} {Jayapura} sana, kawang itu, orang ___ ... \textbar ... dia datang de duduk
Gloss (with missing item): and.then 3SG come person Jayapura L.DIST friend D.DIST person ___ ... ... ... 3SG come 3SG sit
The English translation of this sentence is:[Talking about a friend:] ‘and then she came, (the) person (from) Jayapura over there, that friend, (the) person (from) Senggi, she came (and) she sat (down)’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: \textsc{np} \textsc{3sg} expressions with a \isi{comma intonation} are analyzed as topic-comment constructions. Cross-linguistically, in topic-comment constructions, the “topic is generally expected to continue” and therefore “third person pronouns [{\ldots}] are used in order to represent the continued occurrence of a topic” \citep[209]{Bhat.2007}. This observation also applies to Papuan Malay \textsc{np} {\textbar} \textsc{3sg} expressions, that is, the preposed \isi{noun} phrase signals the topic, while coreferential \textitbf{dia}/\textitbf{de} ‘\textsc{3sg}’ has comment function. This strategy of forming topic-comment constructions is shown in (\ref{Example_6.81}) and (\ref{Example_6.82}): \textitbf{orang its gloss ___} and \textitbf{Klara} designate the topics while \textitbf{dia} ‘\textsc{3sg}’ and \textitbf{de} ‘\textsc{3sg}’ function as comments, respectively.
A: word: senggi	 gloss: Senggi
B: word: tinggi	 gloss: be.high
C: word: sarmi	 gloss: Sarmi
D: word: itu	 gloss: D.DIST
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 493:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): {baru} dia {datang,} {orang} {Jayapura} sana, kawang itu, orang Senggi ... \textbar ... ___ datang de duduk
Gloss (with missing item): and.then 3SG come person Jayapura L.DIST friend D.DIST person Senggi ... ... ... ___ come 3SG sit
The English translation of this sentence is:[Talking about a friend:] ‘and then she came, (the) person (from) Jayapura over there, that friend, (the) person (from) Senggi, she came (and) she sat (down)’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: \textsc{np} \textsc{3sg} expressions with a \isi{comma intonation} are analyzed as topic-comment constructions. Cross-linguistically, in topic-comment constructions, the “topic is generally expected to continue” and therefore “third person pronouns [{\ldots}] are used in order to represent the continued occurrence of a topic” \citep[209]{Bhat.2007}. This observation also applies to Papuan Malay \textsc{np} {\textbar} \textsc{3sg} expressions, that is, the preposed \isi{noun} phrase signals the topic, while coreferential \textitbf{the morpheme ___}/\textitbf{de} ‘\textsc{3sg}’ has comment function. This strategy of forming topic-comment constructions is shown in (\ref{Example_6.81}) and (\ref{Example_6.82}): \textitbf{orang Senggi} and \textitbf{Klara} designate the topics while \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘\textsc{3sg}’ and \textitbf{de} ‘\textsc{3sg}’ function as comments, respectively.
A: word: dia	 gloss: 3SG
B: word: diai	 gloss: 3SG
C: word: dei	 gloss: 3sg
D: word: pendeta	 gloss: pastor
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 494:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): Klara ... \textbar ... ___ lompat satu kali tu
Gloss (with missing item): Klara ... ... ... ___ jump one time D.DIST
The English translation of this sentence is:‘Klara, she jumped once (EMPH)’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: \textsc{np} \textsc{3sg} expressions with a \isi{comma intonation} are analyzed as topic-comment constructions. Cross-linguistically, in topic-comment constructions, the “topic is generally expected to continue” and therefore “third person pronouns [{\ldots}] are used in orthe morpheme ___r to represent the continued occurrence of a topic” \citep[209]{Bhat.2007}. This observation also applies to Papuan Malay \textsc{np} {\textbar} \textsc{3sg} expressions, that is, the preposed \isi{noun} phrase signals the topic, while coreferential \textitbf{dia}/\textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘\textsc{3sg}’ has comment function. This strategy of forming topic-comment constructions is shown in (\ref{Example_6.81}) and (\ref{Example_6.82}): \textitbf{orang Senggi} and \textitbf{Klara} the morpheme ___signate the topics while \textitbf{dia} ‘\textsc{3sg}’ and \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘\textsc{3sg}’ function as comments, respectively.
A: word: de	 gloss: 3SG
B: word: deng	 gloss: with
C: word: dei	 gloss: 3sg
D: word: prempuang	 gloss: 10pt
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 495:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ___ ko ini ko takut
Gloss (with missing item): ___ 2SG D.PROX 2SG feel.afraid(.of)
The English translation of this sentence is:‘you Barce here, you feel afraid’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Topic-comment constructions with no \isi{comma intonation} are also possible, however. In this type of constructions, the topic is expressed in a \isi{noun} phrase with a \isi{pronoun} determiner and \isi{demonstrative} modifier, such that ``\textsc{n pro-sg dem}''. This is illustrated in (\ref{Example_6.67}), repeated as (\ref{Example_6.83}), and in (\ref{Example_6.68}) in §\ref{Para_6.2.1.1} (p. \pageref{Example_6.68}). Very often, however, the preposed topical \isi{noun} phrase does not contain a \isi{pronoun} determiner, such that ``\textsc{n dem}''. This is demonstrated with the topic-comment constructions \textitbf{ade ini de} ‘this younger sibling, he/she’ in (\ref{Example_6.84}), and \textitbf{Ise ni de} ‘Ise here, she’ in (\ref{Example_6.85}). In [\textsc{n (pro-sg) dem]} \textsc{pro-sg} topic-comment constructions, the \isi{demonstrative} sets aside the topic, and therefore no \isi{comma intonation} is needed.
A: word: barce	 gloss: Barce
B: word: baru	 gloss: and.then
C: word: pante-barat	 gloss: Pante-Barat
D: word: dari	 gloss: from
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 505:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. The English translation of this sentence is:‘and then this younger sibling, he/she is sick’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Topic-comment constructions with no \isi{comma intonation} are also possible, however. In this type of constructions, the topic is expressed in a \isi{noun} phrase with a \isi{pronoun} determiner and \isi{demonstrative} modifier, such that ``\textsc{n pro-sg dem}''. This is illustrated in (\ref{Example_6.67}), repeated as (\ref{Example_6.83}), and in (\ref{Example_6.68}) in §\ref{Para_6.2.1.1} (p. \pageref{Example_6.68}). Very often, however, the preposed topical \isi{noun} phrase does not contain a \isi{pronoun} determiner, such that ``\textsc{n dem}''. This is demonstrated with the topic-comment constructions \textitbf{the morpheme ___ ini de} ‘this younger sibling, he/she’ in (\ref{Example_6.84}), and \textitbf{Ise ni de} ‘Ise here, she’ in (\ref{Example_6.85}). Question 506:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): baru [ade ___ [de] sakit
Gloss (with missing item): and.then ySb ___ 3SG be.sick
The English translation of this sentence is:‘and then this younger sibling, he/she is sick’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Topic-comment constructions with no \isi{comma intonation} are also possible, however. In this type of constructions, the topic is expressed in a \isi{noun} phrase with a \isi{pronoun} determiner and \isi{demonstrative} modifier, such that ``\textsc{n pro-sg dem}''. This is illustrated in (\ref{Example_6.67}), repeated as (\ref{Example_6.83}), and in (\ref{Example_6.68}) in §\ref{Para_6.2.1.1} (p. \pageref{Example_6.68}). Very often, however, the preposed topical \isi{noun} phrase does not contain a \isi{pronoun} determiner, such that ``\textsc{n dem}''. This is demonstrated with the topic-comment constructions \textitbf{ade the morpheme ___ de} ‘this younger sibling, he/she’ in (\ref{Example_6.84}), and \textitbf{Ise ni de} ‘Ise here, she’ in (\ref{Example_6.85}). In [\textsc{n (pro-sg) dem]} \textsc{pro-sg} topic-comment constructions, the \isi{demonstrative} sets aside the topic, and therefore no \isi{comma intonation} is needed.
A: word: ini	 gloss: D.PROX
B: word: begini	 gloss: like.this
C: word: sini	 gloss: L.PROX
D: word: miflal	 gloss: Miflal
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 507:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): baru [ade ini] ___ sakit
Gloss (with missing item): and.then ySb D.PROX ___ be.sick
The English translation of this sentence is:‘and then this younger sibling, he/she is sick’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Topic-comment constructions with no \isi{comma intonation} are also possible, however. In this type of constructions, the topic is expressed in a \isi{noun} phrase with a \isi{pronoun} the morpheme ___terminer and \isi{the morpheme ___monstrative} modifier, such that ``\textsc{n pro-sg the morpheme ___m}''. This is illustrated in (\ref{Example_6.67}), repeated as (\ref{Example_6.83}), and in (\ref{Example_6.68}) in §\ref{Para_6.2.1.1} (p. \pageref{Example_6.68}). Very often, however, the preposed topical \isi{noun} phrase does not contain a \isi{pronoun} the morpheme ___terminer, such that ``\textsc{n the morpheme ___m}''. This is the morpheme ___monstrated with the topic-comment constructions \textitbf{athe morpheme ___ ini the morpheme ___} ‘this younger sibling, he/she’ in (\ref{Example_6.84}), and \textitbf{Ise ni the morpheme ___} ‘Ise here, she’ in (\ref{Example_6.85}). In [\textsc{n (pro-sg) the morpheme ___m]} \textsc{pro-sg} topic-comment constructions, the \isi{the morpheme ___monstrative} sets asithe morpheme ___ the topic, and therefore no \isi{comma intonation} is neethe morpheme ___d.
A: word: de	 gloss: 3SG
B: word: deng	 gloss: with
C: word: dei	 gloss: 3sg
D: word: bapa	 gloss: father
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 508:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ... ___ ni] [de] su mulay takut ini
Gloss (with missing item): ... ___ D.PROX 3SG already start feel.afraid(.of) D.PROX
The English translation of this sentence is:‘[this tree began shaking, shaking like this, and] Ise here, she already started feeling afraid’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Topic-comment constructions with no \isi{comma intonation} are also possible, however. In this type of constructions, the topic is expressed in a \isi{noun} phrase with a \isi{pronoun} determiner and \isi{demonstrative} modifier, such that ``\textsc{n pro-sg dem}''. This is illustrated in (\ref{Example_6.67}), repeated as (\ref{Example_6.83}), and in (\ref{Example_6.68}) in §\ref{Para_6.2.1.1} (p. \pageref{Example_6.68}). Very often, however, the preposed topical \isi{noun} phrase does not contain a \isi{pronoun} determiner, such that ``\textsc{n dem}''. This is demonstrated with the topic-comment constructions \textitbf{ade ini de} ‘this younger sibling, he/she’ in (\ref{Example_6.84}), and \textitbf{its gloss ___ ni de} ‘its gloss ___ here, she’ in (\ref{Example_6.85}). In [\textsc{n (pro-sg) dem]} \textsc{pro-sg} topic-comment constructions, the \isi{demonstrative} sets aside the topic, and therefore no \isi{comma intonation} is needed.
A: word: ise	 gloss: Ise
B: word: bisa	 gloss: be.able
C: word: andi	 gloss: Andi
D: word: ini	 gloss: D.PROX
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 509:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ... [Ise ___ [de] su mulay takut ini
Gloss (with missing item): ... Ise ___ 3SG already start feel.afraid(.of) D.PROX
The English translation of this sentence is:‘[this tree began shaking, shaking like this, and] Ise here, she already started feeling afraid’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Topic-comment constructions with no \isi{comma intonation} are also possible, however. In this type of constructions, the topic is expressed in a \isi{noun} phrase with a \isi{pronoun} determiner and \isi{demonstrative} modifier, such that ``\textsc{n pro-sg dem}''. This is illustrated in (\ref{Example_6.67}), repeated as (\ref{Example_6.83}), and in (\ref{Example_6.68}) in §\ref{Para_6.2.1.1} (p. \pageref{Example_6.68}). Very often, however, the preposed topical \isi{noun} phrase does not contain a \isi{pronoun} determiner, such that ``\textsc{n dem}''. This is demonstrated with the topic-comment constructions \textitbf{ade ithe morpheme ___ de} ‘this younger sibling, he/she’ in (\ref{Example_6.84}), and \textitbf{Ise the morpheme ___ de} ‘Ise here, she’ in (\ref{Example_6.85}). In [\textsc{n (pro-sg) dem]} \textsc{pro-sg} topic-comment constructions, the \isi{demonstrative} sets aside the topic, and therefore no \isi{comma intonation} is needed.
A: word: ni	 gloss: D.PROX
B: word: begini	 gloss: like.this
C: word: sini	 gloss: L.PROX
D: word: agus	 gloss: Agus
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 510:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ... [Ise ni] ___ su mulay takut ini
Gloss (with missing item): ... Ise D.PROX ___ already start feel.afraid(.of) D.PROX
The English translation of this sentence is:‘[this tree began shaking, shaking like this, and] Ise here, she already started feeling afraid’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Topic-comment constructions with no \isi{comma intonation} are also possible, however. In this type of constructions, the topic is expressed in a \isi{noun} phrase with a \isi{pronoun} the morpheme ___terminer and \isi{the morpheme ___monstrative} modifier, such that ``\textsc{n pro-sg the morpheme ___m}''. This is illustrated in (\ref{Example_6.67}), repeated as (\ref{Example_6.83}), and in (\ref{Example_6.68}) in §\ref{Para_6.2.1.1} (p. \pageref{Example_6.68}). Very often, however, the preposed topical \isi{noun} phrase does not contain a \isi{pronoun} the morpheme ___terminer, such that ``\textsc{n the morpheme ___m}''. This is the morpheme ___monstrated with the topic-comment constructions \textitbf{athe morpheme ___ ini the morpheme ___} ‘this younger sibling, he/she’ in (\ref{Example_6.84}), and \textitbf{Ise ni the morpheme ___} ‘Ise here, she’ in (\ref{Example_6.85}). In [\textsc{n (pro-sg) the morpheme ___m]} \textsc{pro-sg} topic-comment constructions, the \isi{the morpheme ___monstrative} sets asithe morpheme ___ the topic, and therefore no \isi{comma intonation} is neethe morpheme ___d.
A: word: de	 gloss: 3SG
B: word: deng	 gloss: with
C: word: dei	 gloss: 3sg
D: word: saya	 gloss: 1SG
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 511:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ___ ko] masak daging sa biking papeda e?
Gloss (with missing item): ___ 2SG cook meat 1SG make sagu.porridge eh
The English translation of this sentence is:‘you aunt cook the meat, I make the sagu porridge, eh?’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: There are four reasons for analyzing the \textsc{np} \textsc{2sg} expressions in (\ref{Example_6.51}) to (\ref{Example_6.68}) and the \textsc{np} \textsc{3sg} constructions in (\ref{Example_6.69}) to (\ref{Example_6.78}) as \isi{noun} phrases with a pronominal determiner and not as topic-comment constructions.
A: word: mama-ade	 gloss: aunt
B: word: mama-tua	 gloss: aunt
C: word: nene	 gloss: grandmother
D: word: pendeta	 gloss: pastor
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 519:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ... dasar bodo ___ ko
Gloss (with missing item): ... base be.stupid ___ 2SG
The English translation of this sentence is:‘[you (SG) here, do you (SG) have ears (or) not,] (you are of course) stupid, you pig’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: First, \textsc{np} \textsc{pro-sg} expressions can occur in positions other than the clause-initial subject slot, as shown with the \textsc{np} \textsc{2sg} \isi{noun} phrases in (\ref{Example_6.62}), (\ref{Example_6.64}), and (\ref{Example_6.65}), and the \textsc{np} \textsc{3sg} \isi{noun} phrases in (\ref{Example_6.69}) and (\ref{Example_6.74}). In these positions, however, the respective common nouns cannot be interpreted as topics in topic-comment constructions. This is due to the fact that topicalized constituents do not remain in-situ but are fronted to the clause-initial position (see also Example (\ref{Example_1.4}) in §\ref{Para_1.6.1.4}, p. \pageref{Example_1.4}).
A: word: babi	 gloss: pig
B: word: rabik	 gloss: tear
C: word: sapi	 gloss: cow
D: word: dia	 gloss: 3SG
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Gloss (with missing item): ... base be.stupid pig ___

In these positions, however, the respective common nouns cannot be interpreted as topics in topic-comment constructions. This is due to the fact that topicalized constituents do not remain in-situ but are fronted to the clause-initial position (see also Example (\ref{Example_1.4}) in §\ref{Para_1.6.1.4}, p. \pageref{Example_1.4}).
A: word: ko	 gloss: 2SG
B: word: skola	 gloss: go.to.school
C: word: bicara	 gloss: speak
D: word: sana	 gloss: L.DIST
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 527:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): Wili ko jangang {gara\Tildegara} [tanta dia ___
Gloss (with missing item): Wili 2SG NEG.IMP RDP\Tildeirritate aunt 3SG ___
The English translation of this sentence is:‘you Wili don’t irritate that aunt!’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: First, \textsc{np} \textsc{pro-sg} expressions can occur in positions other than the clause-initial subject slot, as shown with the \textsc{np} \textsc{2sg} \isi{noun} phrases in (\ref{Example_6.62}), (\ref{Example_6.64}), and (\ref{Example_6.65}), and the \textsc{np} \textsc{3sg} \isi{noun} phrases in (\ref{Example_6.69}) and (\ref{Example_6.74}). In these positions, however, the respective common nouns cannot be interpreted as topics in topic-comment constructions. This is due to the fact that topicalized constthe morpheme ___ents do not remain in-sthe morpheme ___ but are fronted to the clause-initial position (see also Example (\ref{Example_1.4}) in §\ref{Para_1.6.1.4}, p. \pageref{Example_1.4}).
A: word: itu	 gloss: D.DIST
B: word: situ	 gloss: L.MED
C: word: sana	 gloss: L.DIST
D: word: hurki	 gloss: Hurki
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 528:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ... di dano situ di ___ {\bluebold{laki\Tildelaki}} de] pu [tempat situ]]
Gloss (with missing item): ... at lake L.MED at ___ RDP\Tildehusband 3SG POSS place L.MED
The English translation of this sentence is:‘[we wanted to pray a whole night while picnicking, at what’s-its-name,] at the lake there, at the older brother’s place there’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: First, \textsc{np} \textsc{pro-sg} expressions can occur in positions other than the clause-initial subject slot, as shown with the \textsc{np} \textsc{2sg} \isi{noun} phrases in (\ref{Example_6.62}), (\ref{Example_6.64}), and (\ref{Example_6.65}), and the \textsc{np} \textsc{3sg} \isi{noun} phrases in (\ref{Example_6.69}) and (\ref{Example_6.74}). In these positions, however, the respective common nouns cannot be interpreted as topics in topic-comment constructions. This is due to the fact that topicalized constituents do not remain in-situ but are fronted to the clause-initial position (see also Example (\ref{Example_1.4}) in §\ref{Para_1.6.1.4}, p. \pageref{Example_1.4}).
A: word: kaka	 gloss: oSb
B: word: br–ade-kaka	 gloss: VBLZ–siblings
C: word: komputer	 gloss: computer
D: word: martina	 gloss: Martina
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 529:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ... di dano situ di [[kaka {\bluebold{laki\Tildelaki}} ___ pu [tempat situ]]
Gloss (with missing item): ... at lake L.MED at oSb RDP\Tildehusband ___ POSS place L.MED
The English translation of this sentence is:‘[we wanted to pray a whole night while picnicking, at what’s-its-name,] at the lake there, at the older brother’s place there’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: First, \textsc{np} \textsc{pro-sg} expressions can occur in positions other than the clause-initial subject slot, as shown with the \textsc{np} \textsc{2sg} \isi{noun} phrases in (\ref{Example_6.62}), (\ref{Example_6.64}), and (\ref{Example_6.65}), and the \textsc{np} \textsc{3sg} \isi{noun} phrases in (\ref{Example_6.69}) and (\ref{Example_6.74}). In these positions, however, the respective common nouns cannot be interpreted as topics in topic-comment constructions. This is due to the fact that topicalized constituents do not remain in-situ but are fronted to the clause-initial position (see also Example (\ref{Example_1.4}) in §\ref{Para_1.6.1.4}, p. \pageref{Example_1.4}).
A: word: de	 gloss: 3SG
B: word: deng	 gloss: with
C: word: dei	 gloss: 3sg
D: word: pace	 gloss: man
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 530:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ___ ko itu ko taw kata pis ka tida
Gloss (with missing item): ___ 2SG D.DIST 2SG know word please[E] or NEG
The English translation of this sentence is:‘you Eferdina there, do you know the word ``please'' or not?’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Second, an \textsc{np} \textsc{pro-sg} expression can be modified with a \isi{demonstrative}, as in the \textsc{np} \textsc{2sg} \isi{noun} phrases in (\ref{Example_6.66}) to (\ref{Example_6.68}), or the \textsc{np} \textsc{3sg} \isi{noun} phrases in \ref{Example_6.69}) and (\ref{Example_6.76}). In these ``\textsc{np} \textsc{pro-sg dem}'' expressions, the demonstratives have scope over the pronouns. The fact that the pronouns occur in \isi{noun} phrases with adnominal \isi{demonstrative}, in turn, supports the conclusion that in \textsc{np} \textsc{pro-sg} expressions the pronouns function as determiners. Moreover, in two of the examples, the \textsc{np} \textsc{pro-sg} \textsc{dem} expressions have topic function in topic-comment constructions, namely the \textsc{np} \textsc{2sg} \textsc{dem} \isi{noun} phrases in (\ref{Example_6.67}) and (\ref{Example_6.68}). In both cases, the preposed \isi{noun} phrases are copied by coreferential \textitbf{ko} ‘\textsc{2sg}’ which has comment function.\footnote{There is no \isi{comma intonation} between the topical \isi{noun} phrases and the pronominal comments in (\ref{Example_6.67}) and (\ref{Example_6.69}).} Neither bare \textitbf{Barce} in (\ref{Example_6.67}), nor bare \textitbf{its gloss ___} in (\ref{Example_6.68}) can be topics in topic-comment constructions. Instead it is the entire \isi{noun} phrase, including determiner \textitbf{ko} ‘2\textsc{sg}’, which has topic function. This, in turn, also supports the conclusion that in \textsc{np} \textsc{pro-sg} expressions, the \isi{pronoun} functions as a pronominal determiner.
A: word: eferdina	 gloss: Eferdina
B: word: berdiri	 gloss: stand
C: word: pis	 gloss: please[E]
D: word: kam	 gloss: 2PL
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 531:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): Eferdina ___ itu ko taw kata pis ka tida
Gloss (with missing item): Eferdina ___ D.DIST 2SG know word please[E] or NEG
The English translation of this sentence is:‘you Eferdina there, do you know the word ``please'' or not?’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Second, an \textsc{np} \textsc{pro-sg} expression can be modified with a \isi{demonstrative}, as in the \textsc{np} \textsc{2sg} \isi{noun} phrases in (\ref{Example_6.66}) to (\ref{Example_6.68}), or the \textsc{np} \textsc{3sg} \isi{noun} phrases in \ref{Example_6.69}) and (\ref{Example_6.76}). In these ``\textsc{np} \textsc{pro-sg dem}'' expressions, the demonstratives have scope over the pronouns. The fact that the pronouns occur in \isi{noun} phrases with adnominal \isi{demonstrative}, in turn, supports the conclusion that in \textsc{np} \textsc{pro-sg} expressions the pronouns function as determiners. Moreover, in two of the examples, the \textsc{np} \textsc{pro-sg} \textsc{dem} expressions have topic function in topic-comment constructions, namely the \textsc{np} \textsc{2sg} \textsc{dem} \isi{noun} phrases in (\ref{Example_6.67}) and (\ref{Example_6.68}). In both cases, the preposed \isi{noun} phrases are copied by coreferential \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘\textsc{2sg}’ which has comment function.\footnote{There is no \isi{comma intonation} between the topical \isi{noun} phrases and the pronominal comments in (\ref{Example_6.67}) and (\ref{Example_6.69}).} Neither bare \textitbf{Barce} in (\ref{Example_6.67}), nor bare \textitbf{Eferdina} in (\ref{Example_6.68}) can be topics in topic-comment constructions. Instead it is the entire \isi{noun} phrase, including determiner \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘2\textsc{sg}’, which has topic function. This, in turn, also supports the conclusion that in \textsc{np} \textsc{pro-sg} expressions, the \isi{pronoun} functions as a pronominal determiner.
A: word: ko	 gloss: 2SG
B: word: skola	 gloss: go.to.school
C: word: fol	 gloss: be.full
D: word: maytua	 gloss: wife
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 532:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): Eferdina ko ___ ko taw kata pis ka tida
Gloss (with missing item): Eferdina 2SG ___ 2SG know word please[E] or NEG
The English translation of this sentence is:‘you Eferdina there, do you know the word ``please'' or not?’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Second, an \textsc{np} \textsc{pro-sg} expression can be modified with a \isi{demonstrative}, as in the \textsc{np} \textsc{2sg} \isi{noun} phrases in (\ref{Example_6.66}) to (\ref{Example_6.68}), or the \textsc{np} \textsc{3sg} \isi{noun} phrases in \ref{Example_6.69}) and (\ref{Example_6.76}). In these ``\textsc{np} \textsc{pro-sg dem}'' expressions, the demonstratives have scope over the pronouns. The fact that the pronouns occur in \isi{noun} phrases with adnominal \isi{demonstrative}, in turn, supports the conclusion that in \textsc{np} \textsc{pro-sg} expressions the pronouns function as determiners. Moreover, in two of the examples, the \textsc{np} \textsc{pro-sg} \textsc{dem} expressions have topic function in topic-comment constructions, namely the \textsc{np} \textsc{2sg} \textsc{dem} \isi{noun} phrases in (\ref{Example_6.67}) and (\ref{Example_6.68}). In both cases, the preposed \isi{noun} phrases are copied by coreferential \textitbf{ko} ‘\textsc{2sg}’ which has comment function.\footnote{There is no \isi{comma intonation} between the topical \isi{noun} phrases and the pronominal comments in (\ref{Example_6.67}) and (\ref{Example_6.69}).} Neither bare \textitbf{Barce} in (\ref{Example_6.67}), nor bare \textitbf{Eferdina} in (\ref{Example_6.68}) can be topics in topic-comment constructions. Instead it is the entire \isi{noun} phrase, including determiner \textitbf{ko} ‘2\textsc{sg}’, which has topic function. This, in turn, also supports the conclusion that in \textsc{np} \textsc{pro-sg} expressions, the \isi{pronoun} functions as a pronominal determiner.
A: word: itu	 gloss: D.DIST
B: word: situ	 gloss: L.MED
C: word: sana	 gloss: L.DIST
D: word: dari	 gloss: from
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 533:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): Wili ko jangang {gara\Tildegara} ___ dia itu]!
Gloss (with missing item): Wili 2SG NEG.IMP RDP\Tildeirritate ___ 3SG D.DIST
The English translation of this sentence is:‘you Wili don’t irritate that aunt!’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Second, an \textsc{np} \textsc{pro-sg} expression can be modified with a \isi{demonstrative}, as in the \textsc{np} \textsc{2sg} \isi{noun} phrases in (\ref{Example_6.66}) to (\ref{Example_6.68}), or the \textsc{np} \textsc{3sg} \isi{noun} phrases in \ref{Example_6.69}) and (\ref{Example_6.76}). In these ``\textsc{np} \textsc{pro-sg dem}'' expressions, the demonstratives have scope over the pronouns. The fact that the pronouns occur in \isi{noun} phrases with adnominal \isi{demonstrative}, in turn, supports the conclusion that in \textsc{np} \textsc{pro-sg} expressions the pronouns function as determiners. Moreover, in two of the examples, the \textsc{np} \textsc{pro-sg} \textsc{dem} expressions have topic function in topic-comment constructions, namely the \textsc{np} \textsc{2sg} \textsc{dem} \isi{noun} phrases in (\ref{Example_6.67}) and (\ref{Example_6.68}). In both cases, the preposed \isi{noun} phrases are copied by coreferential \textitbf{ko} ‘\textsc{2sg}’ which has comment function.\footnote{There is no \isi{comma intonation} between the topical \isi{noun} phrases and the pronominal comments in (\ref{Example_6.67}) and (\ref{Example_6.69}).} Neither bare \textitbf{Barce} in (\ref{Example_6.67}), nor bare \textitbf{Eferdina} in (\ref{Example_6.68}) can be topics in topic-comment constructions. Instead it is the entire \isi{noun} phrase, including determiner \textitbf{ko} ‘2\textsc{sg}’, which has topic function. This, in turn, also supports the conclusion that in \textsc{np} \textsc{pro-sg} expressions, the \isi{pronoun} functions as a pronominal determiner.
A: word: tanta	 gloss: aunt
B: word: mantang	 gloss: former
C: word: nene	 gloss: grandmother
D: word: pemuda	 gloss: youth
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 534:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): Wili ko jangang {gara\Tildegara} [tanta ___ itu]!
Gloss (with missing item): Wili 2SG NEG.IMP RDP\Tildeirritate aunt ___ D.DIST
The English translation of this sentence is:‘you Wili don’t irritate that aunt!’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Second, an \textsc{np} \textsc{pro-sg} expression can be modified with a \isi{demonstrative}, as in the \textsc{np} \textsc{2sg} \isi{noun} phrases in (\ref{Example_6.66}) to (\ref{Example_6.68}), or the \textsc{np} \textsc{3sg} \isi{noun} phrases in \ref{Example_6.69}) and (\ref{Example_6.76}). In these ``\textsc{np} \textsc{pro-sg dem}'' expressions, the demonstratives have scope over the pronouns. The fact that the pronouns occur in \isi{noun} phrases with adnominal \isi{demonstrative}, in turn, supports the conclusion that in \textsc{np} \textsc{pro-sg} expressions the pronouns function as determiners. Moreover, in two of the examples, the \textsc{np} \textsc{pro-sg} \textsc{dem} expressions have topic function in topic-comment constructions, namely the \textsc{np} \textsc{2sg} \textsc{dem} \isi{noun} phrases in (\ref{Example_6.67}) and (\ref{Example_6.68}). In both cases, the preposed \isi{noun} phrases are copied by coreferential \textitbf{ko} ‘\textsc{2sg}’ which has comment function.\footnote{There is no \isi{comma intonation} between the topical \isi{noun} phrases and the pronominal comments in (\ref{Example_6.67}) and (\ref{Example_6.69}).} Neither bare \textitbf{Barce} in (\ref{Example_6.67}), nor bare \textitbf{Eferdina} in (\ref{Example_6.68}) can be topics in topic-comment constructions. Instead it is the entire \isi{noun} phrase, including determiner \textitbf{ko} ‘2\textsc{sg}’, which has topic function. This, in turn, also supports the conclusion that in \textsc{np} \textsc{pro-sg} expressions, the \isi{pronoun} functions as a pronominal determiner.
A: word: dia	 gloss: 3SG
B: word: diai	 gloss: 3SG
C: word: dei	 gloss: 3sg
D: word: agus	 gloss: Agus
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 535:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): Wili ko jangang {gara\Tildegara} [tanta dia ___
Gloss (with missing item): Wili 2SG NEG.IMP RDP\Tildeirritate aunt 3SG ___

The fact that the pronouns occur in \isi{noun} phrases with adnominal \isi{demonstrative}, in turn, supports the conclusion that in \textsc{np} \textsc{pro-sg} expressions the pronouns function as determiners. Moreover, in two of the examples, the \textsc{np} \textsc{pro-sg} \textsc{dem} expressions have topic function in topic-comment constructions, namely the \textsc{np} \textsc{2sg} \textsc{dem} \isi{noun} phrases in (\ref{Example_6.67}) and (\ref{Example_6.68}). D: word: dua	 gloss: two
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 536:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ___ pendeta di Mambramo de tu jual RW
Gloss (with missing item): ___ pastor at Mambramo 3SG D.DIST sell cooked.dog.meat
The English translation of this sentence is:‘that older sibling pastor in (the) Mambramo (area) sells cooked dog meat’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Second, an \textsc{np} \textsc{pro-sg} expression can be modified with a \isi{demonstrative}, as in the \textsc{np} \textsc{2sg} \isi{noun} phrases in (\ref{Example_6.66}) to (\ref{Example_6.68}), or the \textsc{np} \textsc{3sg} \isi{noun} phrases in \ref{Example_6.69}) and (\ref{Example_6.76}). In these ``\textsc{np} \textsc{pro-sg dem}'' expressions, the demonstratives have scope over the pronouns. The fact that the pronouns occur in \isi{noun} phrases with adnominal \isi{demonstrative}, in turn, supports the conclusion that in \textsc{np} \textsc{pro-sg} expressions the pronouns function as determiners. Moreover, in two of the examples, the \textsc{np} \textsc{pro-sg} \textsc{dem} expressions have topic function in topic-comment constructions, namely the \textsc{np} \textsc{2sg} \textsc{dem} \isi{noun} phrases in (\ref{Example_6.67}) and (\ref{Example_6.68}). In both cases, the preposed \isi{noun} phrases are copied by coreferential \textitbf{ko} ‘\textsc{2sg}’ which has comment function.\footnote{There is no \isi{comma intonation} between the topical \isi{noun} phrases and the pronominal comments in (\ref{Example_6.67}) and (\ref{Example_6.69}).} Neither bare \textitbf{Barce} in (\ref{Example_6.67}), nor bare \textitbf{Eferdina} in (\ref{Example_6.68}) can be topics in topic-comment constructions. Instead it is the entire \isi{noun} phrase, including determiner \textitbf{ko} ‘2\textsc{sg}’, which has topic function. This, in turn, also supports the conclusion that in \textsc{np} \textsc{pro-sg} expressions, the \isi{pronoun} functions as a pronominal determiner.
A: word: kaka	 gloss: oSb
B: word: br–ade-kaka	 gloss: VBLZ–siblings
C: word: komputer	 gloss: computer
D: word: pemuda	 gloss: youth
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 537:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): kaka ___ di Mambramo de tu jual RW
Gloss (with missing item): oSb ___ at Mambramo 3SG D.DIST sell cooked.dog.meat
The English translation of this sentence is:‘that older sibling pastor in (the) Mambramo (area) sells cooked dog meat’

The fact that the pronouns occur in \isi{noun} phrases with adnominal \isi{demonstrative}, in turn, supports the conclusion that in \textsc{np} \textsc{pro-sg} expressions the pronouns function as determiners. Moreover, in two of the examples, the \textsc{np} \textsc{pro-sg} \textsc{dem} expressions have topic function in topic-comment constructions, namely the \textsc{np} \textsc{2sg} \textsc{dem} \isi{noun} phrases in (\ref{Example_6.67}) and (\ref{Example_6.68}). Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 538:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): kaka pendeta ___ Mambramo de tu jual RW
Gloss (with missing item): oSb pastor ___ Mambramo 3SG D.DIST sell cooked.dog.meat
The English translation of this sentence is:‘that older sibling pastor in (the) Mambramo (area) sells cooked dog meat’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Second, an \textsc{np} \textsc{pro-sg} expression can be mothe morpheme ___fied with a \isi{demonstrits gloss ___ive}, as in the \textsc{np} \textsc{2sg} \isi{noun} phrases in (\ref{Example_6.66}) to (\ref{Example_6.68}), or the \textsc{np} \textsc{3sg} \isi{noun} phrases in \ref{Example_6.69}) and (\ref{Example_6.76}). In these ``\textsc{np} \textsc{pro-sg dem}'' expressions, the demonstrits gloss ___ives have scope over the pronouns. The fact thits gloss ___ the pronouns occur in \isi{noun} phrases with adnominal \isi{demonstrits gloss ___ive}, in turn, supports the conclusion thits gloss ___ in \textsc{np} \textsc{pro-sg} expressions the pronouns function as determiners. Moreover, in two of the examples, the \textsc{np} \textsc{pro-sg} \textsc{dem} expressions have topic function in topic-comment constructions, namely the \textsc{np} \textsc{2sg} \textsc{dem} \isi{noun} phrases in (\ref{Example_6.67}) and (\ref{Example_6.68}). In both cases, the preposed \isi{noun} phrases are copied by coreferential \textitbf{ko} ‘\textsc{2sg}’ which has comment function.\footnote{There is no \isi{comma intonits gloss ___ion} between the topical \isi{noun} phrases and the pronominal comments in (\ref{Example_6.67}) and (\ref{Example_6.69}).} Neither bare \textitbf{Barce} in (\ref{Example_6.67}), nor bare \textitbf{Eferthe morpheme ___na} in (\ref{Example_6.68}) can be topics in topic-comment constructions. Instead it is the entire \isi{noun} phrase, incluthe morpheme ___ng determiner \textitbf{ko} ‘2\textsc{sg}’, which has topic function. This, in turn, also supports the conclusion thits gloss ___ in \textsc{np} \textsc{pro-sg} expressions, the \isi{pronoun} functions as a pronominal determiner.
A: word: di	 gloss: at
B: word: dia	 gloss: 3SG
C: word: ana–nya	 gloss: child–3POSSR
D: word: dua	 gloss: two
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 539:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): kaka pendeta di ___ de tu jual RW
Gloss (with missing item): oSb pastor at ___ 3SG D.DIST sell cooked.dog.meat
The English translation of this sentence is:‘that older sibling pastor in (the) Mambramo (area) sells cooked dog meat’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Second, an \textsc{np} \textsc{pro-sg} expression can be modified with a \isi{demonstrative}, as in the \textsc{np} \textsc{2sg} \isi{noun} phrases in (\ref{Example_6.66}) to (\ref{Example_6.68}), or the \textsc{np} \textsc{3sg} \isi{noun} phrases in \ref{Example_6.69}) and (\ref{Example_6.76}). In these ``\textsc{np} \textsc{pro-sg dem}'' expressions, the demonstratives have scope over the pronouns. The fact that the pronouns occur in \isi{noun} phrases with adnominal \isi{demonstrative}, in turn, supports the conclusion that in \textsc{np} \textsc{pro-sg} expressions the pronouns function as determiners. Moreover, in two of the examples, the \textsc{np} \textsc{pro-sg} \textsc{dem} expressions have topic function in topic-comment constructions, namely the \textsc{np} \textsc{2sg} \textsc{dem} \isi{noun} phrases in (\ref{Example_6.67}) and (\ref{Example_6.68}). In both cases, the preposed \isi{noun} phrases are copied by coreferential \textitbf{ko} ‘\textsc{2sg}’ which has comment function.\footnote{There is no \isi{comma intonation} between the topical \isi{noun} phrases and the pronominal comments in (\ref{Example_6.67}) and (\ref{Example_6.69}).} Neither bare \textitbf{Barce} in (\ref{Example_6.67}), nor bare \textitbf{Eferdina} in (\ref{Example_6.68}) can be topics in topic-comment constructions. Instead it is the entire \isi{noun} phrase, including determiner \textitbf{ko} ‘2\textsc{sg}’, which has topic function. This, in turn, also supports the conclusion that in \textsc{np} \textsc{pro-sg} expressions, the \isi{pronoun} functions as a pronominal determiner.
A: word: mambramo	 gloss: Mambramo
B: word: ambil	 gloss: fetch
C: word: yoram	 gloss: Yoram
D: word: mama-tua	 gloss: aunt
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 540:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. The English translation of this sentence is:‘that older sibling pastor in (the) Mambramo (area) sells cooked dog meat’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Second, an \textsc{np} \textsc{pro-sg} expression can be modified with a \isi{the morpheme ___monstrative}, as in the \textsc{np} \textsc{2sg} \isi{noun} phrases in (\ref{Example_6.66}) to (\ref{Example_6.68}), or the \textsc{np} \textsc{3sg} \isi{noun} phrases in \ref{Example_6.69}) and (\ref{Example_6.76}). In these ``\textsc{np} \textsc{pro-sg the morpheme ___m}'' expressions, the the morpheme ___monstratives have scope over the pronouns. The fact that the pronouns occur in \isi{noun} phrases with adnominal \isi{the morpheme ___monstrative}, in turn, supports the conclusion that in \textsc{np} \textsc{pro-sg} expressions the pronouns function as the morpheme ___terminers. Moreover, in two of the examples, the \textsc{np} \textsc{pro-sg} \textsc{the morpheme ___m} expressions have topic function in topic-comment constructions, namely the \textsc{np} \textsc{2sg} \textsc{the morpheme ___m} \isi{noun} phrases in (\ref{Example_6.67}) and (\ref{Example_6.68}). In both cases, the preposed \isi{noun} phrases are copied by coreferential \textitbf{ko} ‘\textsc{2sg}’ which has comment function.\footnote{There is no \isi{comma intonation} between the topical \isi{noun} phrases and the pronominal comments in (\ref{Example_6.67}) and (\ref{Example_6.69}).} Neither bare \textitbf{Barce} in (\ref{Example_6.67}), nor bare \textitbf{Eferdina} in (\ref{Example_6.68}) can be topics in topic-comment constructions. Instead it is the entire \isi{noun} phrase, including the morpheme ___terminer \textitbf{ko} ‘2\textsc{sg}’, which has topic function. This, in turn, also supports the conclusion that in \textsc{np} \textsc{pro-sg} expressions, the \isi{pronoun} functions as a pronominal the morpheme ___terminer.
A: word: de	 gloss: 3SG
B: word: deng	 gloss: with
C: word: dei	 gloss: 3sg
D: word: dia	 gloss: 3SG
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 541:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option.

Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Second, an \textsc{np} \textsc{pro-sg} expression can be modified with a \isi{demonstrative}, as in the \textsc{np} \textsc{2sg} \isi{noun} phrases in (\ref{Example_6.66}) to (\ref{Example_6.68}), or the \textsc{np} \textsc{3sg} \isi{noun} phrases in \ref{Example_6.69}) and (\ref{Example_6.76}). In these ``\textsc{np} \textsc{pro-sg dem}'' expressions, the demonstratives have scope over the pronouns. The fact that the pronouns occur in \isi{noun} phrases with adnominal \isi{demonstrative}, in the morpheme ___rn, supports the conclusion that in \textsc{np} \textsc{pro-sg} expressions the pronouns function as determiners. Moreover, in two of the examples, the \textsc{np} \textsc{pro-sg} \textsc{dem} expressions have topic function in topic-comment constructions, namely the \textsc{np} \textsc{2sg} \textsc{dem} \isi{noun} phrases in (\ref{Example_6.67}) and (\ref{Example_6.68}). In both cases, the preposed \isi{noun} phrases are copied by coreferential \textitbf{ko} ‘\textsc{2sg}’ which has comment function.\footnote{There is no \isi{comma intonation} between the topical \isi{noun} phrases and the pronominal comments in (\ref{Example_6.67}) and (\ref{Example_6.69}).} Neither bare \textitbf{Barce} in (\ref{Example_6.67}), nor bare \textitbf{Eferdina} in (\ref{Example_6.68}) can be topics in topic-comment constructions. B: word: satu	 gloss: one
C: word: sana	 gloss: L.DIST
D: word: ise	 gloss: Ise
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 542:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ___ ko ini ko takut
Gloss (with missing item): ___ 2SG D.PROX 2SG feel.afraid(.of)
The English translation of this sentence is:‘you Barce here, you feel afraid’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Second, an \textsc{np} \textsc{pro-sg} expression can be modified with a \isi{demonstrative}, as in the \textsc{np} \textsc{2sg} \isi{noun} phrases in (\ref{Example_6.66}) to (\ref{Example_6.68}), or the \textsc{np} \textsc{3sg} \isi{noun} phrases in \ref{Example_6.69}) and (\ref{Example_6.76}). The fact that the pronouns occur in \isi{noun} phrases with adnominal \isi{demonstrative}, in turn, supports the conclusion that in \textsc{np} \textsc{pro-sg} expressions the pronouns function as determiners. Moreover, in two of the examples, the \textsc{np} \textsc{pro-sg} \textsc{dem} expressions have topic function in topic-comment constructions, namely the \textsc{np} \textsc{2sg} \textsc{dem} \isi{noun} phrases in (\ref{Example_6.67}) and (\ref{Example_6.68}). In both cases, the preposed \isi{noun} phrases are copied by coreferential \textitbf{ko} ‘\textsc{2sg}’ which has comment function.\footnote{There is no \isi{comma intonation} between the topical \isi{noun} phrases and the pronominal comments in (\ref{Example_6.67}) and (\ref{Example_6.69}).} Neither bare \textitbf{its gloss ___} in (\ref{Example_6.67}), nor bare \textitbf{Eferdina} in (\ref{Example_6.68}) can be topics in topic-comment constructions. Instead it is the entire \isi{noun} phrase, including determiner \textitbf{ko} ‘2\textsc{sg}’, which has topic function. This, in turn, also supports the conclusion that in \textsc{np} \textsc{pro-sg} expressions, the \isi{pronoun} functions as a pronominal determiner.

Please only return the letter (A–D).

Gloss (with missing item): Barce ___ D.PROX 2SG feel.afraid(.of)
The English translation of this sentence is:‘you Barce here, you feel afraid’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Second, an \textsc{np} \textsc{pro-sg} expression can be modified with a \isi{demonstrative}, as in the \textsc{np} \textsc{2sg} \isi{noun} phrases in (\ref{Example_6.66}) to (\ref{Example_6.68}), or the \textsc{np} \textsc{3sg} \isi{noun} phrases in \ref{Example_6.69}) and (\ref{Example_6.76}). In these ``\textsc{np} \textsc{pro-sg dem}'' expressions, the demonstratives have scope over the pronouns. The fact that the pronouns occur in \isi{noun} phrases with adnominal \isi{demonstrative}, in turn, supports the conclusion that in \textsc{np} \textsc{pro-sg} expressions the pronouns function as determiners. Moreover, in two of the examples, the \textsc{np} \textsc{pro-sg} \textsc{dem} expressions have topic function in topic-comment constructions, namely the \textsc{np} \textsc{2sg} \textsc{dem} \isi{noun} phrases in (\ref{Example_6.67}) and (\ref{Example_6.68}). In both cases, the preposed \isi{noun} phrases are copied by coreferential \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘\textsc{2sg}’ which has comment function.\footnote{There is no \isi{comma intonation} between the topical \isi{noun} phrases and the pronominal comments in (\ref{Example_6.67}) and (\ref{Example_6.69}).} Neither bare \textitbf{Barce} in (\ref{Example_6.67}), nor bare \textitbf{Eferdina} in (\ref{Example_6.68}) can be topics in topic-comment constructions. Instead it is the entire \isi{noun} phrase, including determiner \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘2\textsc{sg}’, which has topic function. This, in turn, also supports the conclusion that in \textsc{np} \textsc{pro-sg} expressions, the \isi{pronoun} functions as a pronominal determiner.
A: word: ko	 gloss: 2SG
B: word: skola	 gloss: go.to.school
C: word: ayo	 gloss: come.on!
D: word: susana	 gloss: Susana
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 551:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. The fact that the pronouns occur in \isi{noun} phrases with adnominal \isi{demonstrative}, in turn, supports the conclusion that in \textsc{np} \textsc{pro-sg} expressions the pronouns function as determiners. Moreover, in two of the examples, the \textsc{np} \textsc{pro-sg} \textsc{dem} expressions have topic function in topic-comment constructions, namely the \textsc{np} \textsc{2sg} \textsc{dem} \isi{noun} phrases in (\ref{Example_6.67}) and (\ref{Example_6.68}). Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 552:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Second, an \textsc{np} \textsc{pro-sg} expression can be modified with a \isi{demonstrative}, as in the \textsc{np} \textsc{2sg} \isi{noun} phrases in (\ref{Example_6.66}) to (\ref{Example_6.68}), or the \textsc{np} \textsc{3sg} \isi{noun} phrases in \ref{Example_6.69}) and (\ref{Example_6.76}). The fact that the pronouns occur in \isi{noun} phrases with adnominal \isi{demonstrative}, in turn, supports the conclusion that in \textsc{np} \textsc{pro-sg} expressions the pronouns function as determiners. Moreover, in two of the examples, the \textsc{np} \textsc{pro-sg} \textsc{dem} expressions have topic function in topic-comment constructions, namely the \textsc{np} \textsc{2sg} \textsc{dem} \isi{noun} phrases in (\ref{Example_6.67}) and (\ref{Example_6.68}). In both cases, the preposed \isi{noun} phrases are copied by coreferential \textitbf{ko} ‘\textsc{2sg}’ which has comment function.\footnote{There is no \isi{comma intonation} between the topical \isi{noun} phrases and the pronominal comments in (\ref{Example_6.67}) and (\ref{Example_6.69}).} Neither bare \textitbf{Barce} in (\ref{Example_6.67}), nor bare \textitbf{Eferdina} in (\ref{Example_6.68}) can be topics in topic-comment constructions. Instead it is the entire \isi{noun} phrase, including determiner \textitbf{ko} ‘2\textsc{sg}’, which has topic function. Please only return the letter (A–D).
