Question 560:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ___ de], [pace de] mandi rapi, de mandi rapi
Gloss (with missing item): ___ 3SG man 3SG bathe be.neat 3SG bathe be.neat
The English translation of this sentence is:‘the man, the man bathed neatly, he bathed neatly’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Fourth, the corpus includes a number of utterances, in which speakers repeat an \textsc{np} \textsc{pro-sg} expression as a form of hesitation or delay; in each case the \isi{pronoun} is third person \textitbf{dia}/\textitbf{de} ‘3\textsc{sg}’. Two of these repetitions are presented in (\ref{Example_6.86}) and (\ref{Example_6.87}). It is noted that the speakers do not repeat the respective bare nouns \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ and \textitbf{Markus}, but the \textsc{np} \textsc{3sg} expressions \textitbf{the morpheme ___ de} ‘the its gloss ___’ (literally ‘he its gloss ___’) and \textitbf{Markus de} ‘Markus’ (literally ‘he Markus’). This suggests that they perceive these expressions to be cohesive entities which, in turn, supports their analysis as single \isi{noun} phrases.
A: word: pace	 gloss: man
B: word: mace	 gloss: woman
C: word: bapa	 gloss: father
D: word: mama-tua	 gloss: aunt
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 561:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): [pace ___ [pace de] mandi rapi, de mandi rapi
Gloss (with missing item): man ___ man 3SG bathe be.neat 3SG bathe be.neat
The English translation of this sentence is:‘the man, the man bathed neatly, he bathed neatly’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Fourth, the corpus incluthe morpheme ___s a number of utterances, in which speakers repeat an \textsc{np} \textsc{pro-sg} expression as a form of hesitation or the morpheme ___lay; in each case the \isi{pronoun} is third person \textitbf{dia}/\textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘3\textsc{sg}’. Two of these repetitions are presented in (\ref{Example_6.86}) and (\ref{Example_6.87}). It is noted that the speakers do not repeat the respective bare nouns \textitbf{pace} ‘man’ and \textitbf{Markus}, but the \textsc{np} \textsc{3sg} expressions \textitbf{pace the morpheme ___} ‘the man’ (literally ‘he man’) and \textitbf{Markus the morpheme ___} ‘Markus’ (literally ‘he Markus’). This suggests that they perceive these expressions to be cohesive entities which, in turn, supports their analysis as single \isi{noun} phrases.
A: word: de	 gloss: 3SG
B: word: deng	 gloss: with
C: word: dei	 gloss: 3sg
D: word: oktofina	 gloss: Oktofina
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 562:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): [pace de], ___ de] mandi rapi, de mandi rapi
Gloss (with missing item): man 3SG ___ 3SG bathe be.neat 3SG bathe be.neat
The English translation of this sentence is:‘the man, the man bathed neatly, he bathed neatly’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Fourth, the corpus includes a number of utterances, in which speakers repeat an \textsc{np} \textsc{pro-sg} expression as a form of hesitation or delay; in each case the \isi{pronoun} is third person \textitbf{dia}/\textitbf{de} ‘3\textsc{sg}’. Two of these repetitions are presented in (\ref{Example_6.86}) and (\ref{Example_6.87}). It is noted that the speakers do not repeat the respective bare nouns \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ and \textitbf{Markus}, but the \textsc{np} \textsc{3sg} expressions \textitbf{the morpheme ___ de} ‘the its gloss ___’ (literally ‘he its gloss ___’) and \textitbf{Markus de} ‘Markus’ (literally ‘he Markus’). This suggests that they perceive these expressions to be cohesive entities which, in turn, supports their analysis as single \isi{noun} phrases.
A: word: pace	 gloss: man
B: word: mace	 gloss: woman
C: word: bapa	 gloss: father
D: word: deng	 gloss: with
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 563:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): [pace de], [pace ___ mandi rapi, de mandi rapi
Gloss (with missing item): man 3SG man ___ bathe be.neat 3SG bathe be.neat
The English translation of this sentence is:‘the man, the man bathed neatly, he bathed neatly’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Fourth, the corpus incluthe morpheme ___s a number of utterances, in which speakers repeat an \textsc{np} \textsc{pro-sg} expression as a form of hesitation or the morpheme ___lay; in each case the \isi{pronoun} is third person \textitbf{dia}/\textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘3\textsc{sg}’. Two of these repetitions are presented in (\ref{Example_6.86}) and (\ref{Example_6.87}). It is noted that the speakers do not repeat the respective bare nouns \textitbf{pace} ‘man’ and \textitbf{Markus}, but the \textsc{np} \textsc{3sg} expressions \textitbf{pace the morpheme ___} ‘the man’ (literally ‘he man’) and \textitbf{Markus the morpheme ___} ‘Markus’ (literally ‘he Markus’). This suggests that they perceive these expressions to be cohesive entities which, in turn, supports their analysis as single \isi{noun} phrases.
A: word: de	 gloss: 3SG
B: word: deng	 gloss: with
C: word: dei	 gloss: 3sg
D: word: kitong	 gloss: 1PL
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 564:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): akirnya ___ de], [Markus dia] turung begini
Gloss (with missing item): finally ___ 3SG Markus 3SG descend like.this
The English translation of this sentence is:‘finally Markus, Markus came down (to the coast) like this’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Fourth, the corpus includes a number of utterances, in which speakers repeat an \textsc{np} \textsc{pro-sg} expression as a form of hesitation or delay; in each case the \isi{pronoun} is third person \textitbf{dia}/\textitbf{de} ‘3\textsc{sg}’. Two of these repetitions are presented in (\ref{Example_6.86}) and (\ref{Example_6.87}). It is noted that the speakers do not repeat the respective bare nouns \textitbf{pace} ‘man’ and \textitbf{its gloss ___}, but the \textsc{np} \textsc{3sg} expressions \textitbf{pace de} ‘the man’ (literally ‘he man’) and \textitbf{its gloss ___ de} ‘its gloss ___’ (literally ‘he its gloss ___’). This suggests that they perceive these expressions to be cohesive entities which, in turn, supports their analysis as single \isi{noun} phrases.
A: word: markus	 gloss: Markus
B: word: kamar	 gloss: room
C: word: lukas	 gloss: Lukas
D: word: mama	 gloss: mother
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 567:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option.

Gloss (with missing item): finally Markus 3SG Markus ___ descend like.this
The English translation of this sentence is:‘finally Markus, Markus came down (to the coast) like this’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Fourth, the corpus includes a number of utterances, in which speakers repeat an \textsc{np} \textsc{pro-sg} expression as a form of hesitation or delay; in each case the \isi{pronoun} is third person \textitbf{the morpheme ___}/\textitbf{de} ‘3\textsc{sg}’. Two of these repetitions are presented in (\ref{Example_6.86}) and (\ref{Example_6.87}). It is noted that the speakers do not repeat the respective bare nouns \textitbf{pace} ‘man’ and \textitbf{Markus}, but the \textsc{np} \textsc{3sg} expressions \textitbf{pace de} ‘the man’ (literally ‘he man’) and \textitbf{Markus de} ‘Markus’ (literally ‘he Markus’). This suggests that they perceive these expressions to be cohesive entities which, in turn, supports their analysis as single \isi{noun} phrases.
A: word: dia	 gloss: 3SG
B: word: diai	 gloss: 3SG
C: word: dei	 gloss: 3sg
D: word: kitong	 gloss: 1PL
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 568:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ___ dong] snang skali
Gloss (with missing item): ___ 3PL feel.happy(.about) very
The English translation of this sentence is:‘the young people feel very happy’ (Lit. ‘youth they’)
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Plural pronouns also function as determiners in \isi{noun} phrases, such that as illustrated in (\ref{Example_6.88}) and (\ref{Example_6.89}). They signal the definiteness and person-number values of their referents, and thereby allow their unambiguous identification.
A: word: pemuda	 gloss: youth
B: word: pe–muda	 gloss: AG–be.young
C: word: blas	 gloss: teens
D: word: martin	 gloss: Martin
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The examples in (\ref{Example_6.88}) and (\ref{Example_6.89}) also show that \textsc{n} \textsc{pro-pl} \isi{noun} phrases have two readings.

Question 576:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ___ dong] snang skali
Gloss (with missing item): ___ 3PL feel.happy(.about) very
The English translation of this sentence is:‘the young people feel very happy’ (Lit. ‘youth they’)
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: First with an \isi{indefinite} referent, such as \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ in (\ref{Example_6.88}), \textsc{n} \textsc{pro-pl} \isi{noun} phrases have an additive plural reading. Second with a \isi{definite} referent such as \textitbf{Ise} in (\ref{Example_6.89}), \textsc{n} \textsc{pro-pl} \isi{noun} phrases receive an \isi{associative} inclusory plural reading. This makes Papuan Malay belong to the large group of languages in Asia where the “\isi{associative plural} marker [{\ldots}] is also used to express additive plurals” \citep[5–6]{Daniel.2013}.
A: word: pemuda	 gloss: youth
B: word: pe–muda	 gloss: AG–be.young
C: word: blas	 gloss: teens
D: word: mama	 gloss: mother
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 577:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): [pemuda ___ snang skali
Gloss (with missing item): youth ___ feel.happy(.about) very
The English translation of this sentence is:‘the young people feel very happy’ (Lit. ‘youth they’)
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: First with an \isi{indefinite} referent, such as \textitbf{pemuda} ‘youth’ in (\ref{Example_6.88}), \textsc{n} \textsc{pro-pl} \isi{noun} phrases have an additive plural reading. Second with a \isi{definite} referent such as \textitbf{Ise} in (\ref{Example_6.89}), \textsc{n} \textsc{pro-pl} \isi{noun} phrases receive an \isi{associative} inclusory plural reading. This makes Papuan Malay belong to the large group of languages in Asia where the “\isi{associative plural} marker [{\ldots}] is also used to express additive plurals” \citep[5–6]{Daniel.2013}.
A: word: dong	 gloss: 3PL
B: word: dong/dorang	 gloss: 3PL
C: word: kam	 gloss: 2PL
D: word: miflal	 gloss: Miflal
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 579:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Second with a \isi{definite} referent such as \textitbf{Ise} in (\ref{Example_6.89}), \textsc{n} \textsc{pro-pl} \isi{noun} phrases receive an \isi{associative} inclusory plural reading. This makes Papuan Malay belong to the large group of languages in Asia where the “\isi{associative plural} marker [{\ldots}] is also used to express additive plurals” \citep[5–6]{Daniel.2013}.

Question 580:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): jadi ___ kitorang ini masak
Gloss (with missing item): so ___ 1PL D.PROX cook
The English translation of this sentence is:‘so we grandmothers here cook’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Cross-linguistically, the additive interpretation implies referential homogeneity of the group. That is, “every referent of the plural form is also a referent of the stem” \citep[1]{Daniel.2013}. This additive reading of Papuan Malay \textsc{n} \textsc{pro-pl} is illustrated in (\ref{Example_6.90}) to (\ref{Example_6.92}). In (\ref{Example_6.90}), \textitbf{kitorang} ‘\textsc{1pl}’ denotes the plurality of its bare head nominal \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’, while in (\ref{Example_6.91}) \textitbf{kamu} ‘\textsc{2pl}’ signals the plurality of \textitbf{bangsat} ‘rascal’, and in (\ref{Example_6.92}) \textitbf{dong} ‘\textsc{3pl}’ indicates the plurality of \textitbf{anjing} ‘dog’. These examples also show that the referent is always animate. It can be human as in (\ref{Example_6.90}) and (\ref{Example_6.91}), or nonhuman as in (\ref{Example_6.92}); inanimate referents are unattested.
A: word: nene	 gloss: grandmother
B: word: beneraf	 gloss: Beneraf
C: word: tanta	 gloss: aunt
D: word: bapa	 gloss: father
Please only return the letter (A–D).

D: word: hurki	 gloss: Hurki
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 596:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ___ kamu tu tinggal lari ke sana ke mari
Gloss (with missing item): ___ 2PL D.DIST stay run to L.DIST to hither
The English translation of this sentence is:‘you rascals there keep running back and forth’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Cross-linguistically, the additive interpretation implies referential homogeneity of the group. That is, “every referent of the plural form is also a referent of the stem” \citep[1]{Daniel.2013}. This additive reading of Papuan Malay \textsc{n} \textsc{pro-pl} is illustrated in (\ref{Example_6.90}) to (\ref{Example_6.92}). In (\ref{Example_6.90}), \textitbf{kitorang} ‘\textsc{1pl}’ denotes the plurality of its bare head nominal \textitbf{nene} ‘grandmother’, while in (\ref{Example_6.91}) \textitbf{kamu} ‘\textsc{2pl}’ signals the plurality of \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’, and in (\ref{Example_6.92}) \textitbf{dong} ‘\textsc{3pl}’ indicates the plurality of \textitbf{anjing} ‘dog’. These examples also show that the referent is always animate. It can be human as in (\ref{Example_6.90}) and (\ref{Example_6.91}), or nonhuman as in (\ref{Example_6.92}); inanimate referents are unattested.
A: word: bangsat	 gloss: rascal
B: word: langsung	 gloss: immediately
C: word: tinus	 gloss: Tinus
D: word: jepang	 gloss: Japan
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 599:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Sentence (with missing item): ... di mana ___ dong gong-gong

Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Cross-linguistically, the additive interpretation implies referential homogeneity of the group. These examples also show that the referent is always animate. It can be human as in (\ref{Example_6.90}) and (\ref{Example_6.91}), or nonhuman as in (\ref{Example_6.92}); inanimate referents are unattested.
A: word: anjing	 gloss: dog
B: word: banjir	 gloss: flooding
C: word: petrus	 gloss: Petrus
D: word: anging	 gloss: wind
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 601:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): jadi ___ kitorang ini masak
Gloss (with missing item): so ___ 1PL D.PROX cook
The English translation of this sentence is:‘so we grandmothers here cook’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In (\ref{Example_6.90}) to (\ref{Example_6.92}) the number of referents is left unspecified. When this number is limited to two, speakers very often use a dual construction, such that ``bare \textsc{n} \textsc{pro-pl} \textitbf{dua}''. In such a construction, the two referents are not explicitly mentioned but subsumed under the postposed adnominal \isi{numeral} \textitbf{dua} ‘two’, as in (\ref{Example_6.93}) and (\ref{Example_6.94}).
A: word: nene	 gloss: grandmother
B: word: beneraf	 gloss: Beneraf
C: word: tanta	 gloss: aunt
D: word: anging	 gloss: wind
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 607:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option.

Gloss (with missing item): RDP\Tildehusband 2PL ___ sweep
The English translation of this sentence is:‘you two boys sweep’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In (\ref{Example_6.90}) to (\ref{Example_6.92}) the number of referents is left unspecified. When this number is limited to its gloss ___, speakers very often use a the morpheme ___l construction, such that ``bare \textsc{n} \textsc{pro-pl} \textitbf{the morpheme ___}''. In such a construction, the its gloss ___ referents are not explicitly mentioned but subsumed under the postposed adnominal \isi{numeral} \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’, as in (\ref{Example_6.93}) and (\ref{Example_6.94}).
A: word: dua	 gloss: two
B: word: siduasi	 gloss: Siduas
C: word: kedua	 gloss: second
D: word: martin	 gloss: Martin
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 612:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ___ Oktofina kam pulang jam brapa?
Gloss (with missing item): ___ Oktofina 2PL go.home hour several
The English translation of this sentence is:‘what time did you aunt Oktofina and your companions including you (Oktofina) come home?’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In her cross-linguistic semantic analysis of \isi{associative} plurals, \citet[470–471]{Moravcsik.2003} defines “\isi{associative} plurals as “constructions whose meaning is ‘X and X’s associate(s)’, where all members are individuals, X is the focal referent, and the associate(s) form a group centering around X”. In Papuan Malay, the focal referent is always encoded with a \isi{noun} or \isi{noun} phrase heading the phrasal construction, while the associates are encoded with a post-head plural \isi{pronoun}. In (\ref{Example_6.95}) and (\ref{Example_6.96}), for instance, \textitbf{Lodia} and \textitbf{Pawlus} are the focal referents while the pronouns \textitbf{torang} ‘\textsc{1pl}’ and \textitbf{dorang} ‘\textsc{3pl}’ denote the associates, respectively.
A: word: tanta	 gloss: aunt
B: word: mantang	 gloss: former
C: word: nene	 gloss: grandmother
D: word: sidaq	 gloss: 3PL
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 613:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): tanta ___ kam pulang jam brapa?
Gloss (with missing item): aunt ___ 2PL go.home hour several
The English translation of this sentence is:‘what time did you aunt Oktofina and your companions including you (Oktofina) come home?’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In her cross-linguistic semantic analysis of \isi{associative} plurals, \citet[470–471]{Moravcsik.2003} defines “\isi{associative} plurals as “constructions whose meaning is ‘X and X’s associate(s)’, where all members are individuals, X is the focal referent, and the associate(s) form a group centering around X”. In Papuan Malay, the focal referent is always encoded with a \isi{noun} or \isi{noun} phrase heading the phrasal construction, while the associates are encoded with a post-head plural \isi{pronoun}. In (\ref{Example_6.95}) and (\ref{Example_6.96}), for instance, \textitbf{Lodia} and \textitbf{Pawlus} are the focal referents while the pronouns \textitbf{torang} ‘\textsc{1pl}’ and \textitbf{dorang} ‘\textsc{3pl}’ denote the associates, respectively.
A: word: oktofina	 gloss: Oktofina
B: word: oktofernus	 gloss: Oktofernus

D: word: saya	 gloss: 1SG

Question 614:

Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In her cross-linguistic semantic analysis of \isi{associative} plurals, \citet[470–471]{Moravcsik.2003} defines “\isi{associative} plurals as “constructions whose meaning is ‘X and X’s associate(s)’, where all members are individuals, X is the focal referent, and the associate(s) form a group centering around X”. In Papuan Malay, the focal referent is always encoded with a \isi{noun} or \isi{noun} phrase heading the phrasal construction, while the associates are encoded with a post-head plural \isi{pronoun}. In (\ref{Example_6.95}) and (\ref{Example_6.96}), for instance, \textitbf{Lodia} and \textitbf{Pawlus} are the focal referents while the pronouns \textitbf{torang} ‘\textsc{1pl}’ and \textitbf{dorang} ‘\textsc{3pl}’ denote the associates, respectively.
A: word: kam	 gloss: 2PL
B: word: kamar	 gloss: room
C: word: tong	 gloss: 1PL
D: word: kaka	 gloss: oSb
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 615:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): tanta ada mara ___ dorang
Gloss (with missing item): aunt exist be.angry ___ 3PL
The English translation of this sentence is:‘aunt is being angry with Pawlus and his companions including Pawlus’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In her cross-linguistic semantic analysis of \isi{associative} plurals, \citet[470–471]{Moravcsik.2003} defines “\isi{associative} plurals as “constructions whose meaning is ‘X and X’s associate(s)’, where all members are individuals, X is the focal referent, and the associate(s) form a group centering around X”. In Papuan Malay, the focal referent is always encoded with a \isi{noun} or \isi{noun} phrase heading the phrasal construction, while the associates are encoded with a post-head plural \isi{pronoun}. In (\ref{Example_6.95}) and (\ref{Example_6.96}), for instance, \textitbf{Lodia} and \textitbf{its gloss ___} are the focal referents while the pronouns \textitbf{torang} ‘\textsc{1pl}’ and \textitbf{dorang} ‘\textsc{3pl}’ denote the associates, respectively.
A: word: pawlus	 gloss: Pawlus
B: word: pawla	 gloss: Pawla
C: word: glas	 gloss: glass
D: word: dong/dorang	 gloss: 3PL
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 616:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): tanta ada mara Pawlus ___
Gloss (with missing item): aunt exist be.angry Pawlus ___
The English translation of this sentence is:‘aunt is being angry with Pawlus and his companions including Pawlus’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In her cross-linguistic semantic analysis of \isi{associative} plurals, \citet[470–471]{Moravcsik.2003} defines “\isi{associative} plurals as “constructions whose meaning is ‘X and X’s associate(s)’, where all members are individuals, X is the focal referent, and the associate(s) form a group centering around X”. In Papuan Malay, the focal referent is always encoded with a \isi{noun} or \isi{noun} phrase heading the phrasal construction, while the associates are encoded with a post-head plural \isi{pronoun}. In (\ref{Example_6.95}) and (\ref{Example_6.96}), for instance, \textitbf{Lodia} and \textitbf{Pawlus} are the focal referents while the pronouns \textitbf{torang} ‘\textsc{1pl}’ and \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘\textsc{3pl}’ denote the associates, respectively.
A: word: dorang	 gloss: 3PL
B: word: dong/dorang	 gloss: 3PL
C: word: kam	 gloss: 2PL
D: word: smua	 gloss: all
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 617:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ___ Oktofina kam pulang jam brapa?
Gloss (with missing item): ___ Oktofina 2PL go.home hour several
The English translation of this sentence is:‘what time did you aunt Oktofina and your companions including you (Oktofina) come home?’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The reading of Papuan Malay \textsc{n} \textsc{pro-pl} \isi{noun} phrases is not only \isi{associative}, however. Adopting \citegen[479]{Moravcsik.2003} analysis, the reading of such \isi{noun} phrases is also “inclusory”, in that “all members of the plural set are summarily referred to by a \isi{pronoun}” (see also \citealt[25]{Haspelmath.2004}; \citealt{Gil.2009}). That is, the reference of the plural \isi{pronoun} in a Papuan Malay \textsc{n} \textsc{pro-pl} \isi{noun} phrase includes the reference of the focal referent, such that ``\textsc{pro} including X''. In (\ref{Example_6.95}), for instance, the \isi{pronoun} \textitbf{kam} ‘\textsc{2pl}’ includes not only the companions and the speaker, but all members of the plural set, “including \textitbf{Oktofina}”. That is, the \textsc{n} \textsc{pro-pl} \isi{noun} phrase \textitbf{Oktofina kam} does not signal an additive relation in the sense of ``Oktofina plus you companions''. Likewise in (\ref{Example_6.96}), the reference of \textitbf{dorang} ‘\textsc{3pl}’ includes not only the associates of the focal referent \textitbf{Pawlus}, but all members of the plural set, ``including Pawlus''.
A: word: tanta	 gloss: aunt
B: word: mantang	 gloss: former
C: word: nene	 gloss: grandmother
D: word: kace	 gloss: Kace
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 618:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): tanta ___ kam pulang jam brapa?
Gloss (with missing item): aunt ___ 2PL go.home hour several
The English translation of this sentence is:‘what time did you aunt Oktofina and your companions including you (Oktofina) come home?’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The reading of Papuan Malay \textsc{n} \textsc{pro-pl} \isi{noun} phrases is not only \isi{associative}, however. Adopting \citegen[479]{Moravcsik.2003} analysis, the reading of such \isi{noun} phrases is also “inclusory”, in that “all members of the plural set are summarily referred to by a \isi{pronoun}” (see also \citealt[25]{Haspelmath.2004}; \citealt{Gil.2009}). That is, the reference of the plural \isi{pronoun} in a Papuan Malay \textsc{n} \textsc{pro-pl} \isi{noun} phrase includes the reference of the focal referent, such that ``\textsc{pro} including X''. In (\ref{Example_6.95}), for instance, the \isi{pronoun} \textitbf{kam} ‘\textsc{2pl}’ includes not only the companions and the speaker, but all members of the plural set, “including \textitbf{its gloss ___}”. That is, the \textsc{n} \textsc{pro-pl} \isi{noun} phrase \textitbf{its gloss ___ kam} does not signal an additive relation in the sense of ``its gloss ___ plus you companions''. Likewise in (\ref{Example_6.96}), the reference of \textitbf{dorang} ‘\textsc{3pl}’ includes not only the associates of the focal referent \textitbf{Pawlus}, but all members of the plural set, ``including Pawlus''.
A: word: oktofina	 gloss: Oktofina
B: word: oktofernus	 gloss: Oktofernus
C: word: blanga	 gloss: cooking.pot
D: word: anjing	 gloss: dog
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 619:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Question 621:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Question 622:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ___ {Iskia} dong bunu babi, bapa desa dorang dong bunu babi
Gloss (with missing item): ___ Iskia 3PL kill pig father village 3PL 3PL kill pig
The English translation of this sentence is:‘father Iskia and his companions including Iskia killed a pig, father mayor and his companions including the mayor, they killed a pig’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Referential heterogeneity of Papuan Malay \isi{associative} inclusory expressions is illustrated with the examples in (\ref{Example_6.97}) to (\ref{Example_6.99}). In (\ref{Example_6.97}), \textitbf{the morpheme ___ Iskia dong} ‘its gloss ___ Iskia and them’ does not denote several people called \textitbf{Iskia}; neither does \textitbf{the morpheme ___ desa dorang} ‘its gloss ___ mayor and them’ refer to more than one mayor. The same applies to the examples in (\ref{Example_6.98}) and (\ref{Example_6.99}) (in this context \textitbf{dokter} ‘doctor’ has a \isi{definite} reading as the local hospital has only one doctor). In each case, the plural \isi{pronoun} encodes a heterogeneous set of associates “centering around X”, the focal referent. Moreover, the pronouns include the focal referents in their reference.
A: word: bapa	 gloss: father
B: word: bapa-ade	 gloss: uncle
C: word: tete	 gloss: grandfather
D: word: dong/dorang	 gloss: 3PL
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 623:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): {bapa} ___ dong bunu babi, bapa desa dorang dong bunu babi
Gloss (with missing item): father ___ 3PL kill pig father village 3PL 3PL kill pig
The English translation of this sentence is:‘father Iskia and his companions including Iskia killed a pig, father mayor and his companions including the mayor, they killed a pig’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Referential heterogeneity of Papuan Malay \isi{associative} inclusory expressions is illustrated with the examples in (\ref{Example_6.97}) to (\ref{Example_6.99}). In (\ref{Example_6.97}), \textitbf{bapa its gloss ___ dong} ‘father its gloss ___ and them’ does not denote several people called \textitbf{its gloss ___}; neither does \textitbf{bapa desa dorang} ‘father mayor and them’ refer to more than one mayor. The same applies to the examples in (\ref{Example_6.98}) and (\ref{Example_6.99}) (in this context \textitbf{dokter} ‘doctor’ has a \isi{definite} reading as the local hospital has only one doctor). In each case, the plural \isi{pronoun} encodes a heterogeneous set of associates “centering around X”, the focal referent. Moreover, the pronouns include the focal referents in their reference.
A: word: iskia	 gloss: Iskia
B: word: miskin	 gloss: be.poor
C: word: arbais	 gloss: Arbais
D: word: itu	 gloss: D.DIST
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 625:

Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Referential heterogeneity of Papuan Malay \isi{associative} inclusory expressions is illustrated with the examples in (\ref{Example_6.97}) to (\ref{Example_6.99}). Question 629:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): {bapa} ___ dong bunu babi, bapa desa dorang dong bunu babi
Gloss (with missing item): father ___ 3PL kill pig father village 3PL 3PL kill pig
The English translation of this sentence is:‘father Iskia and his companions including Iskia killed a pig, father mayor and his companions including the mayor, they killed a pig’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Referential heterogeneity of Papuan Malay \isi{associative} inclusory expressions is illustrated with the examples in (\ref{Example_6.97}) to (\ref{Example_6.99}). In (\ref{Example_6.97}), \textitbf{bapa its gloss ___ dong} ‘father its gloss ___ and them’ does not denote several people called \textitbf{its gloss ___}; neither does \textitbf{bapa desa dorang} ‘father mayor and them’ refer to more than one mayor. The same applies to the examples in (\ref{Example_6.98}) and (\ref{Example_6.99}) (in this context \textitbf{dokter} ‘doctor’ has a \isi{definite} reading as the local hospital has only one doctor). In each case, the plural \isi{pronoun} encodes a heterogeneous set of associates “centering around X”, the focal referent. Moreover, the pronouns include the focal referents in their reference.
A: word: iskia	 gloss: Iskia
B: word: miskin	 gloss: be.poor
C: word: arbais	 gloss: Arbais
D: word: hurki	 gloss: Hurki
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 630:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Question 632:

Question 633:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Referential heterogeneity of Papuan Malay \isi{associative} inclusory expressions is illustrated with the examples in (\ref{Example_6.97}) to (\ref{Example_6.99}). In each case, the plural \isi{pronoun} encodes a heterogeneous set of associates “centering around X”, the focal referent. Moreover, the pronouns include the focal referents in their reference.
A: word: dorang	 gloss: 3PL
B: word: dong/dorang	 gloss: 3PL
C: word: kam	 gloss: 2PL
D: word: mambramo	 gloss: Mambramo
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 634:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Gloss (with missing item): Ise 2SG stay at L.PROX just with ___ 3PL
The English translation of this sentence is:‘you Ise just stay here with aunt and her companions including aunt!’

A: word: mama-tua	 gloss: aunt

C: word: nene	 gloss: grandmother
D: word: isabela	 gloss: Isabela
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 636:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ___ {Iskia} dong bunu babi, bapa desa dorang dong bunu babi
Gloss (with missing item): ___ Iskia 3PL kill pig father village 3PL 3PL kill pig
The English translation of this sentence is:‘father Iskia and his companions including Iskia killed a pig, father mayor and his companions including the mayor, they killed a pig’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The semantic property “reference to groups” is shown in (\ref{Example_6.97}) and (\ref{Example_6.98}). In the two examples, the \textsc{n} \textsc{pro-pl} \isi{noun} phrases denote coherent groups of inherently associated individuals, namely \textitbf{the morpheme ___ Iskia dong} ‘its gloss ___ Iskia and them’, \textitbf{the morpheme ___ desa dorang} ‘its gloss ___ mayor and them’, and \textitbf{mama-tua dorang} ‘aunt and them’, respectively. These examples also illustrate the notion of “ranking” in \isi{associative} inclusory expressions. The pragmatically highest ranking members are the focal referents \textitbf{the morpheme ___ Iskia} ‘its gloss ___ Iskia’ and \textitbf{the morpheme ___ desa} ‘its gloss ___ mayor’ in (\ref{Example_6.97}), and \textitbf{mama-tua} ‘aunt’ in (\ref{Example_6.98}). The remaining members of the plural sets, by contrast, are not fully enumerated but subsumed under the plural \isi{pronoun} \textitbf{dong/dorang} ‘3\textsc{pl}’.
A: word: bapa	 gloss: father
B: word: bapa-ade	 gloss: uncle
C: word: tete	 gloss: grandfather
D: word: sama	 gloss: to
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 644:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ___ {Iskia} dong bunu babi, bapa desa dorang dong bunu babi
Gloss (with missing item): ___ Iskia 3PL kill pig father village 3PL 3PL kill pig
The English translation of this sentence is:‘father Iskia and his companions including Iskia killed a pig, father mayor and his companions including the mayor, they killed a pig’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The semantic property “reference to groups” is shown in (\ref{Example_6.97}) and (\ref{Example_6.98}). In the two examples, the \textsc{n} \textsc{pro-pl} \isi{noun} phrases denote coherent groups of inherently associated individuals, namely \textitbf{the morpheme ___ Iskia dong} ‘its gloss ___ Iskia and them’, \textitbf{the morpheme ___ desa dorang} ‘its gloss ___ mayor and them’, and \textitbf{mama-tua dorang} ‘aunt and them’, respectively. These examples also illustrate the notion of “ranking” in \isi{associative} inclusory expressions. The pragmatically highest ranking members are the focal referents \textitbf{the morpheme ___ Iskia} ‘its gloss ___ Iskia’ and \textitbf{the morpheme ___ desa} ‘its gloss ___ mayor’ in (\ref{Example_6.97}), and \textitbf{mama-tua} ‘aunt’ in (\ref{Example_6.98}). The remaining members of the plural sets, by contrast, are not fully enumerated but subsumed under the plural \isi{pronoun} \textitbf{dong/dorang} ‘3\textsc{pl}’.
A: word: bapa	 gloss: father
B: word: bapa-ade	 gloss: uncle
C: word: tete	 gloss: grandfather
D: word: senggi	 gloss: Senggi
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 645:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): {bapa} ___ dong bunu babi, bapa desa dorang dong bunu babi
Gloss (with missing item): father ___ 3PL kill pig father village 3PL 3PL kill pig
The English translation of this sentence is:‘father Iskia and his companions including Iskia killed a pig, father mayor and his companions including the mayor, they killed a pig’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The semantic property “reference to groups” is shown in (\ref{Example_6.97}) and (\ref{Example_6.98}). In the two examples, the \textsc{n} \textsc{pro-pl} \isi{noun} phrases denote coherent groups of inherently associated individuals, namely \textitbf{bapa its gloss ___ dong} ‘father its gloss ___ and them’, \textitbf{bapa desa dorang} ‘father mayor and them’, and \textitbf{mama-tua dorang} ‘aunt and them’, respectively. These examples also illustrate the notion of “ranking” in \isi{associative} inclusory expressions. The pragmatically highest ranking members are the focal referents \textitbf{bapa its gloss ___} ‘father its gloss ___’ and \textitbf{bapa desa} ‘father mayor’ in (\ref{Example_6.97}), and \textitbf{mama-tua} ‘aunt’ in (\ref{Example_6.98}). The remaining members of the plural sets, by contrast, are not fully enumerated but subsumed under the plural \isi{pronoun} \textitbf{dong/dorang} ‘3\textsc{pl}’.
A: word: iskia	 gloss: Iskia
B: word: miskin	 gloss: be.poor
C: word: arbais	 gloss: Arbais
D: word: dia	 gloss: 3SG
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 649:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Gloss (with missing item): father Iskia 3PL kill pig father village ___ 3PL kill pig
The English translation of this sentence is:‘father Iskia and his companions including Iskia killed a pig, father mayor and his companions including the mayor, they killed a pig’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The semantic property “reference to groups” is shown in (\ref{Example_6.97}) and (\ref{Example_6.98}). In the two examples, the \textsc{n} \textsc{pro-pl} \isi{noun} phrases denote coherent groups of inherently associated individuals, namely \textitbf{bapa Iskia dong} ‘father Iskia and them’, \textitbf{bapa desa the morpheme ___} ‘father mayor and them’, and \textitbf{mama-tua the morpheme ___} ‘aunt and them’, respectively. These examples also illustrate the notion of “ranking” in \isi{associative} inclusory expressions. The pragmatically highest ranking members are the focal referents \textitbf{bapa Iskia} ‘father Iskia’ and \textitbf{bapa desa} ‘father mayor’ in (\ref{Example_6.97}), and \textitbf{mama-tua} ‘aunt’ in (\ref{Example_6.98}). The remaining members of the plural sets, by contrast, are not fully enumerated but subsumed under the plural \isi{pronoun} \textitbf{dong/the morpheme ___} ‘3\textsc{pl}’.
A: word: dorang	 gloss: 3PL
B: word: dong/dorang	 gloss: 3PL
C: word: kam	 gloss: 2PL
D: word: derang	 gloss: 3PL
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 650:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): Ise ko tinggal di sini suda deng ___ dorang!
Gloss (with missing item): Ise 2SG stay at L.PROX just with ___ 3PL
The English translation of this sentence is:‘you Ise just stay here with aunt and her companions including aunt!’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The semantic property “reference to groups” is shown in (\ref{Example_6.97}) and (\ref{Example_6.98}). In the two examples, the \textsc{n} \textsc{pro-pl} \isi{noun} phrases denote coherent groups of inherently associated individuals, namely \textitbf{bapa Iskia dong} ‘father Iskia and them’, \textitbf{bapa desa dorang} ‘father mayor and them’, and \textitbf{the morpheme ___ dorang} ‘its gloss ___ and them’, respectively. These examples also illustrate the notion of “ranking” in \isi{associative} inclusory expressions. The pragmatically highest ranking members are the focal referents \textitbf{bapa Iskia} ‘father Iskia’ and \textitbf{bapa desa} ‘father mayor’ in (\ref{Example_6.97}), and \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ in (\ref{Example_6.98}). The remaining members of the plural sets, by contrast, are not fully enumerated but subsumed under the plural \isi{pronoun} \textitbf{dong/dorang} ‘3\textsc{pl}’.
A: word: mama-tua	 gloss: aunt
B: word: mama-ade	 gloss: aunt
C: word: nene	 gloss: grandmother
D: word: pawlus	 gloss: Pawlus
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 651:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Question 652:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ___ Oktofina kam pulang jam brapa?
Gloss (with missing item): ___ Oktofina 2PL go.home hour several
The English translation of this sentence is:‘what time did you aunt Oktofina and your companions including you (Oktofina) come home?’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Typically, the associates are encoded with the third person plural \isi{pronoun}. Less frequently, the associates are encoded with the first person plural \isi{pronoun}, as in (\ref{Example_6.95}), repeated as (\ref{Example_6.101}), or with the second person plural \isi{pronoun} as in (\ref{Example_6.101}) and (\ref{Example_6.102}). In \isi{associative} inclusory expressions formed with the second person plural \isi{pronoun}, the focal referent is typically the addressee as in (\ref{Example_6.101}). Alternatively, although much less often, one of the associates can be the addressee as in (\ref{Example_6.102}) (the focal referent \textitbf{Lodia} was not present during this conversation).
A: word: tanta	 gloss: aunt
B: word: mantang	 gloss: former
C: word: nene	 gloss: grandmother
D: word: banyak	 gloss: many
Please only return the letter (A–D).

B: word: kamar	 gloss: room
C: word: tong	 gloss: 1PL
D: word: dengang	 gloss: with
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 661:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ___ Oktofina kam pulang jam brapa?
Gloss (with missing item): ___ Oktofina 2PL go.home hour several
The English translation of this sentence is:‘what time did you aunt Oktofina and your companions including you (Oktofina) come home?’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Typically, the associates are encoded with the third person plural \isi{pronoun}. Less frequently, the associates are encoded with the first person plural \isi{pronoun}, as in (\ref{Example_6.95}), repeated as (\ref{Example_6.101}), or with the second person plural \isi{pronoun} as in (\ref{Example_6.101}) and (\ref{Example_6.102}). In \isi{associative} inclusory expressions formed with the second person plural \isi{pronoun}, the focal referent is typically the addressee as in (\ref{Example_6.101}). Alternatively, although much less often, one of the associates can be the addressee as in (\ref{Example_6.102}) (the focal referent \textitbf{Lodia} was not present during this conversation).
A: word: tanta	 gloss: aunt
B: word: mantang	 gloss: former
C: word: nene	 gloss: grandmother
D: word: orang	 gloss: person
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Alternatively, although much less often, one of the associates can be the addressee as in (\ref{Example_6.102}) (the focal referent \textitbf{Lodia} was not present during this conversation).

Question 663:

Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Typically, the associates are encoded with the third person plural \isi{pronoun}. Less frequently, the associates are encoded with the first person plural \isi{pronoun}, as in (\ref{Example_6.95}), repeated as (\ref{Example_6.101}), or with the second person plural \isi{pronoun} as in (\ref{Example_6.101}) and (\ref{Example_6.102}). Question 664:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ___ Oktofina kam pulang jam brapa?
Gloss (with missing item): ___ Oktofina 2PL go.home hour several
The English translation of this sentence is:‘what time did you aunt Oktofina and your companions including you (Oktofina) come home?’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In (\ref{Example_6.95}) to (\ref{Example_6.102}), the number of referents is not specified. When only two participants are involved, however, that is the focal referent plus one associate, Papuan Malay speakers very often use a dual construction, such that ``bare \textsc{n} \textsc{pro-pl} \textitbf{dua}'', as in (\ref{Example_6.103}). Like dual constructions with an additive reading (§\ref{Para_6.2.2.1}), the associate is not explicitly mentioned but subsumed under the post-head \isi{numeral} \textitbf{dua} ‘two’.
A: word: tanta	 gloss: aunt
B: word: mantang	 gloss: former
C: word: nene	 gloss: grandmother
D: word: miflal	 gloss: Miflal
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Like dual constructions with an additive reading (§\ref{Para_6.2.2.1}), the associate is not explicitly mentioned but subsumed under the post-head \isi{numeral} \textitbf{dua} ‘two’.

Question 667:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ___ kitong dua kluar mo pergi cari pinang
Gloss (with missing item): ___ 1PL two go.out want go search betel.nut
The English translation of this sentence is:‘uncle and I went out and wanted to look for betel nuts’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In (\ref{Example_6.95}) to (\ref{Example_6.102}), the number of referents is not specified. When only two participants are involved, however, that is the focal referent plus one associate, Papuan Malay speakers very often use a dual construction, such that ``bare \textsc{n} \textsc{pro-pl} \textitbf{dua}'', as in (\ref{Example_6.103}). Like dual constructions with an additive reading (§\ref{Para_6.2.2.1}), the associate is not explicitly mentioned but subsumed under the post-head \isi{numeral} \textitbf{dua} ‘two’.
A: word: om	 gloss: uncle

C: word: tete	 gloss: grandfather
D: word: deng	 gloss: with
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 669:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): om kitong ___ kluar mo pergi cari pinang
Gloss (with missing item): uncle 1PL ___ go.out want go search betel.nut
The English translation of this sentence is:‘uncle and I went out and wanted to look for betel nuts’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In (\ref{Example_6.95}) to (\ref{Example_6.102}), the number of referents is not specified. When only its gloss ___ participants are involved, however, that is the focal referent plus one associate, Papuan Malay speakers very often use a the morpheme ___l construction, such that ``bare \textsc{n} \textsc{pro-pl} \textitbf{the morpheme ___}'', as in (\ref{Example_6.103}). Like the morpheme ___l constructions with an additive reading (§\ref{Para_6.2.2.1}), the associate is not explicitly mentioned but subsumed under the post-head \isi{numeral} \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’.
A: word: dua	 gloss: two
B: word: siduasi	 gloss: Siduas
C: word: kedua	 gloss: second
D: word: cantik	 gloss: be.beautiful
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 670:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): Ise ko tinggal di sini suda deng ___ dorang!
Gloss (with missing item): Ise 2SG stay at L.PROX just with ___ 3PL
The English translation of this sentence is:‘you Ise just stay here with aunt and her companions including aunt!’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: As for the lexical classes employed in \isi{associative plural} expressions, \citet[3]{Daniel.2013} observe “a clear preference for \isi{associative} plurals formed from proper names over kin terms over non-kin human common nouns over nonhuman nouns”. This also applies to Papuan Malay, in that the focal referents in \isi{associative} inclusory expressions are formed from human nouns while nonhuman animate focal referents are unattested. Among human nouns in the corpus, however, kin terms as in (\ref{Example_6.98}) are more common than proper names as in (\ref{Example_6.95}). This has to do with the fact that culturally people prefer not to use proper names, if they have another option, especially if the person is older and/or present. In addition, although not very often, \isi{associative plural} expressions are formed from non-kin terms such as the title \isi{noun} expression \textitbf{bapa desa} ‘father mayor’ in (\ref{Example_6.97}), or the common \isi{noun} \textitbf{dokter} ‘doctor’ in (\ref{Example_6.99}). (See also {Moravcsik 2003: 471–473}.)
A: word: mama-tua	 gloss: aunt
B: word: mama-ade	 gloss: aunt
C: word: nene	 gloss: grandmother
D: word: dengang	 gloss: with
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 671:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): Ise ko tinggal di sini suda deng mama-tua ___
Gloss (with missing item): Ise 2SG stay at L.PROX just with aunt ___
The English translation of this sentence is:‘you Ise just stay here with aunt and her companions including aunt!’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: As for the lexical classes employed in \isi{associative plural} expressions, \citet[3]{Daniel.2013} observe “a clear preference for \isi{associative} plurals formed from proper names over kin terms over non-kin human common nouns over nonhuman nouns”. This also applies to Papuan Malay, in that the focal referents in \isi{associative} inclusory expressions are formed from human nouns while nonhuman animate focal referents are unattested. Among human nouns in the corpus, however, kin terms as in (\ref{Example_6.98}) are more common than proper names as in (\ref{Example_6.95}). This has to do with the fact that culturally people prefer not to use proper names, if they have another option, especially if the person is older and/or present. In addition, although not very often, \isi{associative plural} expressions are formed from non-kin terms such as the title \isi{noun} expression \textitbf{bapa desa} ‘father mayor’ in (\ref{Example_6.97}), or the common \isi{noun} \textitbf{dokter} ‘doctor’ in (\ref{Example_6.99}). (See also {Moravcsik 2003: 471–473}.)
A: word: dorang	 gloss: 3PL
B: word: dong/dorang	 gloss: 3PL
C: word: kam	 gloss: 2PL
D: word: markus	 gloss: Markus
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 675:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ___ {Iskia} dong bunu babi, bapa desa dorang dong bunu babi
Gloss (with missing item): ___ Iskia 3PL kill pig father village 3PL 3PL kill pig
The English translation of this sentence is:‘father Iskia and his companions including Iskia killed a pig, father mayor and his companions including the mayor, they killed a pig’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: As for the lexical classes employed in \isi{associative plural} expressions, \citet[3]{Daniel.2013} observe “a clear preference for \isi{associative} plurals formed from proper names over kin terms over non-kin human common nouns over nonhuman nouns”. This also applies to Papuan Malay, in that the focal referents in \isi{associative} inclusory expressions are formed from human nouns while nonhuman animate focal referents are unattested. Among human nouns in the corpus, however, kin terms as in (\ref{Example_6.98}) are more common than proper names as in (\ref{Example_6.95}). This has to do with the fact that culturally people prefer not to use proper names, if they have another option, especially if the person is older and/or present. In addition, although not very often, \isi{associative plural} expressions are formed from non-kin terms such as the title \isi{noun} expression \textitbf{the morpheme ___ desa} ‘its gloss ___ mayor’ in (\ref{Example_6.97}), or the common \isi{noun} \textitbf{dokter} ‘doctor’ in (\ref{Example_6.99}). (See also {Moravcsik 2003: 471–473}.)
A: word: bapa	 gloss: father
B: word: bapa-ade	 gloss: uncle
C: word: tete	 gloss: grandfather
D: word: kitorang	 gloss: 1PL
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 677:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): {bapa} {Iskia} ___ bunu babi, bapa desa dorang dong bunu babi
Gloss (with missing item): father Iskia ___ kill pig father village 3PL 3PL kill pig
The English translation of this sentence is:‘father Iskia and his companions including Iskia killed a pig, father mayor and his companions including the mayor, they killed a pig’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: As for the lexical classes employed in \isi{associative plural} expressions, \citet[3]{Daniel.2013} observe “a clear preference for \isi{associative} plurals formed from proper names over kin terms over non-kin human common nouns over nonhuman nouns”. This also applies to Papuan Malay, in that the focal referents in \isi{associative} inclusory expressions are formed from human nouns while nonhuman animate focal referents are unattested. Among human nouns in the corpus, however, kin terms as in (\ref{Example_6.98}) are more common than proper names as in (\ref{Example_6.95}). This has to do with the fact that culturally people prefer not to use proper names, if they have another option, especially if the person is older and/or present. In addition, although not very often, \isi{associative plural} expressions are formed from non-kin terms such as the title \isi{noun} expression \textitbf{bapa desa} ‘father mayor’ in (\ref{Example_6.97}), or the common \isi{noun} \textitbf{dokter} ‘doctor’ in (\ref{Example_6.99}). (See also {Moravcsik 2003: 471–473}.)
A: word: dong	 gloss: 3PL
B: word: dong/dorang	 gloss: 3PL
C: word: kam	 gloss: 2PL
D: word: derang	 gloss: 3PL
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 678:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): {bapa} {Iskia} dong bunu babi, ___ desa dorang dong bunu babi
Gloss (with missing item): father Iskia 3PL kill pig ___ village 3PL 3PL kill pig
The English translation of this sentence is:‘father Iskia and his companions including Iskia killed a pig, father mayor and his companions including the mayor, they killed a pig’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: As for the lexical classes employed in \isi{associative plural} expressions, \citet[3]{Daniel.2013} observe “a clear preference for \isi{associative} plurals formed from proper names over kin terms over non-kin human common nouns over nonhuman nouns”. This also applies to Papuan Malay, in that the focal referents in \isi{associative} inclusory expressions are formed from human nouns while nonhuman animate focal referents are unattested. Among human nouns in the corpus, however, kin terms as in (\ref{Example_6.98}) are more common than proper names as in (\ref{Example_6.95}). This has to do with the fact that culturally people prefer not to use proper names, if they have another option, especially if the person is older and/or present. In addition, although not very often, \isi{associative plural} expressions are formed from non-kin terms such as the title \isi{noun} expression \textitbf{the morpheme ___ desa} ‘its gloss ___ mayor’ in (\ref{Example_6.97}), or the common \isi{noun} \textitbf{dokter} ‘doctor’ in (\ref{Example_6.99}). (See also {Moravcsik 2003: 471–473}.)
A: word: bapa	 gloss: father
B: word: bapa-ade	 gloss: uncle
C: word: tete	 gloss: grandfather
D: word: martin	 gloss: Martin
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 679:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. This also applies to Papuan Malay, in that the focal referents in \isi{associative} inclusory expressions are formed from human nouns while nonhuman animate focal referents are unattested. This has to do with the fact that culturally people prefer not to use proper names, if they have another option, especially if the person is older and/or present. In addition, although not very often, \isi{associative plural} expressions are formed from non-kin terms such as the title \isi{noun} expression \textitbf{bapa the morpheme ___} ‘father mayor’ in (\ref{Example_6.97}), or the common \isi{noun} \textitbf{dokter} ‘doctor’ in (\ref{Example_6.99}). Question 680:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): {bapa} {Iskia} dong bunu babi, bapa desa ___ dong bunu babi
Gloss (with missing item): father Iskia 3PL kill pig father village ___ 3PL kill pig
The English translation of this sentence is:‘father Iskia and his companions including Iskia killed a pig, father mayor and his companions including the mayor, they killed a pig’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: As for the lexical classes employed in \isi{associative plural} expressions, \citet[3]{Daniel.2013} observe “a clear preference for \isi{associative} plurals formed from proper names over kin terms over non-kin human common nouns over nonhuman nouns”. This also applies to Papuan Malay, in that the focal referents in \isi{associative} inclusory expressions are formed from human nouns while nonhuman animate focal referents are unattested. Among human nouns in the corpus, however, kin terms as in (\ref{Example_6.98}) are more common than proper names as in (\ref{Example_6.95}). This has to do with the fact that culturally people prefer not to use proper names, if they have another option, especially if the person is older and/or present. In addition, although not very often, \isi{associative plural} expressions are formed from non-kin terms such as the title \isi{noun} expression \textitbf{bapa desa} ‘father mayor’ in (\ref{Example_6.97}), or the common \isi{noun} \textitbf{dokter} ‘doctor’ in (\ref{Example_6.99}). (See also {Moravcsik 2003: 471–473}.)
A: word: dorang	 gloss: 3PL
B: word: dong/dorang	 gloss: 3PL
C: word: kam	 gloss: 2PL
D: word: dodo	 gloss: Dodo
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 681:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): Ise ko tinggal di sini suda deng ___ dorang!
Gloss (with missing item): Ise 2SG stay at L.PROX just with ___ 3PL
The English translation of this sentence is:‘you Ise just stay here with aunt and her companions including aunt!’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Concerning the relationship between the focal referent X and the associates, {Daniel and \citet[3]{Moravcsik.2013}} note that “the group may be: (i) X’s family, (ii) X’s friends, or familiar associates, or (iii) an occasional group that X is a member of” with “kin forming the most commonly understood associates”. Papuan Malay also conforms to this cross-linguistic finding in that the associates are most often X’s family as in (\ref{Example_6.98}). Less commonly, X’s associates are friends or companions in a shared activity as in (\ref{Example_6.99}). Associative plurals denoting occasional groups or, according to {\citet[473]{Moravcsik.2003}}, “incidental association”, have not been identified in the corpus.
A: word: mama-tua	 gloss: aunt
B: word: mama-ade	 gloss: aunt
C: word: nene	 gloss: grandmother
D: word: ipa	 gloss: natural.sciences
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 683:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ___ dong
Gloss (with missing item): ___ 3PL
The English translation of this sentence is:‘mother and the others’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The \isi{associative plural} interpretation for \isi{noun} phrases with adnominal plural \isi{pronoun} is also quite common for other \ili{regional Malay varieties}, such as Ambon, Bali Berkuak, Dobo, Kupang, Manado, or \ili{Sri Lanka Malay}. In \ili{Ternate Malay}, however, pronouns do not have adnominal functions {\citep[141]{Litamahuputty.2012}}. The \isi{associative plural} reading of \isi{noun} phrases with adnominal plural pronouns found in \ili{regional Malay varieties} is illustrated in the examples in (\ref{Example_6.104}) to (\ref{Example_6.109}).
A: word: mama	 gloss: mother
B: word: mama-ade	 gloss: aunt
C: word: orang-tua	 gloss: parent
D: word: martin	 gloss: Martin
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 687:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ___ dong
Gloss (with missing item): ___ 3PL
The English translation of this sentence is:‘mother and the others’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In Ambon, Dobo, Kupang, and \ili{Sri Lanka Malay}, the adnominal \isi{pronoun} is postposed as in Papuan Malay, as demonstrated in (\ref{Example_6.104}) to (\ref{Example_6.107}). In Balai Berkuak or \ili{Manado Malay}, by contrast, the \isi{pronoun} is in pre-head position, as shown in (\ref{Example_6.108}) and (\ref{Example_6.109}).
A: word: mama	 gloss: mother
B: word: mama-ade	 gloss: aunt
C: word: orang-tua	 gloss: parent
D: word: ambil	 gloss: fetch
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 695:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ___ dong
Gloss (with missing item): ___ 3PL
The English translation of this sentence is:‘mother and the others’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In all examples, the \isi{pronoun} is the third person plural \isi{pronoun}. In most varieties only the short \isi{pronoun} form is used as for instance in Ambon or \ili{Dobo Malay}, as shown in (\ref{Example_6.104}) and (\ref{Example_6.105}). Only in \ili{Manado Malay} are the short and long forms used, as shown in (\ref{Example_6.109}). Contrasting with Papuan Malay, these \ili{regional Malay varieties} do not use the first and second person plural pronouns to express \isi{associative} plurality.
A: word: mama	 gloss: mother
B: word: mama-ade	 gloss: aunt
C: word: orang-tua	 gloss: parent
D: word: smua	 gloss: all
Please only return the letter (A–D).

Question 698:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore.
